MCCLAIN COUNTY DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES - THE DFC SUPPORT PROGRAM HAS TWO GOALS: 1.	ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITIES, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE NON-PROFIT AGENCIES AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS TO SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF COMMUNITY COALITIONS WORKING TO PREVENT AND REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AMONG YOUTH. 2.	REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AMONG YOUTH AND, OVER TIME, REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AMONG ADULTS BY ADDRESSING THE FACTORS IN A COMMUNITY THAT INCREASE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND PROMOTING THE FACTORS THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE.  REQUIRED ACTIVITIES: UTILIZE THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (SPF) TO IDENTIFY AND SELECT COMPREHENSIVE, DATA- DRIVEN SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION STRATEGIES. UTILIZE COMMUNITY ANTI-DRUG COALITIONS OF AMERICA (CADCA) SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY CHANGE. PROVIDE INFORMATION BUILD SKILLS PROVIDE SOCIAL SUPPORT REDUCE BARRIERS/ENHANCE ACCESS CHANGE CONSEQUENCES/INCENTIVES ALTER THE PHYSICAL DESIGN OF THE ENVIRONMENT CHANGE POLICY AND RULES UTILIZE COMMUNITY COALITION BUILDING STRATEGIES TO ADVANCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION EFFORTS WITH THE IDENTIFIED COALITION COMMUNITY ALLIANCE OF RESOURCES FOR EVERYONE (CARE) DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES AND ACROSS THE COUNTY. BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN MCCLAIN COUNTY TO ADDRESS UNDERAGE DRINKING, NON-MEDICAL USE OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS AND TOBACCO USE AMONG PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE. COLLECT AND REPORT COMMUNITY LEVEL DATA TO DETERMINE PROGRESS TOWARD ACHIEVING GOALS.

DALLAS AREA DRUG PREVENTION PARTNERSHIP-SOUTH (DADPP-SOUTH) - DALLAS COUNTY IS A LARGE, DYNAMIC, AND DIVERSE AREA. WITH OVER 2.6 MILLION RESIDENTS, IT IS A PART OF THE DALLAS/FORT WORTH METROPLEX, MADE UP OF SOME OF THE FASTEST-GROWING CITIES AND COUNTIES IN THE STATE OF TEXAS WITH A COMBINED POPULATION OF ALMOST 7 MILLION PEOPLE. DALLAS COUNTY IS HOME TO OVER 20 FORTUNE 500 COMPANIES WITH MANY MORE NOTABLE COMPANIES EITHER HOME-BASED OR WITH A REGIONAL PRESENCE. MOST DAYS, THERE IS NEWS OF ANOTHER LARGE CORPORATION MOVING INTO THE AREA – ATTRACTED TO THE STRONG EMPLOYMENT BASE, GROWING SUBURBS WITH GOOD HOUSING AND TOP-RATED SCHOOLS, TAX INCENTIVES, PROXIMITY TO AN INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, AND OF COURSE, A VIBRANT ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT, SPORTS, AND SOCIAL SCENE.  DESPITE THIS VIGOROUS AND SPIRITED ENVIRONMENT, AS WELL AS NEIGHBORHOODS OF GREAT WEALTH, THERE ARE AREAS IN DALLAS COUNTY WHERE INCOME DISPARITIES, HEALTH INEQUITIES, AND CRIME ARE THE NORM RATHER THAN THE EXCEPTION. MANY HAVE HIGHER INCARCERATION RATES, LOWER AVERAGE HOUSEHOLD INCOME, AND HIGHER NUMBER OF DRUG-RELATED OFFENSES COMPARED TO MORE AFFLUENT AREAS. CURRENTLY, DATA ON YOUTH DRUG USE HAS ONLY BEEN AVAILABLE ON A COUNTY-WIDE/REGIONAL BASIS BUT WE RECOGNIZE THERE ARE UNIQUE CHARACTERISTICS IN THESE “COMMUNITIES WITHIN THE COMMUNITY”.  ACCORDINGLY, DATA COLLECTION AND SUBSEQUENT PREVENTION STRATEGIES REQUIRE A UNIQUE AND INNOVATIVE APPROACH, CUSTOMIZED TO THE SPECIFIC TRENDS IN THAT AREA. WE, AS A COMMUNITY, CANNOT CONTINUE TO SHOWCASE ALL THE POSITIVE ASPECTS OF DALLAS, WHILE DISMISSING THE WEAKNESSES THAT EXIST IN SOME PARTS OF OUR COMMUNITY – WEAKNESSES THAT NEGATIVELY AFFECT THE LIVES OF ITS CITIZENS. WE BELIEVE IT IS ABOUT RESPECTING AND WANTING THE BEST FOR THOSE THAT LIVE AND WORK IN THESE MARGINALIZED AREAS.  OUR COALITION, DALLAS AREA DRUG PREVENTION PARTNERSHIP-SOUTH (DADPP-SOUTH) HAS IDENTIFIED SIX ZIP CODES IN DALLAS COUNTY EXPERIENCING THE GREATEST CHALLENGES OF THE AREA:  CRIME, DRUG USE, POVERTY, POOR EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES, LACK OF HEALTHY FOOD OPTIONS, AGING SCHOOLS AND INFRASTRUCTURE.  EVEN SO, THIS COMMUNITY HAS MANY CITIZENS AND GROUPS THAT STRONGLY DESIRE A REVITALIZATION BUT KNOW IT WILL TAKE A COHESIVE AND UNIFIED EFFORT TO CREATE REAL CHANGE. DADPP-SOUTH HAS DEVELOPED CRITICAL RELATIONSHIPS WITHIN THIS COMMUNITY TO INCREASE COLLABORATION AND CREATE BEST-PRACTICE DRUG PREVENTION STRATEGIES. THE GOAL OF DADPP-SOUTH IS TO IMPLEMENT EVIDENCE-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIES AIMED AT POPULATION-LEVEL CHANGE IN OUR TARGET ZIP CODES BY 1) LIMITING YOUTH ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES; 2) CHANGING THE CULTURE AND CONTEXT WITHIN WHICH DECISIONS ARE MADE ABOUT SUBSTANCES; 3) SHIFTING THE CONSEQUENCES ASSOCIATED WITH YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE; AND 4) ADDRESSING ISSUES RELATED TO HEALTH DISPARITIES AND PROMOTING HEALTH EQUITY.  DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE, AND THE PROBLEMS IT CREATES, WILL IMPEDE THE BEST EFFORTS OF ALMOST EVERY OTHER COMMUNITY INITIATIVE DUE TO ITS PERVASIVE NEGATIVE EFFECT, AND ACCORDINGLY, PREVENTION IS AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT. BY WORKING TOGETHER AS A COALITION, THIS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT IS BASED ON THE SIMPLE PREMISE THAT LOCAL PEOPLE ARE IN THE BEST POSITION TO SOLVE LOCAL PROBLEMS, INCLUDING THE PREVENTION OF PROBLEMS BEFORE THEY OCCUR. COALITIONS RECOGNIZE THAT PEOPLE ARE MORE LIKELY TO SUPPORT WHAT THEY HELP CREATE, AND CHANGE IS MOST LIKELY TO OCCUR WHEN THE PROCESS ENGAGES MULTIPLE SECTORS OF A COMMUNITY IN A COOPERATIVE APPROACH. DADPP-SOUTH IS MADE UP OF CONCERNED CITIZENS REPRESENTING THE VARIOUS COMMUNITY SECTORS, EACH WITH THEIR OWN UNIQUE EXPERTISE, NETWORKS, INFLUENCE, AND PERSPECTIVE. TOGETHER, WE WILL WORK TO FACILITATE ACCURATE DATA COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION, CONDUCT PUBLIC AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS, PROMOTE HEALTH MEDIA MESSAGES, CONDUCT COMMUNITY OUTREACH, AND EDUCATE YOUTH, PARENTS, AND THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE. AS A RESULT, WE BELIEVE THAT OUR STRATEGIES WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE AND PREVENT YOUTH DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE IN THE COMMUNITY

DELAWARE COUNTY COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP'S DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT - THE DELAWARE COUNTY COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP (DCCP) DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT WILL INCREASE COLLABORATION AND DECREASE SUBSTANCE USE IN DELAWARE COUNTY, OKLAHOMA. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DECREASING UNDERAGE DRINKING, TOBACCO USE AND VAPING, AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG MISUSE THROUGH USE CADCA’S SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY CHANGE AND THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK.

DRUG-FREE ASHLEY COUNTY COALITION DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT - THE DRUG-FREE ASHLEY COUNTY (ARKANSAS) COALITION ENDEAVORS TO JOIN OTHER COMMUNITIES IN OUR NATION TO FIGHT THE EPIDEMIC CONDITION OF OVERWHELMING SUBSTANCE ABUSE.  QUOTED FROM A REPORT BY THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF COUNTIES RESEARCH FOUNDATION, “AT BOTH THE COUNTY AND REGIONAL LEVEL, COALITIONS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ADDRESSING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  COUNTIES HAVE EXPRESSED THAT SILOED APPROACHES ARE INEFFECTIVE AND ULTIMATELY LESSEN IMPACT.  IN ADDITION TO ADDRESSING LIMITED REACH, LEVERAGING COALITIONS CAN HELP LOCAL LEADERS CONSOLIDATE RESOURCES AND EXPERTISE, AND DISTRIBUTE RISK AND RESPONSIBILITY ACROSS MULTIPLE ORGANIZATIONS WHILE INCREASING POTENTIAL IMPACT.  BY ALIGNING WITH SCHOOL BOARDS, FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, LOCAL AND REGIONAL ENTITIES, PHILANTHROPIC ORGANIZATIONS AND THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SECTOR, COUNTIES CAN FOSTER A DEEPER COMMITMENT AND MORE EFFECTIVE COMMUNITY RESPONSE TO SOLVING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE ISSUES.”  BASED ON THIS RATIONALE, THE DRUG-FREE ASHLEY COUNTY COALITION EMBRACES THE TWO GOALS OF THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION THROUGH ITS DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT GRANT.  THOSE GOALS ARE AS FOLLOWS:  “1.  ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITIES, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE NON-PROFIT AGENCIES, AS WELL AS FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS TO SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF COMMUNITY COALITIONS WORKING TO PREVENT AND REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH (INDIVIDUALS 18 YEARS OF AGE AND YOUNGER).  2.  REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH AND, OVER TIME, REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG ADULTS BY ADDRESSING THE FACTORS IN A COMMUNITY THAT INCREASES THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE AND PROMOTING THE FACTORS THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE.”  SPECIFICALLY, THE DRUG-FREE ASHLEY COUNTY COALITION UNDERTAKES THE CHALLENGE TO REDUCE PREVIOUS 30-DAY USE OF ALCOHOL/UNDERAGE DRINKING, MARIJUANA USE, AND MISUSE OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS BY AT LEAST 1% PER YEAR FOR THE NEXT FIVE TO TEN YEARS.  THIS OUTCOME WILL BE EVALUATED THROUGH THE ARKANSAS PREVENTION NEEDS ASSESSMENT (APNA) SURVEY DONE ANNUALLY IN ARKANSAS SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND WILL BRING ALL REPORTED INSTANCES FOR YOUTH OF ASHLEY COUNTY DOWN TO OR BELOW THE STATE AVERAGES.  IN ADDITION TO THE APNA SURVEY, ASHLEY COUNTY YOUTH WILL BE SURVEYED ANNUALLY AS TO THEIR PERCEPTIONS OF COUNTY-WIDE SUBSTANCE ABUSE, ITS ROOT CAUSES, AND VARIANTS, AND WHAT STRATEGIES CAN BE ENGAGED TO COUNTER THOSE CONDITIONS.

SALEM COUNTY HEALTHY COMMUNITIES COALITION - THE MISSION OF LIVE HEALTHY SALEM COUNTY’S SALEM COUNTY HEALTHY COMMUNITIES COALITION (SCHCC) IS TO PREVENT AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN SALEM COUNTY THROUGH COLLABORATION BETWEEN COMMUNITY AND INSTITUTIONAL PARTNERS.  FOR THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROPOSAL, THE SCHCC WILL USE THE SOUTHWEST COUNCIL INC. AS A FISCAL AGENT.  SALEM COUNTY, NJ IS A SPARSELY POPULATED COUNTY ON THE BORDER WITH DELAWARE. THE COUNTY HAS RICH AGRICULTURAL ROOTS BUT IS ECONOMICALLY DEPRIVED WITH LIMITED POCKETS OF PROSPERITY.  THE 2020 CENSUS DOCUMENTED 64,837 PEOPLE LIVING IN SALEM’S 15 MUNICIPALITIES AND SURROUNDING LAND. THIRTY PERCENT OF HOUSEHOLDS SPEND MORE THAN 50% OF THEIR INCOME ON RENT.   TWENTY-THREE PERCENT OF SALEM COUNTY CHILDREN UNDER 18 LIVE BELOW POVERTY, COMPARED TO THE STATE AVERAGE OF 12%. IT IS LESS ETHNICALLY DIVERSE THAN THE REST OF THE STATE WITH 72% OF RESIDENTS IDENTIFYING AS WHITE ALONE. AFRICAN AMERICANS MAKE UP 15% OF RESIDENTS AND 10% OF THE COUNTY POPULATION IS LATINO OF ANY RACE.  THE 2021 COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS PUT SALEM COUNTY AT 20 OUT OF 21 COUNTIES IN TERMS OF POOREST HEALTH OUTCOMES AND LOWER PRESENCE OF HEALTH FACTORS. THE PRIMARY DRUGS OF CONCERN ARE TOBACCO, ALCOHOL, AND MARIJUANA, FOLLOWED BY PRESCRIPTION DRUGS. BASED ON THIS INITIAL ASSESSMENT THE PRIMARY ROOT CAUSES FOR YOUTH  SUBSTANCE USE IN SALEM COUNTY INCLUDE 1. INCREASED AVAILABILITY OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUGS 2. MINIMAL PERCEPTION OF HARM OF YOUTH TOBACCO AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG YOUTH AND ADULTS. 3.INEQUITABLE ACCESS TO SERVICES AND OPPORTUNITIES THAT SUPPORT YOUTH MENTAL HEALTH AND WELLBEING.  TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES, THE SCHCC PLANS TO ENGAGE YOUTH AND ADULTS ACROSS THE COUNTY TO :  1. BUILD RESILIENCY IN THE FACE OF ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES, ESPECIALLY IN THE COMMUNITIES OF SALEM CITY AND PENNS GROVE/CARNEYS POINT BY ESTABLISHING SCHOOL RESILIENCY TEAMS PREPARED TO SUPPORT STUDENTS WITH ACE DRIVEN ACADEMIC CHALLENGES.  THIS WILL BUILD PROTECTIVE FACTORS INCLUDING IMPROVED ACADEMIC ATTAINMENT/SUCCESS, INCREASED ATTACHMENT TO SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY AND INCREASED PRESENCE OF CARING AND SUPPORTIVE ADULTS. 2. CREATE A CULTURE OF CARE AND CONCERN ABOUT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE THAT INCREASES THE PERCEIVED RISK OF HARM AND PARENT AND PEER DISAPPROVAL FOR MARIJUANA, TOBACCO, ALCOHOL AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE BY BUILDING AWARENESS OF HOW YOUTH USE THESE SUBSTANCES AMONG PARENTS, EDUCATORS AND PHYSICIANS AND BY CHANGING POLICY TO INCREASE CONSEQUENCE FOR ADULTS THAT PROVIDE ALCOHOL TO YOUTH AS WELL AS DISCOURAGING POLICY THAT INCREASES ACCESS TO GOVERNMENT SANCTIONED MARIJUANA.  3. BUILD SKILLS TO PREPARE YOUTH TO ADVOCATE FOR PREVENTION POLICY AND TO FOSTER PREVENTION LEADERSHIP THROUGH ONGOING PREVENTION TRAINING AND YOUTH-LED PREVENTION ACTIVITIES.  4. LEVERAGE PARTNERSHIPS TO BRING IN ADDITIONAL PROGRAMMING TO ADDRESS SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH INCLUDING POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMMING THAT WILL ENABLE YOUTH TO BETTER NEGOTIATE THE SOCIAL AND COMMUNITY CONTEXT THAT SURROUNDS THEM. ADDITIONALLY, SCHCC WILL PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY, LAW ENFORCEMENT, AND CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS TO INCREASE PRESCRIPTION DRUG DISPOSAL OPTIONS IN SALEM COUNTY AND PROMOTE PARTNERS MAKING A DIFFERENCE IN PREVENTION ACROSS THE COUNTY.  THE STRATEGIES OUTLINED ABOVE ALONG WITH OTHERS IDENTIFIED THROUGH ONGOING ASSESSMENT AND COURSE CORRECTION MEASURES WILL HELP SCHCC ACHIEVE THE CHANGES IN SCHOOLS AND BROADER COMMUNITIES THAT CAN SUSTAIN LONG TERM DECLINES IN YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN SALEM COUNTY. THE SCHCC WILL USE THE PRIDE SURVEY FOR GRADES 6-12 TO COLLECT CORE MEASURES REGARDING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE ALONGSIDE COALITION PARTNER SURVEYS AND PROCESS EVALUATION MEASURES SUCH AS ATTENDANCE, AND SATISFACTION SURVEYS AT EVENTS AND ACTIVITIES.

HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG COALITION SCRC DRUG FREE COMMUNITY - THE SHIPPENSBURG COMMUNITY RESOURCE COALITION (SCRC) IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT TO PROVIDE QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES AND YOUTH PROGRAMS THAT ARE ACCESSIBLE AND SAFE AND THAT RECOGNIZE THE DIGNITY AND WORTH OF EACH PERSON. OUR GOAL IS TO HELP COMMUNITY MEMBERS REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL. THE SCRC HAS BROUGHT SERVICE PROVIDERS, SHIPPENSBURG UNIVERSITY CAMPUS MEMBERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TOGETHER TO FORM A STRONG ACTION-ORIENTED COALITION. THE SCRC INITIATED TWO COALITIONS IN 2018, COMMUNITIES THAT CARE (CTC) AND HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG. HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG FOCUSES ON THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND CTC FOCUSED ON YOUTH RISK AND RESILIENCY.  IN 2021 HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG AND COMMUNITIES THAT CARE COMBINED IN ORDER TO MAXIMIZE COMMUNITY MEMBERSHIP AND PRESENT A UNIFIED FRONT THAT SEEKS TO ADDRESS AREAS OF CONCERNS FOR ALL AGES. THE SCRC NOW HAS ONLY ONE COALITION, THE HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG COALITION, WITH FOUR FOCUS AREAS THAT ARE INTERRELATED:  HOUSING, TRANSPORTATION, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, AND YOUTH. THE COALITION’S WORK IN ALL OF THESE AREAS WILL HELP TO DECREASE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. IMPROVING CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THESE SYSTEMS AND SERVICES WILL HELP PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, AND OVER TIME, REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG ADULTS.  AS SUCH, THE COALITION’S NEW MISSION STATEMENT ENCOMPASSES INDIVIDUAL, COMMUNITY, AND SYSTEMIC THEMES. THE HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG COALITION'S MISSION STATEMENT IS “TO HELP COMMUNITY MEMBERS REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL BY STRENGTHENING HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES RELATED TO THE WAYS THAT HOME, SCHOOL, WORKPLACE, NEIGHBORHOOD, AND COMMUNITY FACTORS IMPACT ONE'S HEALTH. THIS WORK INCLUDES A REDUCTION IN RISK FACTORS RELATED TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL, AND PHYSICAL HEALTH IN ORDER TO INCREASE YOUTH RESILIENCY.” TO HELP THE COALITION HAVE THE CAPACITY TO ACCOMPLISH ITS MISSION, THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL WORK ON STRENGTHENING THE COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS AND ORGANIZATIONS AND INCREASING COALITION PARTICIPATION.  THE COALITION SEEKS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE OF ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND PRESCRIPTION PAIN RELIEVERS BY INCREASING THE COMMUNITY’S KNOWLEDGE OF YOUTH USE OF THESE SUBSTANCES AND ADDRESSING THE ROOT CAUSES OF USE. TWO OF THE ROOT CAUSES OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE COMMUNITIES THAT CARE ASSESSMENT PROCESS INCLUDE YOUTH DEPRESSIVE SYMPTOMS AND PARENTAL ATTITUDES FAVORABLE TOWARDS ANTI-SOCIAL BEHAVIOR (INCLUDING DRUG AND ALCOHOL USE), ALONG WITH NEEDING TO INCREASE THE PROTECTIVE FACTOR OF COMMUNITY REWARDS FOR PROSOCIAL INVOLVEMENT. THESE FACTORS WERE IDENTIFIED USING DATA FROM THE STUDENT SURVEYS CONDUCTED BY THE STATE. THIS PROJECT WOULD HELP SCRC, THROUGH HEALTHY SHIPPENSBURG COALITION, CONTINUE TO ADDRESS CAUSES OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE BY: -	STRENGTHENING AND EXPANDING THE COALITION MEMBERSHIP AND INFLUENCE; -	CONTINUING TO IMPLEMENT THE COMMUNITIES THAT CARE (CTC) MODEL. THE CTC PROCESS PROMOTES HEALTHY YOUTH DEVELOPMENT BY REDUCING RISK FACTORS AND INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS. RESEARCH SHOWS THAT CTC REDUCES YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, DELINQUENCY, DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY WHILE INCREASING SCHOOL ENGAGEMENT, FAMILY ATTACHMENT, AND POSITIVE HEALTH OUTCOMES LATER IN LIFE; -	CONTINUING WORK WITH YOUTH PROGRAMMING SUCH AS IN-SCHOOL SUPPORT GROUPS, TEEN LEADERSHIP CLUB, LEADERS-IN-TRAINING CAMP AND THE SUMMER LEARNING PROGRAM TO HELP INCREASE THE EASE, ABILITY, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR SHIPPENSBURG YOUTH TO ACCESS PROGRAMS EMPHASIZING SELF-EFFICACY AND LEARNING SKILLS THAT PREVENT SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE; -	IMPLEMENTING A NEW PROJECT TO SCREEN AND PROVIDE INFORMATION AND REFERRAL SERVICES VIA THE SCHOOL DISTRICT; -	CONTINUING THE BLUES PROGRAM, AN EVIDENCE-BASED SIX-WEEK GROUP INTERVENTION THAT FOCUSES ON TEACHING PARTICIPANTS HOW TO REDUCE NEGATIVE COGNITIONS AND INCREASE ENGAGEMENT IN PLEASANT ACTIVITIES; -	PROVIDING WORKSHOPS, EDUCATION, AND MEDIA SPOTS TO ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE U

ADAPP FORWARD SOUTH BRONX COALITION INITIATIVE - THE ADAPP FORWARD SOUTH BRONX COALITION INITIATIVE IS A SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION INITIATIVE DESIGNED TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE AMONG YOUTH 12 TO 18 AND, OVER TIME, REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE AMONG ADULTS THROUGH A COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITY PARTNERS WHO ARE COMMITTED TO PREVENTING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE FORWARD SOUTH BRONX COALITION IS A DIVERSE GROUP OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN COLLABORATION AGAINST UNDERAGE ALCOHOL USE, MARIJUANA, TOBACCO AND OPIOID MISUSE. THE LONG-RANGE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE OUR COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENT BY IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES THAT HAVE A COMPREHENSIVE AND LONG-LASTING IMPACT. THE PRIMARY MISSION IS TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE AMONG THE YOUTH IN THE LONGWOOD/HUNTS POINT COMMUNITY OF THE SOUTH BRONX, BY RAISING AWARENESS, ELIMINATING RISKY BEHAVIORS AND ESTABLISHING A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE FOR ALL RESIDENTS. FSBC REPRESENTS THREE ZIP CODES WITHIN THE COUNTY OF THE BRONX. THE BRONX IS ONE OF 5 COUNTIES THAT MAKE UP NYC. THE 3 ZIP CODES (10474, 10455, 10459) WITH A POPULATION OF 56,144, ARE LOCATED IN AN AREA KNOWN AS THE "SOUTH BRONX". THESE AREAS ARE LOCATED IN THE POOREST CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT IN THE UNITED STATES.  FSBC WAS INITIALLY CONVENED IN 2014 AND RECEIVED THE FIRST ROUND OF DFC FUNDING IN 2016. DURING THIS TIME, SUCCESSFUL STRATEGIES INTRODUCED INCLUDED SOCIAL MARKETING CAMPAIGNS, TOWN HALL MEETINGS, ALCOHOL COMPLIANCE CHECKS, ALCOHOL AWARENESS TRAINING FOR BUSINESSES, AND LEGISLATIVE ADVOCACY TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THE CONSEQUENCES OF UNDERAGE USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA. THIS NEW AND COMPLIMENTARY INITIATIVE WILL BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF THESE EFFORTS WITH STRATEGIES DESIGNED TO IMPACT SOCIAL ACCESS OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA, RETAIL ACCESS OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AND LOW PERCEPTION OF RISK OF HARM OF THESE SUBSTANCES AMONG YOUTH AND ADULTS.  IT WILL ALSO FOCUS ON ENHANCING SKILLS AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO PROSOCIAL ALTERNATIVES FOR PARENTS AND YOUTH. USING A CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE APPROACH, INCLUDING ACCESS TO PROGRAMS AND MATERIALS IN SPANISH AND ENGLISH, THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK, AS WELL AS THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE, THE ADAPP FORWARD SOUTH BRONX COALITION INITIATIVE, ALONG WITH OUR COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL DECREASE YOUTH USE OF MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL, DECREASE COMMUNITY RISK FACTORS FOR UNDERAGE USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AND STRENGTHEN PROTECTIVE FACTORS AMONG YOUTH AND ADULTS IN THE COMMUNITY.

SAFE IN HARLEM IS A TEEN-LED, COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP SUPPORTED, DFC GRANTEE DEDICATED TO THE ERRADICATION OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE AMONG TEENS, YOUTH, AND YOUNG ADULTS IN THE INNER CITY OF HARLEM, NY. - SAFE IN HARLEM IS A DFC AWARD GRANTEE FROM 2015-2020. IN 2021, AMIDST THE PANDEMIC AND A LAPSE IN FUNDING, WE CONTINUED TO DELIVER 2 EBPS TO OVER 40 PARENTS, EDUCATED 5 COMMUNITY LEGISLATORS, AND ENGAGED WITH OVER 400 TEENS TO ADDRESS SOME OF THE HEALTH (ADDICTION AND OVERDOSES) AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC DISPARITIES (FOOD, HEALTHCARE AND SHELTER) WHICH ARE PREVALENT IN THE COMMUNITY OF HARLEM. THIS APPLICATION IS A ROADMAP TO CONTINUING TO BUILD A DRUG-FREE COALITION OF TEENS AND YOUTH CAPABLE OF SELF-DIRECTED COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE FOR GENERATIONS TO COME. IT FOCUSES ON ENGAGEMENT WITH MORE THAN 400 BLACK AND LATINX YOUTH ANNUALLY, AND THEIR GUARDIANS, TO DISRUPT SOCIAL NORMS, STRUCTURAL RACISM IN HEALTH AND EDUCATIONAL SYSTEMS, AND TO ADDRESS SOCIO-ECONOMIC CONDITIONS SUCH AS JOBLESSNESS AND HOMELESSNESS. OUR AIM IS TO USE THE CAPACITY WE HAVE, AND CONTINUE TO BUILD, TO CHANGE COMMUNITY NORMS AROUND ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE THROUGH THE FOLLOWING: MONTHLY UNIVERSAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS WHICH EDUCATE AND INFORM, PARENTING SKILLS ENHANCEMENT AND VOCATIONAL TRAININGS TO INCREASE EMPLOYMENT AND HOME CONNECTEDNESS, ENHANCE ACCESS TO DRUG-FREE ACTIVITIES FOR TEENS TO REDUCE MISUSE, REDUCTION OF ACCESS TO AVAILABILITY OF ALCOHOL IN THE COMMUNITY, INCENTIVIZE BODEGA OWNERS TO REDUCE SALES OF ALCOHOL TO TEENS, CREATE MURALS AND REDUCE ALCOHOL ADVERTISEMENTS TO CHANGE THE PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT. THE PRECEDING AIMS AND GOALS ARE EXPECTED TO REDUCE USE BY 10-15% PER YEAR OVER THE NEXT 5-YEARS OF FUNDING, WHICH IS PREDICTED TO REDUCE ADULT USE OVERTIME.

JEFF DAVIS SUBSTANCE ABUSE COALITION - JEFF DAVIS COUNTY IS LOCATED IN RURAL SOUTHEAST GEORGIA.  THE COUNTY HAS TWO CITIES, HAZLEHURST (THE COUNTY SEAT) AND DENTON. A MAJOR PART OF ITS ECONOMIC BASE IS AGRICULTURE, ESPECIALLY TIMBER. THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NUCLEAR POWER PLANT IN THE MID-TWENTIETH CENTURY BROUGHT THOUSANDS OF WORKERS TO THE AREA, AND MANY STAYED. JEFF DAVIS IS HOME TO 14,779 PEOPLE AND 5,689 HOUSEHOLDS. THE COUNTY’S DEMOGRAPHICS ARE: 82% CAUCASIAN; 15% AFRICAN AMERICAN/BLACK; 1% ASIAN/PI; 2% MULTI-RACIAL/OTHER. 13% ARE LATINO/HISPANIC. ALMOST 40% OF THE HOUSEHOLDS HAVE CHILDREN UNDER 18, AND 20% OF THE TOTAL POPULATION ARE SCHOOL-AGE CHILDREN. WITH A MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME OF $32,900, 59% OF THE HOUSEHOLDS WITH CHILDREN HAVE INCOMES BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL COMPARED TO 28% FOR GEORGIA. THE SCHOOL SYSTEM INCLUDES JEFF DAVIS PRIMARY SCHOOL, GRADES PK-2, 881 STUDENTS; JEFF DAVIS ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, GRADES 3-5, 704 STUDENTS; JEFF DAVIS MIDDLE SCHOOL, GRADES 6-8, 688 STUDENTS; AND JEFF DAVIS HIGH SCHOOL, GRADES 9-12, 860 STUDENTS. JEFF DAVIS STUDENTS ARE MORE LIKELY TO GRADUATE ON TIME THAN THEIR STATEWIDE COUNTERPARTS. FROM 2013 THROUGH 2017, LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS REALIZED THAT OPIOID USE, ADDICTION AND OVERDOSES AMONG ADULTS WERE INCREASING EXPONENTIALLY COMPARED TO THE REST OF GEORGIA. THE COUNTY’S AGE-ADJUSTED DEATH RATE DUE TO DRUG OVERDOSES WAS 27 PER 100,000, DOUBLE THAT OF THE SOUTHEAST HEALTH DISTRICT, THE 16-COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH DISTRICT IN WHICH JEFF DAVIS IS LOCATED, WHICH WAS 13.8 PER 100,000. THE EMERGENCY ROOM RATE FOR DRUG USE DISORDERS DURING THIS TIME WAS THE HIGHEST IN THE STATE WITH 237 PER 100,000 COMPARED TO 163 PER 100,000 FOR GEORGIA. OTHER THAN 12-STEP PROGRAMS, THERE WERE NO TREATMENT OR RECOVERY RESOURCES IN THE COUNTY. THESE CONCERNS LED TO THE FORMATION OF THE JEFF DAVIS SUBSTANCE ABUSE COALITION (JDSAC) IN 2018 WITH THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING INTERAGENCY, COMMUNITY-WIDE, COLLABORATION TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO REDUCE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY RELATED TO SUBSTANCE USE IN THE COUNTY. ITS PRIMARY FOCUS WAS MEETING THE COUNTY’S NEED FOR TREATMENT AND RECOVERY SERVICES. THE COALITION WAS ALSO CONCERNED ABOUT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. THEY KNEW YOUTH WERE BEING EXPOSED TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND ITS CONSEQUENCES IN THEIR FAMILIES. SOME WERE IN FOSTER CARE AS A RESULT OF NEGLECT BY DRUG-INVOLVED PARENTS. THESE YOUTH WERE AT HIGH RISK FOR ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES WHICH OFTEN LEAD TO MANY PROBLEM BEHAVIORS INCLUDING SUBSTANCE USE. THE STRESS OF DEALING WITH PANDEMIC RESTRICTIONS AND ISOLATION FOR TWO YEARS ADDED TO THE LOCAL ACCESSIBILITY OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, OPIOIDS AND METH INCREASED THE RISK OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. THE COALITION DECIDED TO EXPAND ITS FOCUS TO INCLUDE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION. THE COUNTY HAD NO SCHOOL, AFTERSCHOOL OR OTHER PROGRAMMING THAT ADDRESSED SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION. THEY BEGAN STRATEGIC PREVENTION PLANNING IN 2021. MEMBERS REVIEWED DATA AND ATTENDED TRAINING ON RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS, STRATEGIC PLANNING AND STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE. THEY PRIORITIZED ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO AS THEIR TARGET SUBSTANCES BECAUSE THEY ARE THE MOST WIDELY USED BY LOCAL YOUTH AND USE HAD INCREASED BETWEEN 2020 AND 2021. TO INCREASE COLLABORATION, JDSAC WILL RECRUIT ADDITIONAL MEMBERS AND ADD A YOUTH ACTION TEAM. THEY WILL INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE & SKILLS OF MEMBERS TO ENGAGE IN STRATEGIC PREVENTION PLANNING AND WILL INCREASE COMMUNITY AWARENESS OF LOCAL YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PROBLEMS AND THE COALITION’S STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THEM. TO DECREASE YOUTH ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE (ESPECIALLY VAPING), THE COALITION WILL FOCUS ON ENFORCEMENT OF LAWS RELATED TO UNDERAGE SALES OF ALCOHOL & TOBACCO. THEY WILL INCREASE YOUTH AND ADULT AWARENESS OF THE HARMS, RISKS AND CONSEQUENCES OF UNDERAGE ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE THROUGH FAMILY AND YOUTH EDUCATION AND CHANGES IN POLICIES. JDSAC WILL ALSO IMPROVE THE AVAILABILITY OF PROGRAMS AND OPPORTUNITIES THAT PROMOTE POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELO

BROOKS COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES WORKS TO STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG THE VARIOUS SECTORS IN THE COMMUNITY AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. - BROOKS COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES WORKS TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION TO SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF A COMMUNITY COALITION THAT WORKS TO PREVENT AND REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH, AND SUBSEQUENTLY ADULTS, BY ADDRESSING THE FACTORS IN A COMMUNITY THAT INCREASE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE, PROMOTING THE FACTORS THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE, PROVIDING DRUG AWARENESS  AND PREVENTION TRAINING AND EDUCATION, PROVIDING INFORMATION, BUILDING SKILLS, PROVIDING SUPPORT, ENHANCING ACCESS, REDUCING BARRIERS, CHANGING CONSEQUENCES AND INCENTIVES, CHANGING PHYSICAL DESIGN, AND CHANGING RULES AND PROCEDURES IN BROOKS COUNTY, GEORGIA.

COPE DETROIT - COPE DETROIT WAS ESTABLISHED IN MAY 2021 UNDER THE FOLLOWING MISSION STATEMENT: TO PREVENT YOUTH AND ADULT SUBSTANCE ABUSE THROUGH COMMUNITYWIDE EDUCATION AND ADVOCACY IN THE EASTSIDE OF DETROIT. DETROIT IS IN WAYNE COUNTY, MICHIGAN, AND THE LARGEST CITY IN THE STATE. THE DETROIT METROPOLITAN STATISTICAL AREA (MSA) IS ESTIMATED AT 4,296,250 (CENSUS, 2020) AND INCLUDES MACOMB, OAKLAND, AND WAYNE COUNTIES WITHIN A 3,888 SQ MILE AREA. IN 10 YEARS, THE CITY OF DETROIT POPULATION DROPPED 10% FROM 713,777 (2010) TO 639,111 (2020) AS MANY RESIDENTS RELOCATED TO THE SUBURBS OF OAKLAND AND MACOMB TO ESCAPE THE PROBLEMS PLAGUING OUR CITY TO THIS DAY. THE HIGHLIGHTS OF THE COMMUNITY CHARACTERISTICS OF THE EASTSIDE INCLUDE A POPULATION OF 159,346 RESIDENTS OF WHICH 81% ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN AND MORE THAN 36 % OF THE CHILDREN UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE AND LIVE BELOW THE POVERTY LINE. THERE ARE 2,500 STUDENTS IN OUR TARGET SCHOOLS (DENBY, EAST ENGLISH PREP, SOUTHEASTERN, BREWER, AND HAMILTON) OF WHOM 99% ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN, AND 90% ARE FROM LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS. IN 2018, MICHIGAN STATE AND DETROIT EXPERIENCED A MAJOR SETBACK IN LAWS AND NORMS FAVORABLE TO DRUG USE. IT WAS THEN THAT MICHIGAN STATE VOTERS APPROVED THE LEGALIZATION OF RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA USE. WITHOUT A DOUBT THIS ACTION HAS NEGATIVELY IMPACTED DETROIT YOUTH, ADULTS, AND FAMILIES BY MAKING MARIJUANA MORE EASILY ACCESSIBLE AND MORE READILY AVAILABLE TO YOUTH. THE CONDITIONS IN AND AROUND DETROIT HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE 58% INCREASE IN CURRENT MARIJUANA USE AMONG HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH (17.6% IN 2015 TO 27.8% IN 2021) AND CURRENT ALCOHOL USE RATES AMONG HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH INCREASED FROM 22.6% IN 2015 TO 34.2% IN 2019. THE PURPOSE OF THE COPE DETROIT DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS TO BETTER ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE MISUSE AND TO LEVERAGE THESE COLLABORATIONS TO SUSTAIN A SERIES OF ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIES DESIGNED TO SYSTEMATICALLY REDUCE YOUT H SUBSTANCE ABUSE. COPE’S 12 SECTOR REPRESENTATIVE HAVE IDENTIFIED TWO SUBSTANCE ABUSE PRIORITIES—ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA—THAT ARE ADVERSELY IMPACTING THE YOUTH AND FAMILIES IN DETROIT. WORKING IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH THE CITY OF DETROIT, DETROIT PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT, DETROIT WAYNE INTEGRATED HEALTH NETWORK, AND A REGIONAL ALLIANCE OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION NETWORK COALITIONS IN NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES COPE WILL ENGAGE IN MULTIPLE STRATEGIES TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES:  1) REDUCE 30-DAY ALCOHOL USE AMONG 11TH GRADE STUDENTS FROM THE 2019 BASELINE OF 33.1% TO 29.8% (-3.3) BY 2024 AS MEASURED BY THE MICHIGAN PROFILE FOR HEALTHY YOUTH. 2027 TARGET: 6.6-POINT (20%) NET DECREASE; 26.5% OR LOWER.  2) REDUCE 30-DAY MARIJUANA USE AMONG 11TH GRADE STUDENTS FROM THE CURRENT 2019 BASELINE OF 28.8% TO 24.3% (-4.5) BY 2024 AS MEASURED BY THE MICHIGAN PROFILE FOR HEALTHY YOUTH. (2027 TARGET: 9-POINT (20%) NET DECREASE; 23% OR LOWER.  COPE DETROIT IS TARGETING THE MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL AGE YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES WITH THE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN THE FIRST YEAR OF THE 5-YEAR PROJECT INCLUDE: 1) SECURING THE INFRASTRUCTURE AND CAPACITY TO ADDRESS SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION THROUGH WIDE-RANGING COMMUNITY COLLABORATION, 2) IMPROVING COALITION COMPETENCY THROUGH TRAININGS AND EDUCATION, 3) INCREASING AWARENESS OF THE ISSUES AROUND ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA WITH MULTIMODAL COMMUNICATIONS, 4) ENHANCING PARENTING SKILLS TO BUFFER EXPOSURE TO NEGATIVE INFLUENCES, 5) IMPLEMENTING A COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION MEDIA CAMPAIGN TARGETING ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA, 6) ENHANCING SCHOOL-BASED STUDENT PREVENTION CLUBS WITH TRAINING AND ACTIVITY SUPPORT, 7) ADVOCATING FOR SCHOOL DRUG AND ALCOHOL RESPONSE POLICY REVIEWS AND UPDATES, 8) CONDUCTING OUTREACH TARGETING UNDER-RESOURCED, UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES, AND 9) IMPROVING ACCESS TO PREVENTION RESOURCE FOR PARENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES.

THE GARINAGU COALITION IS A GROUP OF ETHNIC GARIFUNA WITH CARIBBEAN ORIGINS LIVING IN NEW ORLEANS WHO AIM TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND BUILD GARINAGU COMMUNITY CAPACITY - WITHIN THE HONDURAN POPULATION OF NEW ORLEANS IS A UNIQUE ETHNIC GROUP CALLED GARIFUNA.  THEIR CULTURE, MEMBER OF UNESCO'S CULTURAL HERITAGE OF HUMANITY, HAS ITS OWN LANGUAGE SEPARATE FROM THE SPANISH SPOKEN BY THEIR FELLOW HONDURANS.  THEY ARE OF AFRICAN DESCENT AND ARE OFTEN UNDERREPRESENTED AND MALIGNED BOTH IN HONDURAS AND IN NEW ORLEANS.  THE GARINAGU COALITION AIMS TO SERVE THE GARIFUNA POPULATION OF NEW ORLEANS EAST WHERE AN ESTIMATED 10000 GARIFUNA LIVE.  THE GARINAGU COALITION WILL UTILIZE EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION STRATEGIES TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND INCREASE GARIFUNA COMMUNITY CAPACITY TO ADDRESS THEIR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS.

THE MAYAHUEL PREVENTION CONSORTIUM II - EXPERIENCED SOUTHERN ARIZONA DFC AWARDEE AMISTADES, INC. JOINS THE MULTI-SECTOR MAYAHUEL PREVENTION CONSORTIUM III (MPCII) IN PROPOSING TO ENGAGE YOUTH AGES 10-18 AND THEIR PARENTS/CAREGIVERS, AS WELL AS COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND LEADERS IN THE LATINO-DOMINANT, US-MEXICO BORDER COMMUNITY OF DOUGLAS, ARIZONA IN ADDRESSING FAST-RISING RATES OF YOUTH UNDERAGE DRINKING AND SUBSTANCE USE, SPECIFICALLY MARIJUANA, PSYCHOSTIMULANTS, AND OPIOIDS – WITH EMPHASIS ON FENTANYL.  FUNDING WILL BE USED TO IMPLEMENT SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY-BASED EDUCATION, POLICY CHANGE  AND CAPACITY-BUILDING EFFORTS AIMED AT 1) REDUCING YOUTH ACCESS TO TARGETED SUBSTANCES THROUGH KEY SOCIAL HOST AND RED TAG ORDINANCES; 2) CHANGING LATINO CULTURAL NORMS ACCEPTING OF YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE THROUGH SUD/OUD PREVENTION EDUCATION AND OUTREACH; 3) ENHANCING YOUTH AND ADULT COMMUNICATION AND DECISION-MAKING SKILLS PROMOTING POSITIVE ENGAGEMENT AND SUBSTANCE USE REFUSAL SKILLS, AND 4) INCREASING COMMUNITY-BASED PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR YOUTH AND ADULTS CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTICIPATION IN ACTIVITIES THAT REDUCE RISK AND ENHANCE PROTECTION. LATINO-LED AMISTADES WILL USE ITS DEMONSTRATED EXPERTISE IN INTEGRATING CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE AND TRAUMA-INFORMED METHODS INTO PREVENTION PROGRAMMING TO ENSURE ENGAGEMENT OF LATINO YOUTH AND ADULTS AT ALL LEVELS OF ACCULTURATION. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE 1) COALITION CAPACITY BUILDING IN LEADERSHIP, MOBILIZATION, USE OF DATA, CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE EBP IMPLEMENTATION; 2) PARENT AND YOUTH MOBILIZATION TO COORDINATE COMMUNITY PREVENTION EFFORTS AND PROSOCIAL ACTIVITIES; 3) COMMUNITY POLICY DEVELOPMENT TO LIMIT ACCESS AND YOUTH AVAILABILITY OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA; 4) BINATIONAL PREVENTION EDUCATION BUILDING KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL AMONG YOUTH AND PARENTS LIVING ON BOTH SIDES OF THE BORDER; AND 5) DATA-DRIVEN PLANNING AND EVALUATION.

YOUTH SUBSTANCE PREVENTION INITIATIVE IN GREENLEE COUNTY, ARIZONA - GREENLEE COUNTY IS THE LEAST POPULOUS COUNTY IN ARIZONA AND THAT CREATES A UNIQUE ENVIRONMENT WHERE SUBSTANCE USE, ESPECIALLY AMONGST YOUTH, IS AS PREVALENT AS ANYWHERE ELSE IN THE COUNTRY, BUT WHERE PREVENTION EFFORTS AND RESOURCES ARE HINDERED BY THE RURAL NATURE OF THE AREA. TO ASSESS THE SEVERITY OF THE PROBLEM, DATA WAS GATHERED THROUGH SEVERAL METHODS, AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE SUBSTANCES OF MOST CONCERN AMONGST YOUTH UNDER THE AGE OF 18 ARE MARIJUANA, ALCOHOL, AND OPIOIDS. TO REMEDIATE THE ISSUE, RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS WERE THEN ANALYZED; IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE GREATEST RISKS ALIGNED WITH A COMMUNITY ACCEPTANCE OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, FAMILY ATTITUDES THAT LEANED TOWARD ANTISOCIAL BEHAVIOR, AND LOW COMMUNITY ATTACHMENT. THE PLAN IN PLACE OUTLINED IN THE PROJECT NARRATIVE IS TO PROVIDE FAMILY AND YOUTH SUPPORT TO FOSTER RESILIENCY AND HEALTHIER DECISION-MAKING. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF THIS INITIATIVE ARE TO: (1) REDUCE ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND OPIOID USE AMONG YOUTH BY 20% EACH; AND (2) REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE DISPARITIES AMONG OUR YOUTH RELATED TO MENTAL HEALTH, RESILIENCY FACTORS, AND UNMITIGATED TRAUMA AND ACES.

HHW DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM - THE STANDUP AJ COALITION IS A COMMUNITY SUBSTANCE MISUSE PREVENTION COALITION LOCATED IN APACHE JUNCTION, ARIZONA ON THE FAR EAST OUTSKIRTS OF THE PHOENIX METRO AREA.  STANDUP AJ PLANS TO ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE THROUGH A MULTI-SECTOR APPROACH USING A SET OF COMMUNITY-BASED STRATEGIES AND ACTION ITEMS TO REDUCE THE PREVALENCE AND IMPACT OF THE TARGET SUBSTANCES.  STRATEGIES TO INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND COALITION CAPACITY INCLUDE INCREASING MEMBER RECRUITMENT, INCREASING MEMBER INVOLVEMENT IN IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ACTIVITIES AND ENHANCING SKILLS OF THE COALITION MEMBERS AND KEY PARTNERS THROUGH TOPICAL TRAININGS ON BEST PRACTICES IN PREVENTION SCIENCE. STRATEGIES TO REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE FOR THE TARGET SUBSTANCES AND ASSOCIATED PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEMS INCLUDE PROVIDING INFORMATION, ENHANCING SKILLS, PROVIDING SUPPORT AND CHANGING CONSEQUENCES TO ADDRESS THE RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS OF PERCEIVED RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE, LACK OF PARENT-CHILD CONVERSATIONS, YOUTH COPING AND RESILIENCY SKILLS AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT IN PROSOCIAL ACTIVITIES.  ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: (1) STANDUP AJ CONTINUING ON ITS PATH TO BECOMING A WELL-FUNCTIONING, EFFECTIVE COALITION WITH INCREASED MEMBERSHIP AND A STRONGER KNOWLEDGE BASE IN AREAS RELATED TO PREVENTION SCIENCE; (2) AN INCREASE IN YOUTH, CAREGIVER AND COMMUNITY AWARENESS OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE; (3) AN INCREASE IN YOUTH PERCEIVED RISKS OF TARGET SUBSTANCES; (4) AN INCREASE IN YOUTH INVOLVEMENT IN PROSOCIAL ACTIVITIES AND THEIR PERCEIVED VALUE OF THIS INVOLVEMENT; AND (5) AN INCREASE IN YOUTH COPING, RESILIENCY AND SELF-REGULATION SKILLS.  BY 2027, STANDUP AJ ANTICIPATES A REDUCTION IN USE OF THE TARGET SUBSTANCES AND A REDUCTION IN SUBSTANCE USE DISPARITIES AMONG OUR YOUTH RELATED TO MENTAL HEALTH, RESILIENCY FACTORS AND UNMITIGATED TRAUMA AND ACES.  USING TRAUMA INFORMED, EVIDENCE BASED STRATEGIES, STANDUP AJ WILL STRIVE TO CREATE A POSITIVE CULTURE THAT ALLOWS YOUTH TO THRIVE IN AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE EVERYONE BELIEVES THEY ARE CAPABLE OF SUCCESS, ADDRESS MENTAL HEALTH AND SOCIAL EMOTIONAL LEARNING TO INCREASE YOUTH RESILIENCE, AND THROUGH IT ALL INCREASE THE CAPABILITIES OF THE COALITION THROUGH CONTINUALLY ASSESSING THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY, ADJUSTING STRATEGIES AS NEEDED, EVALUATING WHAT WE HAVE DONE, AND PLAN STRATEGICALLY BASED ON THE EVALUATION RESULTS.  STANDUP AJ WILL STAND TOGETHER WITH OUR COMMUNITY AND YOUTH PROMOTING POSITIVE HEALTHY LIFE CHOICES AND BUILDING BRIGHT FUTURES.

LATINX-KING COUNTY DREAM COALITION WILL REDUCE AND PREVENT ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA AND TOBACCO USE AND MISUSE AMONG LATINX YOUTH (GRADES 6-12) IN KING COUNTY, WA. - THE LATINX-KING COUNTY DREAM COALITION WILL WORK IN KING COUNTY, WA TO REDUCE AND CHANGE THE CULTURE AND CONTEXT REGARDING ACCEPTABILITY OF ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA AND TOBACCO USE AND MISUSE AMONG LATINX YOUTH (6TH -12TH GRADES), PARENTS AND COMMUNITIES THROUGH CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE EDUCATION, TOOLS AND SERVICES THAT REDUCE HARM, EMPOWER AND STRENGTHEN LATINX FAMILIES TO PROMOTE PHYSICAL, MENTAL AND EMOTIONAL WELLBEING, ENCOURAGE DRUG FREE YOUTH, AND BRING EQUITY AND JUSTICE TO OUR COMMUNITIES. THIS WORK IS NEEDED BECAUSE LATINX YOUTH FACE GREATER RISK FACTORS AND HAVE FEWER PROTECTIVE FACTORS THAN THEIR PEERS FROM MANY OTHER RACIAL/ETHNIC COMMUNITIES, CONTRIBUTING TO HIGH RATES OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE.  WE PROPOSE A COMPREHENSIVE EVIDENCE-BASED SUBSTANCE MISUSE PREVENTION PLAN THAT WILL BE LED BY YOUTH, PARENTS AND ALL 12 SECTORS WHO ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN THE COALITION TO IMPLEMENT THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (I.E. NEEDS ASSESSMENT, CAPACITY BUILDING, PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION WITH CULTURAL RELEVANCE AND SUSTAINABILITY) AND THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE.  PROJECTED LONG TERM OUTCOMES TO BE ACHIEVED OVER FIVE YEARS INCLUDE: 10% DECREASE IN PAST 30 DAY USE; 10% INCREASE IN PERCEPTION OF RISK OF HARM OF USE; 10% DECREASE IN PARENTS’ PERCEPTION THAT IT IS ACCEPTABLE TO USE; AND 10% DECREASE IN PERCEPTION THAT OTHER YOUTH (PEERS) APPROVE OF USE. OTHER PROJECTED LONG TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE 80% OF 6TH -12TH GRADERS AND PARENTS INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS RELATED TO ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA AND CIGARETTE/SMOKING (E-CIGARETTE, VAPOR) PREVENTION AFTER PARTICIPATION IN OUR EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS.

ENVIRONMENTAL PREVENTION AND GEOGRAPHIC EXPANSION TO SUPPORT AT-RISK YOUTH - MARIN HEALTHY YOUTH PARTNERSHIPS (MHYP) IS A COMMUNITY-BASED COALITION THAT WORKS TO RESHAPE COMMUNITY NORMS THAT DRIVE YOUTH AND ADULT SUBSTANCE USE IN MARIN COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. LOCAL FAMILIES FACE SOME OF THE MOST SERIOUS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PROBLEMS IN THE STATE AND NATION. COMPARED WITH THE 58 COUNTIES IN CALIFORNIA, 11TH GRADERS IN MARIN COUNTY HAVE HAD THE HIGHEST RATES OF CURRENT ALCOHOL AND CANNABIS USE AND THE SECOND HIGHEST RATES OF CURRENT BINGE DRINKING. ADDITIONALLY, TAMALPAIS UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT (TUHSD), IN THE MHYP SERVICE AREA, HAS TOPPED THE COUNTY FOR PAST 30-DAY USE AMONGST 11TH GRADERS FOR BINGE DRINKING, ALCOHOL, CANNABIS, AND E-CIGARETTES. HEALTH DISPARITIES AND SOCIAL INJUSTICE ARE ALSO SERIOUS PROBLEMS IN OUR COMMUNITIES, WITH MARIN RANKING IN THE BOTTOM 10% OF CALIFORNIA COUNTIES FOR INCOME INEQUALITY AND SECOND IN THE STATE FOR RACIAL DISPARITIES. DATA SHOW THAT BIPOC AND LGBTQ YOUTH IN OUR SERVICE AREA ARE AT GREATER RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE AND MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS. MHYP WILL FURTHER STRENGTHEN OUR COMMUNITY COALITION AND OUR COLLABORATIONS WITH PARTNERS THAT WE HAVE BUILT OVER THE PAST 5 YEARS OF DFC FUNDING WITH THE GOAL OF REDUCING YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, CANNABIS AND E-CIGARETTES. OUR SHORT AND LONG TERM OBJECTIVES ADDRESS 3 ROOT CAUSES: 1) EASE OF ACCESS (LOCAL CONDITIONS: ACCESS AT SCHOOL, ACCESS AT HOME, ACCESS TO MEDICAL MARIJUANA CARDS, NO-CHASE POLICY FOR YOUTH SHOPLIFTING SUBSTANCES), 2) LOW PERCEPTIONS OF RISK OF HARM (LOCAL CONDITIONS: YOUTH USE AT SCHOOL, PREDATORY YOUTH-ORIENTED MARKETING, CANNABIS LEGALIZATION, LACK OF EVIDENCE-BASED SUBSTANTIVE DRUG-USE CURRICULUM), AND 3) TOXIC STRESS AND MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS (LOCAL CONDITIONS: HIGHLY COMPETITIVE “PRESSURE COOKER” ENVIRONMENT, EQUITY GAP IN ACCESS TO SERVICES, PARENTS AND SIBLINGS USING SUBSTANCES AT HOME, SOCIAL ISOLATION, ANXIETY AND DEPRESSION). OUR 12 MONTH OBJECTIVES PRIORITIZE EQUITY-FOCUSED STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE NEGATIVE FACTORS THAT DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECT BIPOC AND LGBTQ YOUTH BY BUILDING UP PROTECTIVE FACTORS WITHIN INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, SCHOOLS, AND OUR COMMUNITIES. MHYP WILL UNDERTAKE THE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES TO ACHIEVE OUR LONG-TERM GOAL OF REDUCING YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, CANNABIS, AND E-CIGARETTES: 1) GROW OUR 12-SECTOR COALITION AND FURTHER ALIGN OUR WORK WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, 2) INCREASE OUTREACH  AND WELCOME REPRESENTATIVES FROM COMMUNITIES IN OUR EXPANDED SERVICE AREA, 3) EDUCATE OUR COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND LOCAL ELECTED OFFICIALS ABOUT THE PROTECTIVE BENEFITS OF ADOPTING AND IMPLEMENTING NEW LOCAL-LEVEL GOVERNMENT POLICIES DESIGNED TO REDUCE YOUTH ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES, 4) SUPPORT OUR YOUTH COALITION MEMBERS IN THEIR EFFORTS TO DEVELOP AN EQUITY-FOCUSED PROGRAM PROVIDING RESTORATIVE JUSTICE RESPONSES TO SUBSTANCE-USE OFFENSES, 5) REDUCE STIGMA AROUND MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES AND INCREASE ACCESS TO SUPPORT THROUGH MENTAL HEALTH FIRST AID TRAINING AND A TEEN-ADAPTED MODEL OF THE NUMB OR NOURISH CAMPAIGN, AND 6) DEVELOP A COUNTYWIDE SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION CURRICULUM INFORMED BY BRAIN SCIENCE AND SOCIAL SCIENCE TO BE OFFERED ANNUALLY TO BUILD UP TEENS’ DECISION-MAKING SKILLS, AND TO CHANGE THE CULTURE OF ACCESSING AND USING SUBSTANCES AT SCHOOL. MHYP WILL MONITOR AND EVALUATE OUR PROCESSES AND IMPACTS BY CONTINUOUSLY ANALYZING DATA FROM SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUPS, AND KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS ABOUT SUBSTANCE USE, EASE OF ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES, PERCEPTIONS OF HARM, AND PERCEPTIONS OF PEER USE AND PARENTAL DISAPPROVAL. MHYP WILL USE THAT DATA TO MEASURE AND IMPROVE PROGRESS TOWARD THE DEFINED OUTCOMES. OUR COALITION’S WORK WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH COMMUNITY EVENTS AND ONLINE. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL SEEK TO EXPAND OUR FUNDING BEYOND THE GRANT PERIOD THROUGH DONATIONS, SUPPORT FROM FOUNDATIONS, AND OTHER GRANTS FROM GOVERNMENT AGENCIES.

SHERMAN COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES - PROJECT ABSTRACT SHERMAN COUNTY DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES IS A FIVE-YEAR PROJECT FOCUSED ON THE REDUCTION OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG YOUTH IN SHERMAN COUNTY NEBRASKA.   THE PROJECT WILL BE COORDINATED AND IMPLEMENTED BY THE SHERMAN COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION (SCPC). SCPC BEGAN WORKING WITH YOUTH, THEIR FAMILIES AND THE COMMUNITY IN 1997.  SCPC IS A GROWING, ADAPTIVE ORGANIZATION THAT STRIVES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF YOUTH IN OUR FIVE COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND.  SCPC BELIEVES IN UTILIZING QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DATA TO ANNUALLY DETERMINE A WORK-PLAN THAT WILL ALLOW US TO PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS YOUTH ISSUES USING A TRAUMA INFORMED PHILOSOPHY.   THE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMINISTRATION (SAMHSA) HAS DEVELOPED THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (SPF) PLANNING MODEL.  BY APPLYING THE SPF, WE ARE ABLE TO ASSESS ISSUES AND COMMUNITY CONDITIONS, MOBILIZE AND BUILD CAPACITY TO CHANGE THE CONDITIONS AND ADDRESS THE ISSUES, PLAN AND DEVELOP A WORK-PLAN, IMPLEMENT ACTION WITH MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES, STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES AND EVALUATE OUR EFFORTS BEFORE BEGINNING THE PROCESS ALL OVER AGAIN.  WE CONTINUE WITH THESE FIVE STEPS WHILE ALWAYS KEEPING CULTURE COMPETENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY AT THE CORE OF WHAT WE DO.  THE STEPS ARE OF NO USE IF WE ARE NOT INCLUSIVE AND DON’T ALWAYS LOOK FOR WAYS TO SUSTAIN THE WORK WE ARE DOING. THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH A WIDE VARIETY OF COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, THE SHERMAN COUNTY DFC PROJECT WILL CREATE CHANGE USING EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION PROGRAMS THAT TARGET INDIVIDUAL, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY-LEVEL RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS.  WE STRIVE TO REDUCE FACTORS THAT INCREASE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE WHILE WE REINFORCE AND STRENGTHEN FACTORS THAT SERVE TO PROTECT THE YOUTH FROM THE EARLY ONSET OF SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE.  WE ARE PARTNERED WITH CHAMPIONS IN EACH OF THE FOLLOWING SECTORS: YOUTH, PARENTS, BUSINESS LEADERS, THE MEDIA, SCHOOLS, YOUTH SERVING ORGANIZATIONS, RELIGIOUS ORGANIZATIONS, LAW ENFORCEMENT, CIVIC AND VOLUNTEER GROUPS, HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS, GOVERNMENT FUNDED SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION AGENCIES, AND ORGANIZATIONS ADDRESSING SUBSTANCE ABUSE, THE AREA AFFECTED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE FIVE COMMUNITIES OF SHERMAN COUNTY, NEBRASKA: LITCHFIELD, ROCKVILLE, HAZARD, ASHTON AND LOUP CITY.  SHERMAN COUNTY COVERS 572 SQ. MILES OF RURAL NEBRASKA. THE PURPOSE OF THE SHERMAN COUNTY DFC IS TO REDUCE THE USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AMONG YOUTH AND OVER TIME, REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE BY ADULTS BY ADDRESSING THE RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS IN THE COMMUNITY.  WE DO SO BY OFFERING EVIDENCE BASED PROGRAMS USING THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE.  THOSE STRATEGIES INCLUDE: PROVIDING INFORMATION ABOUT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE,  *ENHANCING SKILLS SO YOUTH/ADULTS CAN ENGAGE IN POSITIVE SOCIAL SITUATIONS AND INCREASE DECISION MAKING SKILLS, *PROVIDING SUPPORT TO INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES THAT REDUCE RISK OR ENHANCE PROTECTION FROM SUBSTANCE USE/ABUSE, *ENHANCING ACCESS, REDUCING BARRIERS AND IMPROVING CONNECTIONS BETWEEN SYSTEMS AND SERVICES THAT HELP PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, *CHANGING CONSEQUENCES TO INCENTIVIZE POSITIVE PRACTICES AND DIS-INCENTIVIZE NEGATIVE PRACTICES, *CHANGING THE PHYSICAL DESIGN OF THE COMMUNITY TO REDUCE THE RISK AND ENHANCE THE PROTECTION AGAINST YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, *EDUCATING AND INFORMING THE COMMUNITY ABOUT MODIFYING OR CHANGING POLICIES THAT REDUCE ACCESS AND AVAILABILITY TO SUBSTANCES AMONG YOUTH. THE OUTCOMES OF THE SHERMAN COUNTY DFC PROJECT WILL BE REDUCED SUBSTANCE YOUTH AMONG YOUTH, LEADING TO REDUCED SUBSTANCE USE BY ADULTS WHICH IN TURN WILL HELP TO CREATE A HEALTHIER, MORE SUCCESSFUL COMMUNITY.

A MOBILIZED COMMUNITY TO ENGAGE YOUTH FOR PREVENTION SUCCESS TODAY - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY COMMUNITY LIVING ABOVE (CLA), A DRUG PREVENTION COALITION IN WEST LINN, OREGON (IN CLACKAMAS COUNTY), WORKS WITH COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO STRATEGICALLY ADDRESS RISK FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE INITIATION OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. WEST LINN IS A SMALL AFFLUENT COMMUNITY WITH UNIQUE NORMS, INCLUDING COMMON DENIAL OF THE SEVERITY OF LOCAL YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, LIBERAL STATE DRUG LAWS CREATING A LOW PERCEPTION OF HARM, AND EASY ACCESSIBILITY TO ADDICTIVE SUBSTANCES. CLA PROPOSES TO ENGAGE IN A MORE COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT, STRENGTHEN CAPACITY AND COLLABORATION WITH DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS, UTILIZE SCIENCE-BASED IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATE REGULARLY FOR IMPROVEMENT OF ACTIVITIES. THROUGH THE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMINISTRATIONS’ (SAMHSA) STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (SPF) PROCESS, THE COALITION WILL FINALIZE A STRATEGIC PLAN TO FURTHER DEFINE ACTIVITIES TO PREVENT EARLY ONSET OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE SPECIFIC TO THE SUBSTANCES DETERMINED TO BE THE MOST PREVALENT THREAT TO OUR COMMUNITY. A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT REVEALED LOCAL CONDITIONS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO A LOW PERCEPTION OF HARM AND EXCESSIVE ACCESSIBILITY TO THE SELECTED SUBSTANCES. 	OREGON LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSION (OLCC) DATA SHOWED WEST LINN HAS A HIGH ALCOHOL OUTLET DENSITY DEMONSTRATING SOCIAL ACCEPTANCE OF ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION IS HIGH WITHIN THE DEFINED AREA OF THE GRANT PROPOSAL AREA. THE OLCC IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR MINOR DECOY OPERATIONS TO TEST LOCAL ESTABLISHMENTS ON THE EFFICACY OF CHECKING IDENTIFICATION AND REFUSAL TO SELL ALCOHOL TO MINORS. THE MOST RECENT OPERATION WAS MORE THAN TWO YEARS AGO AND RESULTED IN ONLY 54% COMPLIANCE. NO FOLLOW-UP OR EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH HAS BEEN PROVIDED SINCE THAT TIME. 	IN 2014 OREGON LEGALIZED MARIJUANA FOR “RECREATIONAL” USE, AND MARIJUANA DISPENSARIES QUICKLY SATURATED THE STATE. PRODUCERS GREW RETAIL MARIJUANA AT A RATE THAT QUICKLY EXCEEDED EXPECTATIONS, AND PRICES PLUMMETED TO PRICES COMPARABLE TO THE BLACK MARKET 40 YEARS AGO. SIGNAGE GLAMORIZING MARIJUANA USE AND ADVERTISING PRE-ROLLED JOINTS FOR $2 WERE PLASTERED ACROSS COMMUNITIES EVERYWHERE. WEST LINN WAS PROACTIVE AND QUICKLY ADOPTED AN ORDINANCE BANNING MARIJUANA DISPENSARIES. STILL, AS OF THIS WRITING, THEY ARE ALLOWED TO DELIVER, AND AT LEAST THREE HAVE BEEN CONFIRMED TO DELIVER TO WEST LINN. THE SOCIAL ACCEPTABILITY OF MARIJUANA USE HAS BECOME MAINSTREAM. 	YOUTH IN THE REGION COMMONLY MISUSE PRESCRIPTION PILLS.  OPIOIDS AND BENZODIAZEPINES ARE THE MOST POPULAR, FOR YOUTH ATTEMPTING TO GET HIGH.  IN OUR AREA, YOUTH KNOW THEY CAN OBTAIN PILLS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA OR A BUS RIDE AWAY ON A STREET CORNER.  ACCORDING TO THE OREGON IDAHO HIGH-INTENSITY DRUG TRAFFICKING AREA (HIDTA) PROGRAM, THERE HAS BEEN AN INCREASE IN COUNTERFEIT PILLS DESIGNED TO APPEAR LIKE OPIOIDS AND BENZODIAZEPINES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THE ENFORCEMENT TEAMS IN OREGON SEIZED OVER 1.3 MILLION DOSAGE UNITS OF COUNTERFEIT PILLS CONTAINING FENTANYL DURING 2021 WHICH IS DOUBLE THE AMOUNT SEIZED IN 2020. THE PILLS ARE ALMOST CERTAIN TO CONTAIN THE DEADLY SUBSTANCE FENTANYL OR ITS EQUALLY DANGEROUS ANALOGS.  CLA SEEKS FUNDING TO ADDRESS EARLY-ONSET (OFTEN TOBACCO/NICOTINE) AND RISKY BEHAVIORS TO PREVENT YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND PRESCRIPTION DRUGS THROUGH MEANINGFUL STAKEHOLDER COLLABORATION AND EVIDENCE-BASED INTERVENTIONS. THE GOAL IS TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE PREVALENT DRUG THREATS TO WEST LINN YOUTH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY READINESS TO ADDRESS IT WHILE DECREASING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND EARLY INITIATION OF RISKY BEHAVIORS.

LINCOLN COUNTY COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES - THE LINCOLN COUNTY COALITION (LCC) IS APPLYING FOR THE FY2022 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $125,000. LCC SERVES LINCOLN COUNTY, NEVADA, A COMMUNITY OF 4,499.  THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  LINCOLN COUNTY COALITION WILL PREVENT YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA BY IMPLEMENTING THE PARENTS WHO HOST LOSE THE MOST AND THE TALK THEY HEAR YOU CAMPAIGNS ALONG WITH COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND TRAINING.  LCC WILL WORK TO BUILD COLLABORATION AMONG COALITION PARTNERS TO BUILD A SUSTAINABLE YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION COALITION.

FERGUS COUNTY: DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM- NEW - FERGUS COUNTY MONTANA IS HOME TO WIDE OPEN SPACES FEATURING THE ICONIC MONTANA “BIG SKY”. MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE VISTAS, THE COUNTY IS HOME TO A LOT OF PEOPLE THAT CARE AN AWFUL LOT ABOUT THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THEIR COMMUNITY AND KIDS GROWING UP IN IT. THIS RURAL NATURE PAIRED WITH THE TRADITIONAL WORK FORCE OF FARMING AND AG HELP TO PROVIDE A COMMUNITY BACKBONE OF TOUGH, HONEST, HARDWORKING PEOPLE THAT STILL VALUE THE COMMITMENT OF A HANDSHAKE AND HOLD TRADITIONAL FAMILY VALUES CLOSE TO HEART. WITH THESE GREAT ATTRIBUTES COME THE DOWN SIDE OF ISOLATION, RESOURCE GAPS, AND VIEWS OF ALCOHOL AND SUBSTANCE USE AS A RITE OF PASSAGE.  THE CENTRAL MONTANA YOUTH CHALLENGE (CMYC) COALITION WAS STARTED IN JANUARY 2004. OVER THE PAST 18 YEARS OF OPERATIONS THE COALITION HAS WORKED DILIGENTLY TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES, RESOURCES, AND SOLUTIONS TO HELP MAKE FERGUS COUNTY A BETTER PLACE FOR FAMILIES TO LIVE AND RAISE THEIR KIDS. THE MISSION OF THE CMYC IS TO HELP YOUTH MAKE POSITIVE LIFE CHOICES AND AVOID SUBSTANCE USE WITH SUPPORT FROM COMMUNITY-BASED RESOURCES. THE COALITION PRIDES ITSELF ON TAKING A HOLISTIC, COLLABORATIVE APPROACH ENGAGING THE COMMUNITY IN THE EDUCATION OF SUBSTANCE USE AND THE CONSEQUENCES AND COSTS IT CAN INFLICT ON OUR SMALL RURAL COMMUNITY. THE COALITION BELIEVES THAT BY AMPLIFYING PROTECTIVE FACTORS, WE CAN ACTIVELY MITIGATE THE IMPACTS ALCOHOL AND DRUGS HAVE ON OUR RURAL AND DISPARATE POPULATIONS.  THE CMYC, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FERGUS COUNTY GOVERNMENT, IS SEEKING SUPPORT FROM THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) GRANT TO HELP THE COALITION STRENGTHEN THEIR CAPACITY THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE COMMUNITIES THAT CARE (CTC) FRAMEWORK, DEVELOP MORE CULTURAL REPRESENTATION, AND ULTIMATELY IMPLEMENT LAYERED EVIDENCE-BASED, DATA-DRIVEN, PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES TO ELIMINATE THE NEGATIVE IMPACT METH AND UNDERAGE ALCOHOL USE IS HAVING ON OUR COMMUNITY.  ALTHOUGH THE COALITION HAS HELD STEADY MEMBERSHIP AND COLLABORATION, THERE IS A NEED FOR NEW GROWTH AND INPUT FROM NEW STAKE HOLDERS.  THROUGH THE CTC FRAMEWORK, IT IS HOPEFUL THAT WE CAN ADDRESS THIS CHALLENGE. SECONDLY, FERGUS COUNTY HAS NEVER BEEN ISSUED FUNDING TO FOCUS ON METHAMPHETAMINE PREVENTION.  THIS HAS BEEN A HUGE CHALLENGE TO CREATE A CHANGE WITHOUT ANY MONETARY RESOURCES.  FERGUS COUNTY YOUTH ARE BEING IMPACTED BY ALCOHOL AND METH ON A NEARLY DAILY BASIS. WITH AN ASTONISHING 97.5% OF ALL FELONY CASES BEING DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY TIED TO SUBSTANCE LIKE ALCOHOL AND METH CREATING A DANGEROUS ENVIRONMENT AND ONE THAT INSTILLS A NEGATIVE MESSAGE. AS NOTED BY FERGUS COUNTY SHERIFF AND CORONER, RICHARD VAUGHN, IN HIS LETTER OF SUPPORT “FROM MY NEARLY 29 YEARS OF LAW ENFORCEMENT EXPERIENCE I CAN TESTIFY THAT NEARLY ALL PERSONS BOOKED INTO THE FACILITY WERE RELATED TO SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE. THE NARCOTICS ARRESTS ARE NEARLY ALL FELONY CHARGES FOR METHAMPHETAMINE POSSESSION OR DISTRIBUTION WITH HEROIN CHARGES BECOMING MORE REGULAR. THEFT, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, ASSAULT, AND MOST OTHER ARRESTS ARE A RESULT OF SUBSTANCE USE OR ABUSE. ALCOHOL HAS ALWAYS PLAYED A MAJOR ROLE IN ARRESTS. METHAMPHETAMINE HAS AND IS OUTPACING ALCOHOL FOR ARRESTS IN THE PAST FEW YEARS. I AM CONFIDENT IN STATING THAT THE SUBSTANCE ABUSE IN OUR COUNTRY, STATE AND COUNTY IS AN EPIDEMIC. WE OWE IT TO OUR YOUTH TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF THIS TREND WITH PROGRAMS THAT WILL EDUCATE AND EMPOWER THEM TO BREAK THE CYCLE.”  THE CYMC IS CONFIDENT IN OUR WORK PLAN. WE ARE EVEN MORE CONFIDENT IN OUR TEAM AND COMMUNITY TO MAXIMIZE THE INVESTMENT AND DRIVE MEASURABLE CHANGE IN THE LIVES OF OUR MOST PRECIOUS RESOURCE—OUR CHILDREN. WITH THE SUPPORT OF DFC FUNDING, FERGUS COUNTY WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE AN EXCELLENT PLACE FOR FAMILIES AND CHILDREN TO LEARN, PLAY, AND GROW WITHOUT THE UNNEEDED DANGERS AND LIFE-ALTERING IMPACTS OF METH AND ALCOHOL.

UYLC DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES - THE PROPOSED DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM (DFC) PROJECT IS TO INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION TO BUILD THE CAPACITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE NECESSARY TO CREATE SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE RELATED TO ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SERVE KAMIAH, A SMALL FRONTIER COMMUNITY IN NORTH CENTRAL IDAHO WITH A POPULATION OF APPROXIMATELY 4,600 IN ITS SERVICE AREA.  OUR COMMUNITY HAS BEEN PLAGUED WITH A HISTORY OF SUBSTANCE USE RESULTING FROM A” WORK HARD, PLAY HARD” MENTALITY. GIVEN THIS HISTORY, INCREASING THE CAPACITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE OF OUR COMMUNITY TO TACKLE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IS PARAMOUNT TO THE OVERALL HEALTH OF OUR POPULATION.  BECAUSE OF OUR COUNTY’S RICH HISTORY OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE, THE POPULATION OF FOCUS FOR THE PROJECT IS THE KAMIAH SCHOOL DISTRICT BOUNDARIES, WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, PARENTS, AND YOUTH. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO SERVE THE ENTIRE POPULATION ANNUALLY, AND OVER THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT, WITH BOTH OF ITS GOALS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SERVE KAMIAH WITH ITS TWO MAIN GOALS: INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, RELATED TO UNDERAGE DRINKING AND MARIJUANA MISUSE. PROGRESS TOWARDS GOALS WILL BE MEASURED BY AN INCREASE IN COALITION PARTICIPATION AND COMMUNITY COLLABORATION BY 10% ANNUALLY; A DECREASE IN PAST 30-DAY YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE, PEER AND PARENTAL DISAPPROVAL, PERCEPTION OF HARM, AND INCREASE IN SUPPORT FOR AGENCIES THAT WORK WITH PEOPLE AFFECTED BY SUBSTANCE USE/MISUSE.  THROUGH DFC FUNDING, OUR COMMUNITY WILL WORK TO FURTHER STRENGTHEN CAPACITY AND COLLABORATION AMONG ADULTS AND KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AS STRONG PARTNERSHIPS WILL BE VITAL TO THE SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT. SPECIAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON 0–18- YEAR-OLDS WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR 20.1% OF THE OVERALL POPULATION. UTILIZING THE MOST EFFECTIVE PUBLIC HEALTH PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOCUSED ON COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE INCLUDING THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK AND CADCA’S SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE, THE UPRIVER YOUTH LEADERSHIP COUNCIL WILL PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED INITIATIVES TO ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE RELATED TO UNDERAGE DRINKING AND MARIJUANA USE. THE PROJECT COORDINATOR ALONG WITH THE COALITION MEMBERS WILL ENGAGE YOUTH BY OUTREACHING TO PUBLIC-SCHOOL SYSTEMS AS WELL AS TO CHURCH YOUTH GROUPS, YOUTH-ORIENTED GROUPS, AND PRIVATE AND CHARTER SCHOOLS. THE PROJECT COORDINATOR AND COALITION MEMBERS WILL ALSO SUPPORT A GROUP OF YOUTH ADVOCATES AS THEY LEARN TO LEAD THEIR PEERS, SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY IN SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION EFFORTS.

NEWFOUND COALITION FOR YOUTH DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM - THE NEWFOUND COALITION FOR YOUTH (NCFY) HAS PARTNERED WITH CADY, INC., TO APPLY TO THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM (DFC).  CADY IS A 501(C)3 ORGANIZATION ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FEDERAL FUNDS AND SERVE AS FISCAL AGENT ON BEHALF OF NCFY.  WE WILL ESTABLISH AND GROW A DFC COALITION, AND LAUNCH PREVENTION STRATEGIES SERVING THE NEWFOUND REGION OF NEW HAMPSHIRE (NH), COMPRISED OF THE TOWNS OF ALEXANDRIA, BRIDGEWATER, BRISTOL, DANBURY, GROTON, HEBRON, HILL AND NEW HAMPTON WITH A POPULATION OF 12,025.  OUR MISSION IS TO BUILD COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS, WORKING WITH OUR COMMUNITY TO PREVENT AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE MISUSE AND PROMOTE HEALTHY ENVIRONMENTS AND PROMISING FUTURES.  THE NCFY GREW OUT OF A GRASS-ROOTS RURAL HEALTH PLANNING PROGRAM LAUNCHED BY THE NEWFOUND DRUG RESPONSE TASK FORCE IN 2020, WHICH IDENTIFIED A NEED FOR YOUTH SUBSTANCE MISUSE PREVENTION SERVICES IN NEWFOUND.  THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION TO FOCUS ON LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  WE WILL ACHIEVE OUR GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCE-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL AND TARGETED PREVENTION STRATEGIES ADDRESSING PREVENTION OF YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE.  WE WILL EXPAND AND STRENGTHEN OUR COMMUNITY COALITION SPANNING ALL 12 COMMUNITY SECTORS.  A CORNERSTONE OF OUR APPROACH IS TO ENGAGE YOUTH IN SCHOOL-BASED PREVENTION PROGRAMMING AND A YOUTH ADVISORY COUNCIL FOCUSED ON YOUTH EMPOWERMENT AND SKILLS-BUILDING.  WE WILL ESTABLISH A PARENT ADVISORY COUNCIL TO SERVE AS A FOCAL POINT FOR COMMUNITY-WIDE YOUTH PREVENTION EDUCATION AND OUTREACH.  LEVERAGING THESE COLLABORATIONS, WE WILL LAUNCH AND DISSEMINATE COMPREHENSIVE YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA PREVENTION STRATEGIES THROUGH OUTREACH, EDUCATION, SOCIAL AND TRADITIONAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS, YOUTH ACTIVITIES, AND COMMUNITY TOWN HALLS AND EVENTS.  OUR OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO REDUCE RISK FACTORS AND PROMOTE PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, REDUCING USE OF ALCOHOL AND M ARIJUANA AMONG YOUTH IN THE NEWFOUND COMMUNITY.

CARVER CARES: A MULTI-SECTOR COMMUNITY COALITION APPROACH TO ADDRESS YOUTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE. - “CARVER CARES: A MULTI-SECTOR COMMUNITY COALITION APPROACH TO ADDRESS YOUTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE” WILL ENHANCE AND FURTHER STRENGTH COMMUNITY COLLABORATIONS TO FURTHER REDUCE AND PREVENT YOUTH PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE AND MARIJUANA USE IN THE RURAL TOWN OF CARVER, MASSACHUSETTS. CARVER CARES WILL WORK WITH THE TOWN OF CARVER, LOCATED IN PLYMOUTH COUNTY, MASSACHUSETTS AND IS 38.73 SQUARE MILES.  THE TOWN IS SITUATED APPROXIMATELY 45 MILES SOUTH OF BOSTON WITH ABOUT 11,797 RESIDENTS. THE TARGET POPULATION FOR THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE INDIVIDUALS AGED 18 AND UNDER IN CARVER. ACCORDING TO THE US CENSUS, CARVER’S POPULATION IS MADE UP OF 94.5% WHITE, 0.4% BLACK/AFRICAN AMERICAN, 0.2% AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVE, 1% ASIAN, AND 2.3% TWO OR MORE RACES. HISPANIC OR LATINO OF ANY RACE WERE OF 1.2% THE POPULATION.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR THE CARVER CARES COALITION TO IMPROVE AND CREATE AN INTERDISCIPLINARY MULTI-PRONGED APPROACH TO EDUCATE AND INFORM THE COMMUNITY OF CARVER ABOUT ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES), THE IMPACTS, RISKS AND HARMS OF YOUTH MARIJUANA USE AS WELL AS THE MISUSE OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO FURTHER ESTABLISH COMMUNITY-BASED EFFORTS IN CREATING A ROBUST CURRICULUM AND PROCESSES IN CARVER THAT WILL SPECIFICALLY ADDRESS THE PERCEIVED ACCEPTANCE AND ACCESSIBILITY TO BOTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUGS BY YOUTH, AND INCLUDE COMPONENTS REGARDING THE LONG-TERM IMPACTS OF ACES. THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO CHANGE LOCAL POLICIES, REGULATIONS AND LAWS RELATED TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TO DECREASE ACCESS OF SUBSTANCES AND MINIMIZE THE RISK FOR ACES, WHILE INCREASING EDUCATION AND RESOURCES FOR ALL RESIDENTS IN CARVER.

TOWN OF HOLLISTON- HOLLISTON DRUG ALCOHOL AWARENESS COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT - THE PURPOSE OF THE HOLLISTON DRUG AND ALCOHOL AWARENESS COALITION (HDAAC) TOWN OF HOLLISTON DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT IS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. SHORT TERM EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: AN INCREASE IN COALITION MEMBERSHIP BY 10%, AND YOUTH PARTICIPATION BY 10% AS MEASURED BY COALITION ATTENDANCE RECORDS. AN INCREASE IN COALITION MEMBER CAPACITY FROM ITS BASELINE BY 25%.  AN INCREASE IN YOUTH ATTENDANCE AT SUBSTANCE FREE ACTIVITIES BY 10% BY OCTOBER 2023 AS MEASURED BY YOUTH PROGRAM ATTENDANCE RECORDS. LONG TERM EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: A 30% DECREASE IN THE NUMBER OF YOUTH IN GRADES 9-12 WHO HAVE USED ALCOHOL IN THE LAST 30 DAYS BY YEAR 5 OF DFC FUNDING AS MEASURED BY THE MWAHS. A 30% DECREASE IN THE NUMBER OF YOUTH IN GRADES 9-12 WHO HAVE USED MARIJUANA IN THE LAST 30 DAYS BY YEAR 5 OF DFC FUNDING AS MEASURED BY THE MWAHS.

BRIDGING LIVES: A MULTI-PRONGED COALITION ADDRESSING YOUTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE - “BRIDGING LIVES: A MULTI-PRONGED COALITION ADDRESSING YOUTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE” WILL ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY-BASED EFFORTS TO PREVENT AND REDUCE MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE AMONG HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN GRADES 9-12 IN THE COMMUNITY OF BRIDGEWATER, MASSACHUSETTS. THE SUBURBAN TOWN OF BRIDGEWATER IS LOCATED 25 MILES SOUTH OF BOSTON AND IS HOME TO 28,633 RESIDENTS. THIS COMMUNITY IS MADE UP OF PREDOMINATELY WHITE RESIDENTS (85.1%), IN ADDITION TO 7.5% BLACK/AFRICAN AMERICAN, 0.3% NATIVE AMERICAN, 2.6% ASIAN, 1.8% TWO OR MORE RACES AND 3.1% HISPANIC OR LATINO. THIS PROJECT WILL SPECIFICALLY ADDRESS THE PERCEIVED ACCEPTABILITY, AVAILABILITY AND ACCESS TO MARIJUANA, A LACK OF HEALTHY COPING SKILLS AS WELL AS THE IMPACT THAT ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES) HAS ON YOUNG PEOPLE. THESE RISK FACTORS WILL BE MINIMIZED THROUGH CROSS-SECTOR COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AIMED AT IMPROVING LAWS, REGULATIONS AND POLICIES AROUND YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, DECREASING ACCESS, AND INCREASING EDUCATION AND RESOURCES FOR ALL. THE OUTCOMES THAT BRIDGING LIVES SEEKS TO ACHIEVE THROUGH THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM INCLUDE INCREASING OUTREACH TO RELEVANT SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY TO ENGAGE AND RECRUIT DIVERSE COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS. THE COALITION WILL ALSO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE REGARDING PATTERNS OF YOUTH MARIJUANA AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE THROUGH THE COLLECTION AND ASSESSMENT OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE DATA. THE PROGRAM SEEKS TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE OF COALITION EFFORTS TO ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN BRIDGEWATER, AS WELL AS, REDUCE FACTORS THAT INCREASE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE. THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PEER EDUCATION NETWORK, THE COALITION WILL INCREASE PROMOTION OF FACTORS THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE USE, AS WELL AS INCREASE THE EASE, ABILITY, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR YOUTH TO ACCESS SETTINGS, SUCH AS RESOURCES EMPHASIZING SELF-EFFICACY AND LEARNING SKILLS THAT PREVENT SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE. THE COALITION WILL ALSO DECREASE THE EASE, ABILITY, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR YOUTH TO ACCESS PRESCRIPTION DRUGS AND MARIJUANA BY EDUCATING AND INFORMING ABOUT POLICIES THAT REDUCE ACCESS, CHANGING CONSEQUENCES AND ENHANCING EDUCATION ABOUT THE DANGERS OF USE. THIS WORK WILL ULTIMATELY LEAD TO STRENGTHENED COLLABORATION WITHIN THE COMMUNITY AND A REDUCTION IN SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH AND ADULTS OVERTIME.

CHEEKTOWAGA HEALTHY YOUTH COALITION: A DRUG-FREE COMMUNITY - THE CHEEKTOWAGA HEALTHY YOUTH COALITION SEEKS A DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT TO PREVENT AND REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AMONG YOUTH IN THE COMMUNITY BY IMPLEMENTING INFORMATION CAMPAIGNS, STRUCTURED ACTIVITIES, AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH. THE CHEEKTOWAGA HEALTH YOUTH COALITION HAS BEEN MEETING SINCE MARCH 19, 2019, TO ADDRESS SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH IN THEIR COMMUNITY. THE COALITION’S FIRST MAJOR TASK WAS TO IMPLEMENT AND LATER ANALYZE THE RESULTS OF THE COMMUNITY-LEVEL YOUTH DEVELOPMENT EVALUATION (CLYDE) SURVEY DATA TO UNDERSTAND AND ASSESS YOUTH MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE ISSUES IN THE TOWN OF CHEEKTOWAGA. USING THE INFORMATION AND DATA THAT WAS COLLECTED AND ANALYZED FROM THE 2021 CLYDE SURVEY, WE WERE ABLE TO IDENTIFY ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AS OUR TWO TARGET SUBSTANCES. THE COALITION CHOSE ALCOHOL AS A TARGET SUBSTANCE BASED ON PREVALENCE DATA AVAILABLE FROM NEARBY COALITIONS, PRIMARY QUANTITATIVE DATA COLLECTED THROUGH THE CLYDE SURVEY, PRIMARY QUALITATIVE DATA COLLECTED THROUGH COALITION MEETINGS, AND ARCHIVAL DATA FROM COMMUNITY PARTNERS.  THE COALITION IS DEDICATED TO THE VISION OF A DRUG-FREE COMMUNITY FOR OUR YOUTH, WHERE THEY ARE SUPPORTED, VALUED, HEALTHY, AND SAFE. THE PREVENTION COUNCIL OF ERIE COUNTY, A 501 (C)3 ORGANIZATION, WHOSE MISSION IS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY BEHAVIORS THROUGH SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION, IS THE APPLICANT ON BEHALF OF THE COALITION. THROUGH A FORMAL MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING SIGNED BY THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE PREVENTION COUNCIL, AND THE TOWN OF CHEEKTOWAGA SUPERVISOR, THE PREVENTION COUNCIL OF ERIE COUNTY AGREED TO TAKE ON THE AOR ROLE. THE TOWN WILL SERVE AS A PARTNER IN THE COALITION AND WILL FURNISH MANY OF THE MATCHING FUNDS REQUIRED, BUT WILL NOT SERVE AS THE AOR.  THE COALITION INTENDS TO IMPACT THE TOWN OF CHEEKTOWAGA BY COLLABORATING WITH THE SCHOOLS TO ENGAGE YOUTH BY ESTABLISHING AN ACTIVE PRESENCE IN ALL FOUR SCHOOL DISTRICTS, WORKING WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT TO HELP IN DETERRING ADOLESCENT USE OF MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL, AND WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS BY EDUCATING THEM ON THE DANGERS AND CONSEQUENCES OF SUBSTANCE USE AND ADDICTION.

TONAWANDA DRUG FREE COALITION - TONAWANDA IS A SMALL, PROUD COMMUNITY LOCATED MIDWAY BETWEEN BUFFALO AND NIAGARA FALLS, AND BORDERED BY THE NIAGARA RIVER. POVERTY IS A SIGNIFICANT FACTOR, WITH 54% OF STUDENTS CONSIDERED “ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED” AND A 100% FREE LUNCH RATE IN DISTRICT. DESPITE THIS CHALLENGE, TONAWANDA HAS A LONG HISTORY OF COMMUNITY MOBILIZATION TO MEET LOCAL NEEDS. WITH NEARLY 29% OF TONAWANDA SECONDARY STUDENTS REPORTING EXPERIMENTATION WITH NICOTINE AND/OR CANNABINOIDS, THERE IS NO DENYING THAT TONAWANDA IS FACING A STEEP CLIMB. THE DISRUPTIONS AND DISTRACTIONS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CREATED FERTILE SOIL FOR AN ADDICTION EPIDEMIC THAT HAS RUN UNCHECKED FOR NEARLY THREE YEARS. ONCE CHALLENGES WERE IDENTIFIED AND QUANTIFIED, HOWEVER, MOBILIZATION BEGAN AT AN UNRELENTING PACE. LED BY THE TONAWANDA CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT, INVITATIONS WERE SENT OUT TO RECONVENE THE TONAWANDA DRUG FREE COALITION THAT HAD BEEN DERAILED IN 2019 DUE TO COVID, AND 100% OF INVITEES ATTENDED, BRINGING IDEAS AND ENTHUSIASM. NICOTINE AND CANNABINOID WERE QUICKLY AND UNANIMOUSLY IDENTIFIED AS THE SUBSTANCES OF FOCUS, BASED ON LOCAL NEEDS. TONAWANDA IS READY TO LEVERAGE THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE TO PROACTIVELY AND SUSTAINABLY ADDRESS NICOTINE AND CANNABINOID ADDICTION AMONG LOCAL YOUTH. THE TONAWANDA DRUG FREE COALITION IS ON A MISSION TO BUILD THE COMMUNITY SERVICES AND SUPPORTS THAT CAN PROTECT TONAWANDA YOUTH FROM ADDICTION. - OBJECTIVE 1: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PARTNERS IN THE DRUG FREE COALITION BY 15%, TO BE MEASURED BY ATTENDANCE ROSTERS. - OBJECTIVE 2: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, REDUCE BY 10% CURRENT USE OF NICOTINE (USE WITHIN 30 DAYS) AMONG YOUTH GRADES 6-12 TO BE MEASURED BY PRE- POST-PAST 30-DAY USE SURVEYS. - OBJECTIVE 3: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, REDUCE BY 10% CURRENT USE OF CANNABINOID (USE WITHIN 30 DAYS) AMONG YOUTH GRADES 6-12 TO BE MEASURED BY PRE- POST-PAST 30-DAY USE SURVEYS. AT THIS TIME, TONAWANDA YOUTH HAVE LIMITED EXPOSURE TO SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION PROGRAMMING. WITH FIVE YEARS OF ACTION, THE TONAWANDA DRUG FREE COALITION WILL SHIFT THIS REALITY. THE DISTRICT WILL BE SATURATED WITH EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION, REACHING STUDENTS AND PARENTS WITH FORMAL PROGRAMMING IN GRADES 5-12. THE SCHOOL ENVIRONMENT WILL PIVOT, WITH SOCIALLY INFLUENTIAL STUDENTS TRAINED AS PEER LEADERS, ONGOING PREVENTION PROGRAMS FOR ALL STUDENTS, AND VAPING PREVENTION POSTERS IN VISIBLE LOCATIONS IN HALLWAYS, BATHROOMS, AND OUTDOOR GATHERING LOCATIONS. SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS WILL KEEP DRUG AWARENESS AND PREVENTION CONVERSATIONS FRESH. REACTION TO STUDENT SUBSTANCE USE WILL EMBRACE BEST PRACTICES, INCLUDING SUPPORTIVE SERVICES AND EVIDENCE-BASED ADDICTION RECOVERY STRATEGIES TO REDUCE SUSPENSION TIME. **PLEASE NOTE: THESE SERVICES SUPPORT POSITIVE CHANGE, HELPING PERSONS TO AVOID RELAPSE, BUILD COMMUNITY SUPPORT FOR RECOVERY, AND WORK ON LIFE GOALS NOT RELATED TO ADDICTION SUCH AS RELATIONSHIPS AND EDUCATION. ADDICTION COACHING IS ACTION-ORIENTED WITH AN EMPHASIS ON IMPROVING PRESENT LIFE AND REACHING FUTURE GOALS – IT IS NOT A TREATMENT SERVICE. AS APPROPRIATE AND WITH PARENTAL CONSENT, STUDENTS WILL BE REFERRED TO THE PREVENTION COUNCIL OF ERIE COUNTY’S STUDENT ASSISTANCE PREVENTION COUNSELING (SAPC) OFFERING LICENSED PREVENTION COUNSELING THROUGH THE NYS OFFICE OF ALCOHOLISM AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE (NO GRANT FUNDS WILL BE NEEDED TO SUPPORT THESE COMMUNITY-BASED OPTIONS.) THE TONAWANDA COMMUNITY WILL FORMALIZE REFERRAL NETWORKS, ENSURING THAT YOUTH INVOLVED WITH ILLEGAL SUBSTANCES ARE CONNECTED WITH DISTRICT-LED RECOVERY PROGRAMMING REGARDLESS OF THE ENVIRONMENT THEY WERE IDENTIFIED IN. FINALLY, THE COMMUNITY WILL RALLY BEHIND AN ANNUAL RED RIBBON WEEK CELEBRATION OF BEING DRUG-FREE, WITH MOTIVATIONAL SPEAKER EVENTS FOR SECONDARY STUDENTS AND HIGH-INTEREST ACTIVITIES FOR ALL FAMILIES K-12, CEMENTING AN ANNUAL OPPORTUNITY TO SPOTLIGHT AWARENESS AND PREVENTION RELATED TO NICOTINE AND CANNABINOIDS.

WAYNE COUNTY COMMUNITY SCHOOLS DRUG FREE COMMUNITY COALITION - THE WAYNE COUNTY COMMUNITY SCHOOLS DRUG FREE COMMUNITY COALITION  (WCCS-DFCC) WAS AWARDED A FY2022 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $125,000 BY THE WHITE HOUSE OFFICE OF NATIONAL DRUG CONTROL POLICY, IN COOPERATION WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. THE COALITION SERVES WAYNE COUNTY, NY, A COMMUNITY OF 91,283.  THE WCCS-DFCC  WILL BE GUIDED BY THE FINGER LAKES COMMUNITY SCHOOLS MODEL INCLUDING ORGANIZING FACTORS, AND CORRESPONDING DATA, UTILIZING THE ARCH-C FRAMEWORK.  ARCH STANDS FOR ATTACHMENT, (E.G., TO FAMILY, COMMUNITY, OR SCHOOL), REGULATION OF SELF, (E.G., CONTROLLING IMPULSIVENESS AND SENSATION SEEKING), COMPETENCY, (E.G., ACADEMIC, SKILLS, SELF-EFFICACY), AND HEALTH, BOTH PHYSICAL AND BEHAVIORAL/SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL WHICH ARE ADDRESSED THROUGH -COLLABORATIVE PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION OF MULTIPLE STRATEGIES.  THIS MODEL OPERATES AS A PERSON-CENTERED, PLACE-BASED APPROACH PROMPTING CONSIDERATION OF SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL, COGNITIVE AND PHYSICAL NEEDS OF YOUNG PEOPLE, AND ENCOURAGING COMMUNITIES TO WORK TOGETHER TO SHAPE ENVIRONMENTS AND HARNESS RESOURCES TO MEET THOSE NEEDS. PREVENTION RESEARCHERS HAVE IDENTIFIED A SUBSET OF EARLY AND SHARED RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS THAT CAN BE TARGETED TO REDUCE THE PREVALENCE OF MENTAL, EMOTIONAL, AND BEHAVIORAL DIFFICULTIES FOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH. WE HAVE MAPPED HOW THESE HEALTH RISK FACTORS INTERFERE WITH SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN OUR COMMUNITY, LEADING TO MORE NEGATIVE LIFE TRAJECTORIES, ESPECIALLY FOR YOUTH WITH MULTIPLE CHALLENGES OCCUR LOCALLY.  WCCS-DFCC, AND THE PROPOSED STRATEGIC SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION PLANNING PROCESS, WILL BENEFIT FROM A DECADE OF EXTENSIVE DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS CONDUCTED UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THE WAYNE PARTNERSHIP, AND SUPPORTED BY FINGER LAKES COMMUNITY SCHOOLS.  DESPITE DECREASING RATES OF USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA, THE PROPORTION OF WAYNE COUNTY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS REPORTING HAVING USED ALCOHO L AT LEAST ONCE, I.E., LIFETIME USE OF ALCOHOL, WAS 38.3% IN 2021.  THESE RESULTS INDICATE THAT ALCOHOL REMAINS THE DRUG OF CHOICE AND A CONTINUING CONCERN.  NEARLY ONE IN FOUR (24.0%) HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS USED MARIJUANA AT SOME POINT IN THEIR LIFETIME.  AS A RESULT, ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA ARE THE TWO PRIMARY SUBSTANCES TO BE ADDRESSED BY THE WCCS-DFCC THROUGH A COMMUNITY SCHOOLS MODEL OF CO-LOCATING AND INTEGRATING COMMUNITY SUPPORTS USING A MULTI-TIERED SYSTEM OF SUPPORTS. THE COALITION’S TWO GOALS ARE TO INCREASE COLLABORATION AND TO REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  ACCOMPLISHING THOSE GOALS WILL REQUIRE ADDRESSING SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, INEQUITIES IN ACCESS TO SERVICES AND CAREFUL COORDINATION OF AVAILABLE RESOURCES.  THIS CROSS-SECTOR EFFORT OPERATES AS AN EXTENSION OF COLLABORATION SUPPORTED BY THE WAYNE PARTNERSHIP AND RELIES ON THE LEADERSHIP AND EXPERTISE OF WAYNE COUNTY MENTAL HEALTH, THE COUNCIL ON ALCOHOL AND ADDICTIONS OF THE FINGER LAKES AND SODUS CENTRAL SCHOOL DISTRICT.

THE ASAP BOARD WILL IMPLEMENT PROVEN COMMUNITY WIDE CHANGE STRATEGIES TO REDUCE PRESCRIPTION DRUG MISUSE, YOUTH ALCOHOL USE, AND TOBACCO (VAPING) USE AMONG YOUTH IN ALLEN COUNTY. - THE ALLEN COUNTY AGENCY FOR SUBSTANCE ABUSE POLICY BOARD IS APPLYING FOR THE FY2022 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $125,000.00 BY THE WHITE HOUSE OFFICE OF NATIONAL DRUG CONTROL POLICY, IN COOPERATION WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. THE COALITION SERVES SCOTTSVILLE, KENTUCKY, A COMMUNITY OF 21,065.  THE TWO GOALS OF THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM ARE TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COALITIONS AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE THE GOALS OF THE DFC BY IMPLEMENTING THESE STRATEGIES.  THE ASAP BOARD WILL IMPLEMENT THE SEVEN PROVEN COMMUNITY WIDE CHANGE STRATEGIES BASED ON THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK THAT WILL SEEK TO INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION, INCREASE RISK PERCEPTION, DECREASE ACCESS, AND DECREASE USAGE OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS, ALCOHOL, AND TOBACCO (VAPING) USE AMONG YOUTH IN ALLEN COUNTY.  BELOW IS A LIST OF THE OBJECTIVES:  -	BY 8/29/2023, BUILD CAPACITY AND COMPETENCIES OF THE ASAP BOARD, BY INCREASING ADULT AND YOUTH MEMBERSHIP (GRADES 6-12) BY 10% AS MEASURED BY TRACKING DOCUMENTATION (I.E. MEMBERSHIP ROSTER, SIGN-IN SHEETS, ETC.) -	BY 9/29/23, ASAP WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF ITS YOUTH (GRADES 6-12) AND ADULT COMMUNITY PARTNERS BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF ASAP/COMMUNITY SPONSORED EVENTS BY 15% AND ATTENDANCE AT THOSE EVENTS BY 30% AS EVIDENCED BY SIGN-IN SHEETS -	BY 9/29/23 INCREASE BY 5% THE YOUTH PERCEPTION OF RISK OF ALCOHOL AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY. -	BY 9/29/2023 INCREASE BY 5% THE YOUTH PERCEPTION OF RISK OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY. -	BY 9/29/2023 INCREASE BY 5% THE YOUTH PERCEPTION OF RISK OF TOBACCO (VAPING) AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY. -	BY 9/29/2023 DECREASE BY 5% THE 30-DAY USAGE OF ALCOHOL, AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY RESULTS. -	BY 9/29/2023 DECREASE BY 5% THE 30-DAY USAGE OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS, AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY RESULTS. -	BY 9/29/2023 DECREASE BY 5% THE 30-DAY USAGE OF TOBACCO (VAPING), AMONG 6TH, 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS AS EVIDENCED BY THE KENTUCKY INCENTIVES FOR PREVENTION (KIP) SURVEY RESULTS.

FUNDING NEEDED TO ENACT YOUTH SUBSTANCE-USE REDUCTION PROGRAMS IN FRANKLIN COUNTY, KENTUCKY. - CURRENTLY FRANKLIN COUNTY, KENTUCKY FACES AN EXACERBATED RATE OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE, WITH TOBACCO AND ALCOHOL. WHILE STATEWIDE USE OF THESE SUBSTANCES HAVE GENERALLY BEEN DECREASING, RECENT RATES IN FRANKLIN COUNTY HAVE RISEN, PARTLY DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO DECREASE SUBSTANCE USAGE AMONG YOUTH IN FRANKLIN COUNTY AND WILL BE LED BY THE FRANKLIN COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND ITS JUST SAY YES COALITION. THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE THE ICELANDIC PREVENTION MODEL (IPM), WHICH PLACES A HEAVY EMPHASIS ON INCREASING ACCESS TO OUT-OF-SCHOOL TIME ACTIVITIES AS A KEY PROTECTIVE FACTOR WITH POWERFUL PREVENTATIVE POTENTIAL FOR YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. THE IPM WILL GUIDE THE JUST SAY YES COALITION AND ITS PARTNERS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF VARIOUS SUBSTANCE-REDUCTION INITIATIVES WHICH WILL INVOLVE EXTENSIVE EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND COALITION BUILDING. THIS INCLUDES THE EXPANSION OF THE YES CARD PROGRAM WHICH WILL ANNUALLY DISTRIBUTE $400 GIFT CARDS TO PAY FOR PROVIDER-APPROVED YOUTH ACTIVITIES WHICH WILL ENCOURAGE OUT OF SCHOOL INVOLVEMENT FOR MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO EXPAND UPON PARENTAL EDUCATION THROUGH PARENT CAFES AND BE STRONG FAMILIES TRAINING, WHERE PARENTS WILL RECEIVE THE KNOWLEDGE TO UNDERSTAND THE FACTORS THAT DRIVE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND THE SKILLS TO MEANINGFULLY ENGAGE WITH THEIR CHILDREN. THROUGH THIS IMPLEMENTATION, FRANKLIN COUNTY AND THE JUST SAY YES COALITION AIM TO CREATE POSITIVE, HEALTHY ENVIRONMENTS FOR YOUTH THROUGH DATA-DRIVEN, MUTUALLY REINFORCING STRATEGIES AND CONSISTENT MESSAGING ACROSS VARIOUS SECTORS AND POPULATION GROUPS. THIS WILL RESULT IN AN OVERALL REDUCTION IN TOBACCO AND ALCOHOL USAGE AMONG FRANKLIN COUNTY YOUTH, AND IDEALLY YOUTH ACROSS THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY.

SWICACC SUPPORTS THE DUBOIS COUNTY COALITION FOR ADOLESCENT RESILIENCE AND EMPOWERMENT STRATEGIES AS IT EMPOWERS YOUTH TO BE ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA AND DRUG FREE. - DUBOIS COUNTY YOUTH IN GRADES 6-12 USE ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA. 2021 INDIANA YOUTH SURVEY RESULTS INDICATED THAT WHEN ASKED IF THEY HAD CONSUMED ALCOHOL WITHIN THE PAST 30-DAYS, THE FOLLOWING PERCENTAGES OF STUDENTS RESPONDED IN THE AFFIRMATIVE: 3.5% OF 6TH-GRADE STUDENTS, 4.5% OF 7TH-GRADE STUDENTS, 11.8% OF 8TH-GRADE STUDENTS, 11.5% OF 9TH-GRADE STUDENTS, 13.8% OF 10TH-GRADE STUDENTS, 13.4 OF 11TH-GRADE STUDENTS, AND 22.3% OF 12TH-GRADE STUDENTS. DUBOIS COUNTY JUVENILE COURT DATA INDICATES THAT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THERE WAS A SUBSTANTIAL RISE IN JUVENILE CASES THAT INVOLVED YOUTH ALCOHOL OR DRUG USE WITH 17 CASES FILED IN 2019, 23 CASES IN 2020, AND 40 FILED IN 2021. DUBOIS COUNTY HAS SPECIFICALLY SEEN A SHARP INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF FILED JUVENILE COURT CASES WHERE MARIJUANA IS THE PRESENTING SUBSTANCE. IN 2017, THE NUMBER OF FILED CASES FOR MARIJUANA POSSESSION WAS 4. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC IN 2020, THAT NUMBER INCREASED TO 9, AND IN 2021 THAT NEARLY DOUBLED AT 16 FILED CASES. INDIANA YOUTH SURVEY DATA INDICATES THAT DUBOIS COUNTY YOUTH REPORT PAST 30-DAY MARIJUANA USAGE AS GRADE 6: .2%, GRADE 7: 1.5%, GRADE 8: 2.1%, GRADE 9: 4.2%, GRADE 10: 4.1%, GRADE 11:3.4%, AND GRADE 12: 7.4%. WE KNOW THAT THE EARLIER YOUTH BEGIN USING ALCOHOL AND OTHER DRUGS, THE MORE LIKELY THEY ARE TO EXPERIENCE ADDICTION IN ADULTHOOD. IT IS OUR MISSION TO EMPOWER YOUTH IN DUBOIS COUNTY TO BE ALCOHOL AND DRUG-FREE. THROUGH ASSESSMENT, WE HAVE DETERMINED THAT THE ROOT CAUSES OF YOUTH ALCOHOL USE IN DUBOIS COUNTY ARE ALCOHOL AVAILABILITY AND FAVORABLE PARENTAL ATTITUDES TOWARD USE. MORE SPECIFICALLY, YOUTH IN DUBOIS COUNTY ARE ACCESSING ALCOHOL AT PARTIES, PEOPLE OVER 21 ARE PROVIDING ALCOHOL TO MINORS, PARENTS ARE ALLOWING YOUTH PARTIES WHERE ALCOHOL IS PRESENT, AND THAT ALCOHOL IS AT THE CENTER OF MANY FAMILY-ORIENTED EVENTS WITHIN OUR COMMUNITY. THE ROOT CAUSES OF MARIJUANA USE IN DUBOIS COUNTY ARE FAVORABLE YOUTH AND PARENT ATTITUDES, LOW PERCEPTION OF RISK, AND EASE OF ACCESS. WHILE VAPING IS A METHOD OF DRUG DELIVERY AND NOT A SUBSTANCE ITSELF, CARES SPECIFICALLY TARGETS THIS METHOD OF DELIVERY FOR MARIJUANA AND NICOTINE. WE HAVE FOUND THROUGH ASSESSMENT THAT IT IS THE PRIMARY WAY IN WHICH MARIJUANA IS USED BY YOUTH IN DUBOIS COUNTY AND THAT ONE ROOT CAUSE IS A LACK OF PARENTAL AWARENESS REGARDING VAPING DEVICES. DUBOIS COUNTY CARES UTILIZES THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK TO ASSESS THE COMMUNITY AND DEVELOP A 12-MONTH ACTION PLAN THAT INCLUDES THE SEVEN STRATEGIES OF COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE.
