WE IMPLEMENT PREVENTION ACTIVITIES TO NOT ONLY REDUCE THE NUMBER OF YOUTH WHO ARE CURRENTLY USING ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA BUT TO PREVENT OTHERS FROM DRUG USE INITIATION. THROUGH THE ACTIVITIES OF THE ACTION PLAN, WE AIM TO REDUCE THE AGGREGATE TOTAL PERCENTAGE OF YOUTH REPORTING PAST 30-DAY ALCOHOL USE FROM 11.5% IN 2021 TO 10% OR LESS IN 2027, TO REDUCE THE AGGREGATE TOTAL PERCENTAGE OF YOUTH REPORTING PAST 30-DAY ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE USE BY THE AGGREGATE TOTAL OF 21.42% IN 2019 TO 15% OR LESS IN 2027 AND TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF DUBOIS COUNTY JUVENILE COURT CASES WITH MARIJUANA AS A PRESENTING SUBSTANCE FROM 16 IN 2021 TO LESS THAN 5 IN 2027. WE UTILIZE CAMPAIGNS SUCH AS “TALK. THEY HEAR YOU,” “NOT IN MY HOUSE,” “HIDDEN IN PLAIN SIGHT” AND “TALK IT UP, LOCK IT UP” TO ACHIEVE THE GOALS OF THE ACTION PLAN. OUR PRIORITY IS TO ENSURE THAT OUR EFFORTS ARE CULTURALLY COMPETENT, DATA-DRIVEN, EVIDENCE-BASED, AND FOCUSED ON POPULATION-LEVEL CHANGE.

PARTNERS FOR A DRUG-FREE SULLIVAN COUNTY - PARTNERS FOR A DRUG-FREE SULLIVAN COUNTY WILL COLLABORATE WITH 12 SECTOR PARTNERS, COALITION MEMBERS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WHO WILL WORK TO PROMOTE ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, TOBACCO, AND NICOTINE PREVENTION IN SULLIVAN COUNTY.  PARTNERING WITH MENTAL HEALTH AMERICA WEST CENTRAL INDIANA, PARTNERS FOR A DRUG-FREE SULLIVAN COUNTY WILL PREVENT YOUTH FROM USING SUBSTANCES BY USING INITIATIVES TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE RISK FACTORS OF USE, TRAIN PARENTS, TEACHERS, AND OTHER ADULT STAKEHOLDERS TO SPEAK TO CHILDREN ABOUT THE RISKS OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE, PROVIDE EDUCATION TO YOUTH ON SUBSTANCE MISUSE, USING THE EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUM TO INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND NEGATE RISK FACTORS, ALL THE WHILE WORKING WITH SCHOOLS AND POLICYMAKERS TO UPDATE, CHANGE, AND ADD POLICIES THAT PROTECT YOUTH FROM THE DANGERS OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE AND ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES.

REDUCE THE USE, DEVELOP THE YOUTH (RUDY) - HEALTHY COMMUNITIES OF CLINTON COUNTY COALITION (HCCCC) IS A 501C3 ORGANIZATION LOCATED IN A RURAL COUNTY IN NORTH-CENTRAL INDIANA.  CLINTON COUNTY HAS INCREDIBLE DIVERSITY FOR RURAL INDIANA.  ACCORDING TO THE US CENSUS, 16.5% OF ALL RESIDENTS IN CLINTON COUNTY ARE LATINO.  TAKING INTO ACCOUNT THE KNOWN LARGE NUMBER OF UNDOCUMENTED LATINO RESIDENTS AND THE FACT THAT THE COMMUNITY SCHOOLS OF FRANKFORT HAS AN ENROLLMENT OF 53.2% LATINO STUDENTS, THE COUNTY GOVERNMENT ESTIMATES IT TO BE CLOSER TO 35% OF ALL RESIDENTS IN CLINTON COUNTY ARE LATINO. 	HCCCC IS A GRASSROOTS COALITION FORMED IN 2006.  OUR MISSION IS REDUCING THE RISK FACTORS THAT LEAD TO CHRONIC DISEASE BY MAKING PERMANENT CHANGES THROUGH POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES.  OUR ROBUST COALITION IS MADE UP OF OVER 50 ENTHUSIASTIC PARTNERS THAT REPRESENT ALL SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY. HCCCC'S ROLE IN THE COMMUNITY IS WIDESPREAD WITH STRONG CONNECTIONS WITH THE SCHOOLS, GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, LOCAL BUSINESSES, PARENTS, CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS, THE MINISTERIAL ASSOCIATION, YOUTH LEADERSHIP COUNCIL, LAW ENFORCEMENT, SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES, SOBER-LIVING HOMES, HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS, CHURCHES, AND LOCAL MEDIA.  HCCCC IS THE GO-TO ORGANIZATION FOR HEALTH IN CLINTON COUNTY.  HCCCC HELPS MAKE THE HEALTHY CHOICE THE EASY CHOICE. 	HCCCC COVERS MANY AREAS IN PREVENTATIVE HEALTH, BUT ESPECIALLY YOUTH.  HCCCC’S MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER (SUD) TEAM’S MISSION STATEMENT IS TO DECREASE SUBSTANCE USE BY COMMUNITY MEMBERS THROUGH PREVENTION, TREATMENT, AND INTERVENTION, AND BREAK DOWN THE BARRIERS TO MENTAL HEALTH ASSISTANCE.  LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND THE FOUR COUNTY SCHOOLS IN OUR COMMUNITY LOOK TO HCCCC FOR PREVENTION PROGRAMMING AND PRESENTATIONS FOR YOUTH.  LAST YEAR WHEN CLINTON CENTRAL AND CLINTON PRAIRIE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS HAD A PROBLEM WITH NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA, SPECIFICALLY THROUGH THE USE OF VAPING DEVICES, BOTH SCHOOLS REACHED OUT TO HCCCC.  HCCCC WAS ABLE TO PROVIDE PREVENTION PROGRAMMING TO BOTH SCHOOLS QUICKLY AND EFFICIENTLY. 	THE PURPOSE OF OUR PROPOSED PROJECT, REDUCE THE USE, DEVELOP THE YOUTH (RUDY), IS TO UTILIZE THE CADCA CHANGE STRATEGIES AND SAMHSA VAPING PREVENTION FRAMEWORK TO ADDRESS NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA WHICH IS HAVING A NEGATIVE IMPACT ON OUR COMMUNITY AT MULTIPLE LEVELS.  UNFORTUNATELY, THE INCREASE IN TEEN VAPING IS CAUSING AN INCREASE IN BOTH NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA USE LOCALLY, THE TWO SUBSTANCES THAT THE COALITION WILL ADDRESS WITH THIS FUNDING.  21.4% OF MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, 17.4% OF 10TH GRADERS, AND 21.3% OF 11TH GRADERS REPORT USAGE OF NICOTINE PRODUCTS, WHICH IS ALL HIGHER THAN THE STATE AVERAGE (2020 INYS).  ANOTHER AREA OF CONCERN, ACCORDING TO THE 2020 INYS, IS THE DRASTIC INCREASE IN MARIJUANA USE IN THE LAST MONTH FROM 9TH GRADE (7.1%) TO 11TH GRADE (14.3%). THERE IS A LOW SENSE OF PERCEPTION OF HARM AND RISK REGARDING SUBSTANCE MISUSE (2020 INYS). 34.9% OF 10TH GRADERS IN OUR AREA HAVE FAVORABLE ATTITUDES TOWARD DRUG USE (2020 INYS).  IT IS IMPACTING SCHOOL DISCIPLINE INCLUDING EXPULSIONS, CITATIONS FOR THOSE 18 TO 21 YEARS OF AGE, AND INCREASED PROBATION CASES FOR THOSE UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE.  THE USE OF NICOTINE, CANNABIS, AND THC HAVE A NEGATIVE LONG-TERM IMPACT ON OUR HEALTH OUTCOMES AND RANKINGS. 	OUR INTENDED OUTCOME IS TO BOTH DECREASE THE INITIAL USE OF NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA, BUT ALSO TO LOWER ONGOING USE OF THESE SAME SUBSTANCES.  WE WOULD DO THIS THROUGH STRENGTHENING OUR COLLABORATION WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO IMPLEMENT INDIVIDUAL, SCHOOL, AND COMMUNITY LEVEL INTERVENTIONS, DECREASE BARRIERS, INCREASE ACCESS TO PREVENTATIVE AND TREATMENT MEASURES, AND ENHANCE COMMUNITY MEMBERS’ KNOWLEDGE TO MAKE A LONG-TERM POSITIVE IMPACT. 	HCCCC WOULD LIKE TO TAKE THE SUCCESSES THAT WE HAVE HAD IN THE PREVENTION OF SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER IN A MORE FOCUSED, SUSTAINABLE DIRECTION THROUGH THE DFC GRANT.  THIS ADDITIONAL FUNDING WOULD ALLOW US TO STRENGTHEN OUR COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY

JEFFERSON BERKELEY ALLIANCE DRUG FREE COMMUNITY PROGRAM - THE JEFFERSON BERKELEY ALLIANCE ON SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION (JBASUP) DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THE PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM OF SUBSTANCE USE AMONG CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS IN BERKELEY AND JEFFERSON COUNTIES IN WEST VIRGINIA (WV).  THE JBASUP DFC WILL PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION CURRICULUM IN SCHOOLS LOCATED IN HEDGESVILLE, HARPERS FERRY, AND RANSON, WV.  THE JBASUP WILL USE THE SAMHSA SPF COALITION MODEL TO CONDUCT ASSESSMENTS, BUILD CAPACITY, PLAN AND IMPLEMENT A 12 MONTH-MONTH ACTION PLAN, AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS AND OUTCOMES OF THE DFC WORK PLAN TO MONITOR AND IMPROVE THROUGHOUT THE LONGITUDINAL JBASUP DFC PROJECT.

PRESTERA CENTER'S LOGAN COUNTY (WV) PREVENTION COALITION, LOGAN, WV - PRESTERA CENTER FOR MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES INC. IS THE COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNITY MENTAL HEALTH CENTER APPLYING FOR DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) GRANT FUNDS FOR ITS LOGAN COUNTY (WEST VIRGINIA) PREVENTION COALITION.  LOGAN COUNTY IS A DISADVANTAGED RURAL COUNTY IN SOUTHERN WEST VIRGINIA.  LOGAN COUNTY HAS A LONG HISTORY OF OF SUBSTANCE USE PROBLEMS.  THE LOGAN COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION'S MISSION IS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY AND SAFE COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT LOGAN COUNTY BY REDUCING ALCOHOL AND DRUG USE AMONG YOUTH.  THE GOALS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO 1) INCREASE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE COALITION AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS; AND 2) REDUCE NICOTINE, UNDERAGE DRINKING, AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG YOUTH. THE COALITION HAS PARTNERED WITH ALL 12 SECTORS TO CREATE COMMUNITY CHANGE IN LOGAN COUNTY.  PRESTERA CENTER IS REQUESTING $125,000 PER YEAR IN DFC FUNDING FOR PREVENTION ACTIVITIES IN LOGAN COUNTY, WEST VIRGINIA.

THE MARTINSBURG INITIATIVE'S DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT - THE MARTINSBURG INITIATIVE IS AN ESTABLISHED POLICE, SCHOOL, COMMUNITY, HEALTH, AND EDUCATION PARTNERSHIP.  THE PURPOSE OF TMI’S COMMUNITY COALITION IS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, BUILD STRONG FAMILIES, AND EMPOWER THE COMMUNITY.  TMI WILL EMPLOY EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT FOCUS ON PREVENTING THE INITIATION OF AND USE OF SUBSTANCES AMONG YOUTH INCLUDING SUPPORTING PATTERNS OF SUBSTANCE USE THAT DIFFER AMONG POPULATIONS.  TMI WILL PROVIDE CONNECTIONS FOR RESOURCES FOR SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, AND ADDRESS ROOT CAUSES AND RISK FACTORS RELATED TO SUBSTANCE USE AND WILL IMPLEMENT COMPREHENSIVE STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THE INDIVIDUAL, FAMILY, AND COMMUNITY LEVEL RISK. TMI’S DFC PROJECT SEEKS TO INCREASE YOUTHS’ PERCEPTION OF RISK AND REDUCE ANNUAL USE OF SUBSTANCES AT 11 SCHOOL SITES IN THE MARTINSBURG COMMUNITY.  THIS DFC-FUNDED PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT THE EVIDENCE-BASED TOO GOOD FOR DRUGS PROGRAM AT SCHOOL SITES.  TMI’S DFC PROJECT WILL  EMPLOY RISK STRATIFICATION METHODS TO SCREEN FOR ACES AND TRAUMA AMONG MARTINSBURG YOUTH TO ENSURE THEY ARE CONNECTED TO CASE MANAGEMENT AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES. TMI WILL USE THE SUBSTANCE ABUSE MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMINISTRATION’S (SAMHSA’S) STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (SPF) TO GUIDE COALITION ACTIVITIES SURROUNDING ASSESSMENT, PLANNING, CAPACITY BUILDING, IMPLEMENTATION OF THE 12-MONTH ACTION PLAN, AND EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE MEASURES TO ENSURE PROGRAMMATIC SUCCESS.

FARICARES YOUTH ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE PREVENTION AND EDUCATION GRANT PROPOSAL - FARICARES COALITION, UNDER THE FISCAL HOST OF ISD 2134 (UNITED SOUTH CENTRAL PUBLIC SCHOOLS) IS APPLYING FOR THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM. OUR COALITION IS DETERMINED TO CONTINUE WORKING ON PREVENTION AND REDUCING YOUTH ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE AND ABUSE. FARICARES IS REQUESTING 5 YEARS OF FUNDING AT $125,000 PER YEAR WITH THE COALITION PROVIDING 1:1 MATCH. FARICARES WAS FORMED IN 2012 WHEN COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ORGANIZATIONS OF FARIBAULT COUNTY RECOGNIZED THE NEED FOR A STRUCTURED GROUP FOCUSING ON REDUCING AND PREVENTING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. A WIDE RANGE OF MEMBERS AND ORGANIZATIONS PARTICIPATED ON THE COALITION AND TOGETHER, APPLIED FOR AND RECEIVED A 2016 PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION (P&I) GRANT FROM THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES (DHS), BEHAVIORAL HEALTH UNIT. THE P&I GRANT IMPLEMENTED SEVERAL PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR COMBATING UNDERAGE CONSUMPTION, INCLUDING USING POSITIVE COMMUNITY NORMS (PCN) MESSAGING. THIS MESSAGING FOCUSES ON THE FACT THAT MOST STUDENTS ARE CHOOSING NOT TO USE SUBSTANCES AND CHOOSING HEALTHY ACTIVITIES IN ITS PLACE. DHS HAS BEEN USING THE PCN STRATEGY FOR ALMOST 20 YEARS WITH PROVEN RESULTS IN REDUCING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE/ABUSE. IN THE 10 YEARS SINCE FARICARES STARTED, THE COALITION HAS STRENGTHENED MANY PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL AND REGIONAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND WORKED CLOSELY WITH OUR COMMUNITIES TO PROMOTE AND EDUCATE ABOUT REDUCING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. THE P&I GRANT WAS EFFECTIVE IN HELPING REDUCE YOUTH ALCOHOL USE, AND HAD A PROMISING START TO REDUCING YOUTH TOBACCO USE VIA E-CIGARETTES BEFORE MOMENTUM WAS LOST IN 2020 DUE TO THE PANDEMIC. THE POSITIVE MESSAGING HAS BEEN WELL RECEIVED AND WE KNOW WE WILL CONTINUE MAKING FURTHER PROGRESS IN CHANGING PERCEPTIONS AND BEHAVIORS RELATED TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE WITH THE DFC SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT. THE DFC GRANT WILL HELP FARICARES CONTINUE THEIR WORK IN REDUCING YOUTH ALCOHOL USE RATES, AS WELL AS FOCUSING ON TOBACCO USE VIA E-CIGARETTES (VAPING). THE COALITION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN REDUCING YOUTH ALCOHOL RATES BASED ON MINNESOTA STUDENT SURVEY (MSS) DATA FROM 2016 TO 2019, BUT THE RATES ARE STILL SIGNIFICANT ENOUGH THAT IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONTINUE FOCUSING ON ALCOHOL AS A SUBSTANCE. PAST 30 DAY USE FOR 11TH GRADERS ON THE 2019 MSS WAS 18%. YOUTH TOBACCO USE VIA E-CIGARETTE SOARED IN THE 2019 MSS DATA, AND WAS A SUBSTANCE THE COALITION ADDED IN FALL OF 2019. 28% OF 11TH GRADERS REPORTED PAST 30 DAY USE OF TOBACCO VIA E-CIGARETTE, AND BASED ON PCN AND ANECDOTAL DATA, THE COALITION BELIEVES STRONGLY THAT THOSE RATES HAVE RISEN SINCE THE 2019 MSS SURVEY AND DURING THE PANDEMIC.  WE BELIEVE 2022 MSS DATA WILL SUPPORT OUR RATIONALE FOR CONTINUED FOCUS ON ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE VIA E-CIGARETTES, AND WILL PROVIDE FURTHER CONTEXT FOR BEHAVIORS AND PERCEPTIONS THAT CHANGED THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC. THE DFC GRANT WILL ALLOW THE COALITION TO HAVE A DEDICATED PERSON FOCUSED ON YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION AND REDUCTION, AS WELL AS FOCUSING ON GROWING OUR COALITION PARTNERSHIPS AND YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN SUBSTANCE-FREE ACTIVITIES. IT IS OUR HOPE THAT THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW US TO SPREAD COUNTY-WIDE TO INCLUDE BOTH SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN FARIBAULT COUNTY, AS WELL AS HAVE CONCURRENT, POSITIVE MESSAGING THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE REGION.

COALITION FOR A DRUG-FREE CARROLL COUNTY, OHIO - CARROLL COUNTY GENERAL HEALTH DISTRICT IS THE APPLICANT AND WILL SERVE AS THE FISCAL OFFICER FOR THE COALITION FOR DRUG FREE CARROLL COUNTY (CDFCC). CDFCC HAS BEEN AN ACTIVE COALITION IN CARROLL COUNTY, OHIO FOR NEARLY 10 YEARS. ONE OF THE COALITIONS GOALS IS TO OBTAIN SUSTAINABLE FUNDING. APPLYING FOR THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT THROUGH CDC IS ONE WAY TO MEET THIS GOAL. THE CDFCC HAS BEEN WORKING ON ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION STRATEGIES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON TOBACCO AND MORE RECENTLY VAPING AS A MECHANISM FOR TOBACCO USE IN YOUTH. THE DFC GRANT WILL ALLOW FOR THE EXPANSION OF THE COALITION AND WILL STRENGTHEN THE COALITION MEMBERSHIP THROUGH TRAININGS AND INCREASING SKILLS TO BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY WITHIN THE COMMUNITY TO ADDRESS SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION STRATEGIES. SPECIFIC STRATEGIES AROUND ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE WILL BE TO TARGET EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO YOUTH AND PARENTS BRINGING THE TARGETED AGE TO MIDDLE SCHOOL AS THE MOST RECENT COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSESSMENT IDENTIFIED SUBSTANCE USE INCREASING IN MIDDLE SCHOOL AGED STUDENTS, AND AGE OF STARTING HAS ALSO DECREASED IN THE LAST 5 YEARS TO AS YOUNG AS AGE 12. EDUCATION WILL BE USING EVIDENCE-BASED PROGRAMS PROVIDING SKILLS TO PARENTS TO TALK TO THEIR YOUTH, AND HAVING YOUTH INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS OR REELS TARGETED AT RURAL/COUNTRY KIDS.

THE HURON COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION STRIVES TO SUPPORT, EMPOWER, AND ADVOCATE FOR THE YOUTH AND FAMILIES OF HURON COUNTY BY BUILDING RESILIENCE, PROMOTING MENTAL HEALTH WELLNESS, AND PREVENTING SUBS - THE GOAL OF THE HURON COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION IS TO DECREASE ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG HURON COUNTY YOUTH THROUGH COLLABORATION, EDUCATION, AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND EMPOWERMENT.

GEAUGA COMMUNITY FORUM COALITION - DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) AND SUPPORT PROGRAM – NEW GEAUGA COMMUNITY FORUM COALITION PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY  AS WITH MUCH OF OHIO, GEAUGA COUNTY HAS EXPERIENCED A GROWING SUBSTANCE ABUSE PROBLEM IN RECENT YEARS, INCLUDING 24% OF ADULTS IN GEAUGA COUNTY BEING CONSIDERED BINGE DRINKERS AND 15.3% OF TREATMENT CLAIMS HAVING A PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS OF CANNABIS USE DISORDER IN 2019. ,  ANECDOTALLY, NEARLY 90% OF TEACHERS AND STAFF REPORTED SEEING AN INCREASE IN YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN RECENT YEARS. WHEN ASKED WHICH SUBSTANCES ARE MOST OFTEN MISUSED BY YOUTH IN THE COMMUNITY, 85% OF RESPONDENTS INDICATED MARIJUANA AND 70% INDICATED ALCOHOL. ADDITIONALLY, 55% OF GEAUGA COUNTY STUDENTS DO NOT HAVE SUFFICIENT ASSETS TO THRIVE AS A RESULT OF HAVING A LACK PROTECTIVE FACTORS RELATED TO CONNECTION TO SCHOOL, COMMUNITY SUPPORT, POSITIVE ACTIVITIES, AND POSITIVE SENSE OF SELF. ,  RESEARCH INDICATES THAT THESE RISK FACTORS ARE SOME OF THE MOST COMMON ASSOCIATED WITH HIGH-RISK YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE PURPOSE OF THE GEAUGA COMMUNITY FORUM COALITION (GCFC) IS TO REVERSE THESE PROBLEMS BY CONVENING A CROSS-SYSTEM GROUP OF COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO STRATEGICALLY DETERMINE ENVIRONMENTAL PREVENTION STRATEGIES THAT HELP YOUTH BUILD RESILIENCY AND REDUCE RISK FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. BY WORKING AT THE COMMUNITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL LEVELS, THE COALITION’S ACTIVITIES ARE SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO POSITIVELY IMPACT PREVALENCE RATES OF YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AT THE POPULATION-HEALTH LEVEL. THIS PURPOSE ULTIMATELY EMPOWERS COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO ASSIST YOUTH IN BUILDING RESILIENCY AND REDUCING RISK FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CONDITIONS, PARTICULARLY AS IT RELATES TO ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE.  UTILIZING THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK AND CADCA’S SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE, GCFC WILL ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES THAT ARE ALIGNED WITH THEIR 12-MONTH ACTION PLAN. SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES: COALITION MEMBERS WILL BE FULLY INFORMED ABOUT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. RETAILERS WILL BECOME MORE KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT THE DANGERS AND PREVALENCE OF UNDERAGE DRINKING. MORE COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BECOME AWARE OF THE DANGERS OF YOUTH MARIJUANA USE. INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES: COALITION MEMBERS WILL HAVE THE SKILLSETS NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT ENVIRONMENTAL PREVENTION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE COALITION’S 12-MONTH ACTION PLAN. SCHOOLS WILL DEVELOP CODES OF CONDUCT REGARDING ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION BY YOUTH. ACCESS TO ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA WILL DECREASE FOR YOUTH. YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN PROSOCIAL ACTIVITIES WILL INCREASE. YOUTH LEADERS WILL BECOME MORE SKILLED AND KNOWLEDGEABLE IN ENCOURAGING PEERS NOT TO USE MARIJUANA. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES: THE OVERALL NUMBER AND RETENTION OF COALITION MEMBERS WILL INCREASE. FEWER YOUTH WILL DRINK ALCOHOL AND USE MARIJUANA.

THE GOALS OF THE KOSCIUSKO DRUG FREE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE. - PROJECT ABSTRACT   ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE ARE LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERNS IN RURAL KOSCIUSKO COUNTY, (POPULATION: 80,240; 2020) IN NORTH-EASTERN INDIANA. THE COUNTY IS A MAJOR TOURISM DESTINATION BEST KNOWN FOR ITS “LAKE CULTURE.” AN ESTIMATED 20 PERCENT OF KOSCIUSKO COUNTY’S ADULT POPULATION SMOKE, HIGHER THAN BOTH NATIONAL AND STATE RATES (INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, 2021). THERE ARE 159 ALCOHOL OUTLETS IN KOSCIUSKO COUNTY; EQUIVALENT TO A RATE OF 20.1 OUTLETS PER 10,000 PEOPLE COMPARED TO 18.2 FOR THE STATE (INDIANA PREVENTION RESOURCE CENTER, 2020). CURRENT TRENDS AMONG KOSCIUSKO YOUTH RAISE CONCERNS THAT THE CYCLE WILL NOT BE BROKEN WITH THIS GENERATION: TEENS’ SURVEY RESPONSES TO CORE MEASURES ON PERCEPTION OF HARM, AS WELL AS PARENTAL AND PEER DISAPPROVAL, ARE LOWER THAN STATE RATES AMONG 8TH, 10TH, AND 12TH GRADE STUDENTS (INDIANA YOUTH SURVEY, 2020).   THE MISSION OF KOSCIUSKO DRUG FREE COALITION (KDFC) IS “TO BUILD HOPE AND ELIMINATE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH” (KDFC STRATEGIC PLAN, 2017). THE COALITION HAS BEEN STAFF-LED SINCE ITS INCEPTION IN 2013, REACHING A TOTAL OF 8,152 CHILDREN WITH DIRECT PREVENTION PROGRAMS DELIVERED PRIMARILY IN SCHOOLS OVER THE PAST SIX YEARS. KDFC IS THE ONLY PRIMARY PREVENTION PROVIDER IN THE COUNTY, THE RESULT OF A STATE-FUNDED GRANT TO THE ORGANIZATION KOSCIUSKO CARES THROUGH ITS FISCAL AGENT, THE OTIS R. BOWEN CENTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES (BOWEN CENTER). AS INDIANA’S LARGEST COMMUNITY MENTAL HEALTH CENTER, THE BOWEN CENTER WILL SERVE AS FISCAL AGENT TO KDFC AND ITS DRUG-FREE-COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM AWARD.   THE 554-SQUARE MILE KOSCIUSKO COUNTY COVERS 21 ZIP CODES; THE MOST POPULATED INCLUDING WARSAW (POPULATION: 15,202); FOLLOWED BY WINONA LAKE, SYRACUSE, MILFORD, NORTH WEBSTER, AND PIERCETON (BETWEEN 5,000 AND 1,000). THE COUNTY’S FOUR PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICTS (WARSAW, WAWASEE, TIPPECANOE VALLEY, AND WHITCO) AND THEIR 23 SCHOOLS PRE-K THROUGH 12TH GRADE EDUCATE APPROXIMATELY 12,700 CHILDREN (2021/22). TO TACKLE LOCAL ALCOHOL- AND TOBACCO-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES, THE COALITION WILL RECRUIT PREVENTION ADVOCATES FROM ALL AGES, BUT SPECIFICALLY YOUTH, TO DEVELOP A PIPELINE FOR SUCCESSION AND TO GENERATE EXCITEMENT AMONG TEENS TO BE COMMUNITY LEADERS. ONLY THEN CAN KDFC ACHIEVE ITS TWIN GOALS TO, FIRST, REACH MORE FAMILIES WITH TIMELY AND CULTURALLY-APPROPRIATE EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND SERVICE PROVISION TARGETING POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND, SECOND, SUSTAIN A MIX OF ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIES AND PROGRAMS BEYOND A SINGLE FUNDING STREAM.   KDFC IS CURRENTLY MADE UP OF ADULTS REPRESENTING BUSINESS, MEDIA, EDUCATION, LAW ENFORCEMENT, SOCIAL SERVICES, YOUTH-SERVING ORGANIZATIONS, PARENTS, GOVERNMENT, HEALTHCARE, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH, RELIGIOUS, AND CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS. THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM WILL EFFECT IMMEDIATE CAPACITY-BUILDING IN THE COMMUNITY LED BY KDFC’S 12 SECTOR REPRESENTATIVES WHO WILL MODEL FACILITATIVE LEADERSHIP FOR CONSENSUS-STYLE GOVERNANCE AND IMPLEMENT ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGIES TO PREVENT SUBSTANCE MISUSE AMONG KOSCIUSKO TEENAGERS INTO THEIR ADULTHOOD AND REDUCE DRUG-RELATED OVERDOSES OVER THE NEXT 10 YEARS. THE VISION OF KDFC IS TO END YOUTH EXPERIMENTING WITH THE TWO MOST PREVALENT GATEWAY DRUGS IN THE COUNTY, ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO. THE WAY FORWARD FOR KDFC AND ITS COALITION PARTNERS IS CHAMPIONING BEST PRACTICES IN PREVENTION SCIENCE AND ADVOCATING FOR A PUBLIC HEALTH MODEL OF PREVENTION.   THE FIRST OUTCOME OF DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM FUNDING IS TO RAISE PUBLIC AWARENESS ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL PREVENTION STRATEGIES FOR TRAINING, OUTREACH, AND NETWORKING BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF STAKEHOLDER COLLABORATIONS 20 PERCENT ANNUALLY OVER KDFC’S MEMBERSHIP BASELINE. THE SECOND OUTCOME IS A 1.25 - 2.5% REDUCTION IN YOUTH ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO USE OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS. THE COALITION WI

PREVENTION PROJECT BUTLER COUNTY MISSOURI- WE CAN BE DRUG FREE COALITION - THE MISSION STATEMENT OF THE WE CAN BE DRUG FREE COALITION IS, “WE CAN BE DRUG FREE IS A COMMUNITY COALITION THAT WORKS TO PREVENT THE POTENTIAL HARM OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, AND OTHER DRUGS BY EMPOWERING THE YOUTH IN OUR COMMUNITY.” THE PURPOSE OF THIS APPLICATION IS TO CONTINUE AND FURTHER THE EFFORTS OF THE WE CAN BE DRUG FREE COALITION TO REACH AND EMPOWER MORE YOUTH TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE IN THE COMMUNITY.   WE ARE DEDICATED TO CREATING COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE AND HAVE DONE SO BY CREATING A WELL-BALANCED PLAN THAT ADDRESSES PERSONAL, COMMUNITY, FAMILY, AND SCHOOL RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS WHICH HAVE A DIRECT IMPACT ON THE YOUTH OF BUTLER COUNTY. THE WE CAN BE DRUG FREE COALITION HAS SELECTED OUTCOMES THAT ARE REALISTIC, ATTAINABLE, AND THAT WILL HAVE THE BIGGEST IMPACT ON OUR COMMUNITY. THE OUTCOMES WE HAVE SELECTED ARE DIRECTLY CONNECTED TO THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES LONG TERM GOALS AND A DIRECT PRODUCT OF OUR MISSION TO EMPOWER YOUTH IN OUR COMMUNITY. OUR COALITION PLANS TO STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS BY WORKING WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND YOUTH IN OUR AREA TO CREATE TWO MEDIA CAMPAIGNS TO EDUCATE YOUTH AND PARENTS ABOUT THE HARMFUL EFFECTS OF VAPING NICOTINE. WE ALSO PLAN TO COLLABORATE WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN THE COMMUNITY TO OFFER THE GUIDING GOOD CHOICES PARENT WORKSHOP, WHICH IS A EVIDENCE-BASED PROGRAM THAT HELPS PARENTS PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE COALITION IS ALSO COMMITTED TO REDUCING SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH, AND OVER TIME, REDUCING SUBSTANCE USE AMONG ADULTS. IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL WE WILL EDUCATE PARENTS AND STUDENTS WHO ATTEND OUR LOCAL BOYS AND GIRLS CLUB UTILIZING THE BOTVIN LIFE SKILLS CURRICULUM. THIS EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUM FOCUSES ON HEALTHY DECISION MAKING, MANAGING STRESS, AND INFORMATION ON THE HARMFUL EFFECTS OF SUBSTANCES. OUR FINAL OBJECTIVE WOULD BE TO PARTNER WITH OUR LOCAL CHILDREN’S DIVISION TO OFFER PARENTING CLASSES TO PARENTS IDENTIFIED BY THE ORGANIZATION AS NEEDING ADDITIONAL SKILLS AND SUPPORT.

DRUG FREE COMMUNITY GRANT FOR ADAIR COUNTY OPIOID COALITION - THE ADAIR COUNTY OPIOID COALITION WAS CREATED TO HELP PROVIDE EDUCATION AND REDUCE THE ABUSE OF OPIOID USE IN ADAIR COUNTY AS WELL AS SURROUNDING COUNTIES REACHING ABOUT 30,000 INDIVIDUALS IN OUR RURAL TOWNS. THE COALITION CONSISTS OF SEVERAL DIFFERENT STAKEHOLDERS IN ADAIR COUNTY AND NOW HAS INTEGRATED STAKEHOLDERS IN SCHUYLER COUNTY. BY USING THE 3 P’S OF PUBLIC HEALTH THE COALITION CAN PREVENT SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH, PROMOTE EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES AND INTERVENTIONS, AND PROTECT OUR COMMUNITIES. BY USING EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES AND INTERVENTIONS AS WELL AS COLLABORATING WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS THE COALITION CAN AND WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE EDUCATION TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND IN SCHOOL SETTINGS. HOLDING ANNUAL DRUG EDUCATION SUMMITS AND HIGH SCHOOL SYMPOSIUMS WILL PROVIDE UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION AND HELP KEEP THE PUBLIC INFORMED. THESE PROMISING-PRACTICE INTERVENTIONS WILL ALSO HELP INTEGRATE MESSAGING IN BOTH PARENTS AND STUDENTS BY SIMULTANEOUSLY HAPPENING IN THE SAME TIME FRAME. IT IS THE COALITION'S HOPE THAT BY 2024 THERE WILL BE A REDUCTION IN YOUTH ALCOHOL, OPIOID, AND MARIJUANA USE AND THAT THE COALITION WILL SEE AN INCREASE IN COALITION MEMBERSHIP.

DOUGLAS COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM - THE DOUGLAS COUNTY DRUG PREVENTION COALITION, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NORTHWEST WISCONSIN COMMUNITY SERVICES AGENCY, RESPECTFULLY SUBMITS THE ATTACHED PROPOSAL TO THE CDC / NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL’S NOFO: DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM – NEW. THE PROPOSED FIVE-YEAR PROJECT, CALLED THE DOUGLAS COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM, HAS A TARGET PERIOD OF SEPTEMBER 30, 2022, TO SEPTEMBER 29, 2027. THE REQUESTED GRANT WILL BUILD THE COALITION’S CAPACITY TO ADDRESS THE PROBLEM OF YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, NICOTINE, AND CANNABIS IN DOUGLAS COUNTY.      DOUGLAS COUNTY IS LOCATED IN NORTHWEST WISCONSIN. AT 1,300 SQUARE MILES IN SIZE, IT’S THE FOURTH-LARGEST COUNTY IN WISCONSIN (OUT OF 72 COUNTIES). IT HAS A POPULATION OF APPROXIMATELY 44,295, WHICH RANKS 34TH. THE COUNTY SEAT IS SUPERIOR, WHICH HAS A POPULATION OF 26,223 AND IS PART OF THE DULUTH(MN)/SUPERIOR METROPOLITAN STATISTICAL AREA. THERE ARE MANY SMALLER TOWNS IN DOUGLAS COUNTY, BUT THE MAJORITY OF THE COUNTY IS HIGHLY RURAL AND SPARSELY POPULATED.      DOUGLAS COUNTY IS BORDERED BY LAKE SUPERIOR TO THE NORTH AND INCLUDES 280,000 ACRES OF FORESTLAND, MORE THAN ANY OTHER COUNTY IN THE STATE. THE COUNTY ALSO INCLUDES LAKE NEBAGAMON, A MAJOR RECREATIONAL RESOURCE IN THE REGION, AS WELL AS MANY SMALLER LAKES. THE HIGH QUALITY OF NATURAL RESOURCES IN DOUGLAS COUNTY MAKE IT A POPULAR DESTINATION FOR SECOND HOMEOWNERS AND TOURISTS.      THE DOUGLAS COUNTY DRUG PREVENTION COALITION WILL FOCUS ON PREVENTING AND REDUCING YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, NICOTINE, AND CANNABIS IN THE TWO PRIMARY SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN DOUGLAS COUNTY. SUPERIOR SCHOOL DISTRICT IS LOCATED IN SUPERIOR AND SERVES 4,073 K-12 STUDENTS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY FOCUS ON STUDENTS ATTENDING SUPERIOR MIDDLE SCHOOL AND SUPERIOR HIGH SCHOOL. COMBINED, THESE TWO SCHOOLS HAVE A STUDENT POPULATION OF 2,242. THE SECOND PRIMARY SCHOOL DISTRICT IN DOUGLAS COUNTY IS THE SCHOOL DISTRICT OF MAPLE, WHICH SERVES 1,282 K-12 STUDENTS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY FOCUS ON MAPLE STUDENTS ATTENDING NORTHWESTERN MIDDLE SCHOOL AND NORTHWESTERN HIGH SCHOOL. THESE TWO SCHOOLS HAVE A STUDENT POPULATION OF 679.      IN REGARD TO LOCAL CONDITIONS, DOUGLAS COUNTY EXHIBITS HIGHER THAN AVERAGE RATES OF UNEMPLOYMENT, POVERTY, AND MULTIPLE OTHER SOCIAL ISSUES. WITHIN A CONTEXT IN WHICH MANY PEOPLE COME AND GO BECAUSE OF THE FORESTS, LAKES, AND TOURISM ECONOMY OF DOUGLAS COUNTY, THESE CONDITIONS COMBINE TO CREATE A CULTURE IN WHICH ADULT SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE IS HIGHLY INGRAINED. THIS EXACERBATES CONDITIONS OF POVERTY AND UNEMPLOYMENT AND TAKES A TOLL ON LOCAL YOUTH, BOTH IN TERMS OF QUALITY OF LIFE AND EARLY EXPOSURE TO SUBSTANCE USE.      THE DOUGLAS COUNTY DRUG PREVENTION COALITION FORMED IN 2011 (UNDER A DIFFERENT NAME) IN RESPONSE TO A COMMUNITY SURVEY THAT REVEALED MULTI-LAYERED CONDITIONS AND RISK FACTORS IN REGARD TO SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE IN THE COUNTY. THE ORIGINAL GROUP OF VOLUNTEERS CONSISTED OF 18 PEOPLE, MANY OF WHOM ARE STILL INVOLVED. THE COALITION HAS NEVER EMPLOYED A COORDINATOR AND CONTINUES TO EXIST BECAUSE OF VOLUNTEERS AND A FEW SMALL GRANTS. THE COALITION IS SEEKING NEW FUNDING TO BUILD ON THE FOUNDATION IT HAS BUILT AND INCREASE IMPACT ON YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL, NICOTINE, AND CANNABIS. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, THE COALITION WILL UTILIZE DFC GRANT FUNDS TO STRENGTHEN AND IMPLEMENT A COLLECTIVE-IMPACT MODEL IN DOUGLAS COUNTY. THE MODEL WILL INCLUDE COMMUNITY-LEVEL INTERVENTIONS THAT ARE COMPREHENSIVE, INTEGRATED, AND EVIDENCE-BASED IN NATURE. ALL WORK WILL BE BASED ON THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE AND SAMHSA’S STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK. SELECTED PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES WILL INCLUDE BOTH SCHOOL-BASED PREVENTION EFFORTS AND FAMILY, COMMUNITY, MEDIA, AND POLICY INITIATIVES. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO BRING ABOUT TRANSFORMATIVE CHANGE, LEADING TO A STRONGER CULTURE OF PREVENTION AND REDUCED YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE IN DOUGLAS COUNTY

IRON COUNTY HEALTH COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT - THE MISSION STATEMENT OF IRON COUNTY HEALTH COALITION IS "BY WORKING TOGETHER WITH ALL MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY, THE IRON COUNTY HEALTH COALITION IS COMMITTED TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND ALTERNATIVE ACTIVITIES TO ESTABLISH AWARENESS OF THE NEED FOR PREVENTION, INTERVENTION AND TREATMENT OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE, PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH." IRON COUNTY HEALTH COALITION WILL WORK TO REDUCE YOUTH ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE USE AND OVER TIME REDUCE ADULT ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE ABUSE IN IRON COUNTY, MISSOURI. THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE YOUTH AND ADULTS IN ALL MUNICIPALITIES AND UNICORPORATED AREAS IN IRON COUNTY. OBJECTIVES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF THE COALITION, 2) DEVELOP COALITION ACTION COMMITTEES, 3) INCREASE YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN THE COALITION, 4) STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF THE COALITION TO MAKE COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE, 5) DELIVER EVIDENCE-BASED EDUCATION TO YOUTH AND FAMILIES, 6) DELIVER RESPONSIBLE VENDOR TRAINING TO ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO MERCHANTS, AND 7) IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS. ACTIVITIES WILL BE EVALUATED, INFORMING THE COALITION OF CHANGES AND ADJUSTMENTS THAT ARE NECESSARY TO CONTINUE REACHING THE GOALS OF THE COALITION AND THE DFC GOALS TO INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.

UTE MOUNTAIN UTE TRIBE GROWING HEALTHY UTE DRUG FREE COMMUNITY COALITION - THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ESCALATED AND AMPLIFIED SUBSTANCE USE CHALLENGES IN THE UMUT COMMUNITY, PLACING ALL AT HEIGHTENED RISK BUT ASKING YOUTH TO SHOULDER A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN. BARRED FROM SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY SUPPORTS IN AN EFFORT TO “STOP THE SPREAD,” AND KEPT IN HOMES WHERE BETWEEN 45% AND 55% OF ADULT UTE TRIBAL MEMBERS BATTLE SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER, YOUNG PEOPLE BEGAN TO EXPERIMENT WITH ILLICIT SUBSTANCES. IT IS CRUCIAL THAT THE GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION EMBARKS URGENTLY TO RESTART PAUSED EFFORTS RELATED TO PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION. THE UTE MOUNTAIN UTE TRIBAL GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION (GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION) HAS BEEN WORKING TO IMPROVE PROTECTIONS AND SERVICES FOR YOUTH SINCE 2014. DEDICATED TO THE MISSION OF PREVENTING AND REDUCING SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH UP TO 18 YEARS OF AGE, AND OVER TIME, REDUCING SUBSTANCE ABUSE AMONG ADULTS, BY ADDRESSING THE RISK FACTORS THAT INCREASE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND PROMOTING THE FACTORS THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE, THE EFFORTS OF THE GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION HAVE NEVER BEEN MORE IMPORTANT. THE GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION SEEKS TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS AND ORGANIZATIONS TO SUSTAINABLY ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE; AND TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH AND OVER TIME, AMONG ADULTS – TARGETING ALCOHOL AND METHAMPHETAMINE. PROPOSED EFFORTS EMBRACE THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY-LEVE CHANGE, AND WILL BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY TO ADDRESS LOCAL CHALLENGES, LEVERAGING CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE OUTREACH EFFORTS, EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION PROGRAMMING, A “SURVIVORS SUPPORT GROUP” OPTION FOR YOUTH TO PROMOTE HEALING, EVIDENCE-BASED PARENTING SUPPORT, AND “YOUTH RESILIENCY PROGRAMMING” THAT BUILDS HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS AND STRENGTHENS CULTURAL CONNECTIONS TO MEASURABLY LOWER THE IMPACT OF SUBSTANCE USE ON THE UTE MOUNTAIN UTE TRIBE YOUTH. ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES WILL BE MADE BY ADDING YOUTH-DESIGNED PREVENTION POSTERS AND UTE/ENGLISH SIGNAGE TO THE OUTSIDE OF BUILDINGS, HALLWAYS OF TRIBAL BUILDINGS, AND LOT AREAS WHERE YOUTH CONGREGATE TO USE SUBSTANCES, SERVING AS A VISUAL REMINDER OF UTE CULTURAL COMMUNITY EXPECTATIONS OF SUBSTANCE-FREE YOUTH AND STRENGTHEN PROTECTIONS FOR YOUTH. IN DIRECT ALIGNMENT WITH DFC PRIORITIES, GROWING HEALTHY UTE DFC COALITION SEEKS TO: 1. LIMIT YOUTH ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES. 2. CHANGE THE CULTURE AND CONTEXT WITHIN WHICH DECISIONS ABOUT SUBSTANCE USE ARE MADE. 3. SHIFT THE CONSEQUENCES ASSOCIATED WITH YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. 4. ADDRESS ISSUES RELATED TO HEALTH DISPARITIES AND PROMOTE HEALTH EQUITY MEASURABLE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: OBJECTIVE 1: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PARTNERS IN THE DRUG FREE COALITION BY 15%, TO BE MEASURED BY ATTENDANCE ROSTERS. OBJECTIVE 2: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, REDUCE BY 10% CURRENT USE OF ALCOHOL (USE WITHIN 30 DAYS) AMONG YOUTH GRADES 6-12 TO BE MEASURED BY PRE- POST-PAST 30-DAY USE SURVEYS. OBJECTIVE 3: BY SEPTEMBER 29, 2023, REDUCE BY 10% CURRENT USE OF METHAMPHETAMINE (USE WITHIN 30 DAYS) AMONG YOUTH GRADES 6-12 TO BE MEASURED BY PRE- POST-PAST 30-DAY USE SURVEYS.

PREVENTING THE INITIATION AND USE OF MARIJUANA AND VAPING BY BUILDING CAPACITY AND CHANGING SYSTEMS THAT ADDRESS ACES, TRAUMA AND CONNECTEDNESS IN SKOWHEGAN AREA YOUTH - THE SKOWHEGAN REACH COALITION (REACH) IS A DIVERSE COMMITTEE OF SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS BASED IN SKOWHEGAN, MAINE AND SERVES THE COMMUNITIES SERVED BY MAINE SCHOOL ADMINISTRATIVE DISTRICT # 54. THESE COMMUNITIES INCLUDE CANAAN, CORNVILLE, MERCER, NORRIDGEWOCK, SKOWHEGAN, AND SMITHFIELD. REACH’S GOAL OF REDUCING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE WILL FOCUS ON REDUCING THE PREVALENCE OF MARIJUANA USE AND VAPING IN MSAD #54, PARTICULARLY SKOWHEGAN AREA MIDDLE SCHOOL AND SKOWHEGAN AREA HIGH SCHOOL. TO PREVENT THE INITIATION OF AND USE OF SUBSTANCES AMONG YOUTH, REACH WILL BUILD CAPACITY AND CHANGE SYSTEMS THAT ADDRESS ACES, TRAUMA, AND SCHOOL/COMMUNITY CONNECTEDNESS IN MSAD #54 STUDENTS; ALL KEY FACTORS FOR YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. REACH WILL FOCUS ON DATA-DRIVEN STRATEGIES THAT MITIGATE RISK FACTORS AND PROMOTE PROTECTIVE FACTORS. EMPHASIS WILL BE MADE TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE RATES BY ADDRESSING THE FOLLOWING: YOUTH ENGAGEMENT—REACH WILL FACILITATE SYSTEMS CHANGE AND PROVIDE TRAINING TO ADULTS AT SCHOOL AND IN THE COMMUNITY THAT FOSTER PRACTICES THAT IMPROVE ADULT/YOUTH RELATIONSHIPS.  REACH WILL PROMOTE CONNECTIONS FOR YOUTH AND FAMILIES FROM THE SCHOOL DISTRICT TO COMMUNITY-BASED RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES. ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES/TRAUMA—REACH WILL PROVIDE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO DEVELOP TRAUMA-INFORMED PRACTICES THROUGHOUT THE MSAD #54 DISTRICT THAT PROMOTE HEALTHY NEURODEVELOPMENT AND HEALING WITH THE GOAL OF BECOMING A TRAUMA-INFORMED ORGANIZATION. SOCIAL EMOTIONAL LEARNING (SEL) – REACH WILL SEEK TO IMPLEMENT A DISTRICT-WIDE SOCIAL EMOTIONAL LEARNING CURRICULUM TO IMPROVE SELF-AWARENESS, SELF-MANAGEMENT, SOCIAL AWARENESS, RELATIONSHIP SKILLS AND RESPONSIBLE DECISION-MAKING. EARLY INTERVENTIONS THAT TARGET THESE FIVE COMPETENCIES CAN SHIFT TRAJECTORIES AWAY FROM PROBLEM BEHAVIORS SUCH AS SUBSTANCE MISUSE, AND TOWARDS POSITIVE OUTCOMES. SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENT—REACH INCREASE POSITIVE MESSAGING, PROMOTE INCLUSION, AND PROVIDE SUPPORT TO YOUTH AND ADULTS IMPROVE RELATIONSHIPS BOTH IN THE SCHOOLS AND IN THE COMMUNITY. YOUTH EMPOWERMENT & VOICE- REACH WILL INCLUDE STUDENTS IN DECISION MAKING BY ESTABLISHING A YOUTH ADVISORY BOARD AND HAVING ACTIVE YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN REACH COALITION MEETINGS. THEIR EXPERTISE, PERSPECTIVE, AND IDEAS WILL INFORM COALITION WORK.

YOUTH RESILIENCY COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES PROGRAM - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY THE YOUTH RESILIENCY COALITION (YRC) OF SOUTHERN MAINE IS A NEW COALITION COVERING AND MADE UP OF MEMBERS AND PARTNERS IN FOUR SMALL RURAL COMMUNITIES WITH A COMBINED POPULATION OF 36,000: KITTERY, ELIOT, SOUTH BERWICK AND YORK. THESE COMMUNITIES AND THEIR SCHOOL DISTRICTS, KITTERY, MARSHWOOD AND YORK, HAVE COMBINED TO STRENGTHEN THEIR EFFORTS TO SUPPORT AND IMPROVE YOUTH WELLNESS AND RESILIENCY AND PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. THE COALITION’S MEMBERSHIP REPRESENTS THE TWELVE SECTORS AND IS DRAWN FROM THREE EXPERIENCED COLLABORATIVE GROUPS, YORKWISE, THE MARSHWOOD WELLNESS COMMITTEE, AND THE KITTERY YOUTH COUNCIL. THE CHALLENGES AND TRAGEDIES OF THE PAST YEAR PLUS HAVE STRENGTHENED THE YRC’S  RESOLVE TO REDUCE YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE AS WELL AS TO PREVENT MORE SUICIDES RELATED TO UNATTENDED MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES AND LACK OF RESILIENCY IN FAMILIES. THE YOUTH RESILIENCY COALITION MISSION IS “TO BUILD RESILIENCY AMONG OUR YOUTH AND CARING ADULTS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT UNHEALTHY OUTCOMES FROM DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE AND POOR MENTAL HEALTH.” WE WILL DO THIS BY IMPROVING GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS AND MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS AND REDUCING THE STIGMA ATTACHED TO BOTH. THE YRC WILL COLLABORATE WITH AND LEARN FROM LOCAL, STATEWIDE AND NATIONAL GROUPS, ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS TO IMPROVE CAPACITY FOR PREVENTION THEREBY IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF OUR YOUTH, ESPECIALLY THOSE AT HIGHEST RISK INCLUDING OUR MUCH UNDERSERVED LGBT YOUTH. THE YOUTH RESILIENCY COALITION WILL WORK TO REDUCE YOUTH MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL USE RATES, SOME OF THE HIGHEST IN MAINE. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS IN PART BY -	EMPOWERING YOUTH SO THEY FEEL LIKE THEY MATTER; -	EDUCATING ADULTS TO BE THE HELP AND SUPPORT OUR YOUTH DESERVE; AND, -	REDUCING ACCESS TO LEGAL DRUGS AT OVER 125 ALCOHOL OUTLETS AND NEARLY 30 RETAIL MARIJUANA OUTLETS. OUR GOAL IS TO CHANGE THE ENVIRONMENT IN OUR FOUR SMALL TOWNS SO THAT HEALTHY RESILIENT YOUTH, NOT THE ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA INDUSTRIES, DEFINE US.

SOMERS COMES TOGETHER COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT - THE TOWN OF SOMERS, ON BEHALF OF THE SOMERS COMES TOGETHER (SCT) COALITION, SEEKS TO ADDRESS AND ULTIMATELY PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE THROUGH THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT, FOCUSING ON PREVENTION OF YOUTH ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA USE IN SOMERS, CONNECTICUT. SOMERS, LOCATED IN TOLLAND COUNTY, IS A COMMUNITY WITH A POPULATION OF 11,0005 WITH A LONG HISTORY AS AN AGRICULTURAL AND MILL COMMUNITY. THERE IS A LACK OF AVAILABLE RESOURCES FOR THE RESIDENTS OF SOMERS, INCLUDING NO PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION RESULTING IN INEQUITABLE ACCESS TO CARE FOR THOSE WHO DO NOT HAVE THEIR OWN TRANSPORTATION. ALMOST A QUARTER OF SOMERS FAMILIES ARE FACING ECONOMIC DIFFICULTIES THAT LEADS TO INCREASED STRESS AND RISK FACTORS IN THE HOME. A PRIMARY POPULATION OF FOCUS IN THE COMMUNITY IS THE “SOMERSVILLE” SECTION OF TOWN, WHERE THERE IS A HIGH CONCENTRATION OF POVERTY. THIS SECTION OF TOWN IS WHERE THE OLD MILLS ARE LOCATED THAT WAS ONCE TEMPORARY HOUSING FOR WORKERS PICKING TOBACCO IN THE FIELDS. THE COMMUNITY HAS VERY LIMITED RESOURCES TO SUPPORT POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND HAS RELIED ON VERY LITTLE FUNDING AND NO DEDICATED STAFFING TO OVERSEE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONCERTED, EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. DUE TO THESE LIMITED RESOURCES AND MINIMAL SERVICES FOR YOUTH OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL, THERE IS AN INCREASED RISK OF STUDENTS USING SUBSTANCES WITH PEERS DURING THEIR UNOCCUPIED TIME. YOUTH MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL USE ARE THE PRIMARY SUBSTANCES OF CONCERN IN SOMERS. STUDENT SUBSTANCE USE DATA FROM THE 2017 ERASE STUDENT SURVEY, SHOWS THAT PAST 30-DAY ALCOHOL USE WAS HIGHER (17.9%) IN SOMERS THAN THE REGIONAL RATE (15.6%). THIS REMAINS TRUE FOR PAST-MONTH BINGE DRINKING RATES (10.2%, 8.2% RESPECTIVELY). STUDENTS GRADE 9-12 MOST FREQUENTLY RESPONDED THAT IT IS “VERY” OR “SORT OF” EASY TO OBTAIN ALCOHOL (68.1%) AND MARIJUANA (58.5%). THERE ARE MARIJUANA DISPENSARIES LOCATED RIGHT OVER THE BORDER FROM THE TOWN OF SOMERS INTO MASSACHUSETTS, AS CLOSE AS 14 MILES AWAY. DURING THE CASE INVESTIGATIONS OF YOUTH CAUGHT WITH MARIJUANA, THE JUVENILE REVIEW BOARD DISCOVERED THAT THE MARIJUANA IS FREQUENTLY OBTAINED FROM A DISPENSARY EITHER FROM A DEALER OR THE YOUTH’S PARENTS. EASE OF ACCESS TO MARIJUANA IS ALREADY A RISK FACTOR THAT NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED IN SOMERS, WHICH WILL ONLY BE HEIGHTENED FURTHER AS CONNECTICUT ROLLS OUT ITS OWN RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARIES EXPECTED LATER THIS YEAR. MENTAL HEALTH TRANSPORTS HAVE MOSTLY INCREASED EACH YEAR ACROSS THE AGE GROUPS. OVERDOSE TRANSPORTS INCREASED AMONGST TEENS AND YOUNG ADULTS IN 2020, POSSIBLY DUE TO ISOLATION AND STRESS BROUGHT ON BY THE PANDEMIC. THE MISSION OF SCT IS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH AND ADULTS BY COLLABORATING WITH THE SOMERS COMMUNITY TO INCREASE AWARENESS, PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND SUPPORT YOUTH AND ADULTS TO ENGAGE IN HEALTHY ACTIVITIES. WITH THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES FUNDING, SCT WILL USE THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK TO COLLABORATE WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS IN THE COMMUNITY TO IMPLEMENT PREVENTION STRATEGIES. SCT WILL FOCUS ITS OBJECTIVES ON REDUCING THE PAST 30-DAY USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA AS EVIDENCED ON ITS BI-ANNUAL STUDENT USE SURVEY. THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE ITS GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING THESE STRATEGIES: 1) BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF THE SOMERS COMES TOGETHER COALITION TO BE INCLUSIVE OF ALL SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY, 2) DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGNS TARGETING YOUTH AND THEIR PARENTS TO ADDRESS SOCIAL NORMS ABOUT SUBSTANCE USE, 3) ENHANCE THE SKILLS OF PARENTS IN SOMERS TO SUPPORT SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION AND IMPROVE PROTECTIVE FACTORS, 4) PROVIDE SUPPORTIVE ACTIVITIES FOR YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES TO ENGAGE IN HEALTHY ALTERNATIVES, 5) IMPLEMENT ALCOHOL COMPLIANCE CHECKS AT RETAILS IN SOMERS TO REDUCE YOUTH ACCESS TO ALCOHOL, AND 6) WORK WITH TOWN OFFICIALS TO MODIFY POLICIES TO ENHANCE PROTECTION AGAINST YOUTH MARIJUANA USE.

HEADSUP DFC - THE HEADSUP DFC WAS AWARDED A FY 2022 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $625,000 BY THE WHITE HOUSE OFFICE OF NATIONAL DRUG CONTROL POLICY, IN COOPERATION WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION.  THE COALITION SERVES WARDS 5, 7 & 8 IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, A COMMUNITY OF 160,275.  THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE ITS GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING THESE STRATEGIES: SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS, PREVENTION MESSAGING, PEER LEADERSHIP, AND CAPACITY BUILDING TO REDUCE YOUTH MARIJUANA USE AND ALCOHOL.

RIDE WITH PRIDE: A POSITIVE BEHAVIOR PROGRAM TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND PROMOTE SAFE CHOICES. - RIDE WITH PRIDE DFC PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY  THROUGH THE MAKING OF MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIPS, THE RIDE WITH PRIDE (RWP) COALITION AIMS TO EMPOWER POSITIVE AND SAFE CHOICES AMONG YOUTH. EDUCATION AND OTHER PREVENTION ACTIVITIES WILL ENABLE INFORMED CHOICES THAT AVOID THE DANGERS OF ALCOHOL, E-CIGARETTES, AND OTHER DANGEROUS DRUGS. OVER TIME, A POSITIVE CULTURE WILL DEVELOP IN ORDER TO MAKE OUR COMMUNITY RESILIENT.  NSPD IS SEEKING $125,000 OF YEARLY DFC FUNDING TO PARTIALLY FUND A RWP PROJECT COORDINATOR, FUND SUPPLIES, AND EVALUATE CURRENT EFFORTS TO BETTER REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE WITHIN MUSKEGON COUNTY. WE KNOW THAT EVERY BEHAVIOR HAS A MESSAGE OR NEED BEHIND IT. OUR STUDENTS NEED TO BE GUIDED TOWARD POSITIVE BEHAVIORS AND SAFE CHOICES. THE RWP COALITION COMBINES LAW ENFORCEMENT, EDUCATORS, BUSINESS LEADERS, AND OTHER REPRESENTATIVES FROM ALL SECTORS OF SOCIETY FOR ONE THING, OUR YOUTH.  THIS COMMON GOAL, THIS UNIFIED APPROACH, THIS LIFELONG IMPACT, IS DESIGNED TO CONNECT WITH STUDENTS K-12. STUDENTS BEGIN THE YEAR (CURRENTLY IN NINE SCHOOL DISTRICTS THROUGHOUT MUSKEGON COUNTY) WITH A RWP KICK-OFF EVENT. THEY SIGN A BASIC “POSITIVE BEHAVIOR AND SAFE DRIVING PLEDGE” THAT ENCOURAGES ABIDING BY THEIR SCHOOL’S POSITIVE BEHAVIOR MATRIX, ABSTAIN FROM ALCOHOL AND OTHER DRUG USE, AND TRAVEL SAFELY ON THE ROADS (DRIVING OR SIMPLY WEARING A BIKE HELMET FOR YOUNGER STUDENTS).  THROUGHOUT THE SCHOOL YEAR, REGULAR PREVENTATIVE EVENTS ARE CARRIED OUT BY POLICE, STAFF, AND VOLUNTEERS TO TEACH STUDENTS ABOUT THE DANGERS OF SUBSTANCE USE AND PROMOTE THE BENEFITS OF SUBSTANCE ABSTINENCE. ADDITIONALLY, MATERIALS ARE DISTRIBUTED (LIKE BOOKS, CARTOONS, AND OTHER MEDIA) THAT CAN HELP REINFORCE THESE LESSONS. THE YEAR IS THEN CAPPED OFF BY MAJOR SCHOOL WIDE ASSEMBLIES. POSITIVE BEHAVIOR THROUGHOUT THE YEAR IS RECOGNIZED AND AT THE HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL, ONE LUCKY WINNER IN EACH BUILDING IS REWARDED WITH A NEARLY NEW CAR. THIS ELECTRIC ATMOSPHERE CAN BE FELT ALL YEAR LONG AND THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY.  THESE EFFORTS WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE WITHOUT OUR ROBUST COLLABORATION AND UNIFYING EFFORTS. IF FORTUNATE ENOUGH TO RECEIVE DFC FUNDING, IT IS HOPED THAT WE WILL BE BETTER PREPARED TO COUNTERACT THE NEGATIVE IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WHICH HAS HAD RIPPLE EFFECTS IN THE REALMS OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND DANGEROUS LIFE CHOICES.

HOUSTON RECOVERY INITIATIVE/DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES TARGETING SPRING BRANCH - THE MISSION OF THE HOUSTON RECOVERY INITIATIVE IS TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ON YOUTH PREVENTION, RECOVERY FOR YOUTH AND ADULTS, AND BROADEN THE RECOVERY SUPPORT NETWORK FOR ADULTS AND CHILDREN AT RISK, INDIVIDUALS WITH SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS, AND THEIR FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES IN THE GREATER HOUSTON AREA. THIS COMBINATION PROJECT WITH THE HOUSTON RECOVERY INITIATION AND THE CDC “DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES” GRANT WILL FOCUS ON THE SPRING BRANCH AREA OF HOUSTON, TEXAS IN AN EFFORT TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH.  THE AREA COLLECTIVELY KNOWN AS “SPRING BRANCH” RESIDES WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF HOUSTON, TEXAS WITHIN HARRIS COUNTY.  ACCORDING TO THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICES VITAL STATISTICS, HARRIS COUNTY ACCOUNTS FOR NEARLY 30% OF ALL THE OVERDOSES FOR THE ENTIRE STATE OF TEXAS.  SPRING BRANCH INCLUDES 2 MAJOR ZIP CODES -- 77080 AND 77055 – AND IS CENTRALLY LOCATED IN THE WEST SIDE OF HOUSTON.  SPRING BRANCH IS BORDERED ON EVERY SIDE BY A MAJOR HIGHWAY – I-10, BELTWAY 8, HWY 290, AND THE 610 LOOP.  SPRING BRANCH IS A LARGELY IMMIGRANT POPULATION WITH MAJORITY HISPANIC AND ASIAN IMMIGRANTS LEADS TO SIGNIFICANT LINGUISTIC ISOLATION.  THE PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY CURRENT USE AND PERCEPTION ISSUES IN SPRING BRANCH. THIS QUESTIONNAIRE WILL FOCUS ON ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, MARIJUANA (AS REQUIRED BY DFC), PRESCRIPTION PILLS (DUE TO ACCESSIBILITY), "NON-PRESCRIPTION OPIOID CONTAINING MEDICATIONS" AND METHAMPHETAMINE (DUE TO THEIR PREVALENCE IN THE HOUSTON AREA).  ACCORDING VITAL STATISTICS AT THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICES, HARRIS COUNTY -- WHICH HOUSES THE CITY OF HOUSTON AND THE SPRING BRANCH AREA – CONTRIBUTES MORE THAN 30% OF THE OVERDOSES FOR THE ENTIRE STATE OF TEXAS.  DEMONSTRATING HOW GREAT THE NEED FOR YOUTH SERVICES, HOUSTON IS THE ONLY CITY IN THE US THAT HAS TWO SOBER HIGH SCHOOLS – FORTIS ACADEMY IN NORTHEAST HOUSTON, AND ARCHWAY ACADEMY IN CENTRAL HOUSTON WHICH IS THE LARGEST SOBER HIGH SCHOOL IN THE NATION.  HOWEVER, WHILE FORTIS ACADEMY IS PAID FOR BY THE CITY OF HOUSTON, THE FACILITY IS 30 MINUTES AWAY VIA A TOLL ROAD AND WOULD LIKELY NOT BE AN OPTION FOR A COMMUNITY THAT RELIES ON WALKING OR PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION TO GET TO WORK. ARCHWAY ACADEMY ALSO REQUIRES A 30 MINUTE DRIVE WHICH IS A BARRIER FOR THOSE WITH TRANSPORTATION ISSUES. ADDITIONALLY, WHILE THE COST OF TUITION IS OFFSET BY DONATIONS, TUITION IS $1000/MONTH WHICH IS PAID FOR BY THE FAMILY. THIS IS DEFINITELY A BARRIER FOR A COMMUNITY WITH A MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME OF $45,182 COMPARED TO HARRIS COUNTY $57,791.  WHEN COMPARED TO RESIDENTS OF THE CITY OF HOUSTON, HARRIS COUNTY, OR THE UNITED STATES, INDIVIDUALS LIVING IN THE SPRING BRANCH AREA ARE MORE LIKELY TO LACK HEALTH INSURANCE, GET ROUTINE CHECKUPS (INCLUDING CERVICAL AND COLON CANCER SCREENINGS AND DENTAL CARE), HAVE DIABETES, COPD, OR BE 65+ WITH TOTAL TOOTH LOSS.  THEY ARE MORE LIKELY TO BE LIVING IN POVERTY, ON SNAP (FOOD STAMPS), SPEND MORE THAN 30% OF THEIR INCOME ON RENT, AND HAVE A MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME OF $45,182 WHICH DRASTICALLY DIFFERS FROM HARRIS COUNTY ($57,791). SPRING BRANCH FAMILIES ARE ALMOST TWICE AS LIKELY AS HOUSTON FAMILIES TO BE LIVING IN LINGUISTIC ISOLATION OWING IN A LARGE PART TO THE IMMIGRANT POPULATION. THEY ARE ALSO MORE LIKELY TO LIVE IN AN APARTMENT VERSUS THEIR OWN HOME, LESS LIKELY TO BE EMPLOYED IF THEY ARE FEMALE, AND HAVE HIGHER REPORTS OF POOR MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH.  MULTIPLE SURVEYS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE AT EACH HRI/DFC ACTIVITY, BOTH TO YOUTH WHO HAVE A PARENT/LEGAL GUARDIAN PRESENT, AND A SEPARATE SURVEY FOR PARENTS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND BUSINESS OWNERS. RESULTS OF THE SURVEYS WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO SECTOR REPRESENTATIVES AND DISCUSSED AT COMMUNITY FORUM MEETINGS EVERY 3 MONTHS. THE WORK OF IDENTIFYING AND RECRUITING PARTICIPATING STAKEHOLDER SITES TO ALLOW HRI/DFC EVIDENCE-BASED PRESENTATIONS WILL BE ONGOING.

THE GOAL OF THE TRACC COALITION IS TO STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG COALITION PARTNERS IN SUPPORT OF THE COMMUNITY'S EFFORTS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS SAFE DFC - THE EXCELSIOR SPRINGS SAFE (SUBSTANCE ABUSE FREE ENVIRONMENTS) COALITION SERVES EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, MISSOURI, A COMMUNITY OF 11,640.  THE COALITION’S GOALS FOR THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT ARE TWOFOLD: TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION AND TO PREVENT AND REDUCE LOCAL YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. SAFE WILL INCREASE ACTIVE REPRESENTATION AMONG ALL SECTORS BY 30% FROM 2021 TO 2026 , AS MEASURED THROUGH COALITION MEETING SIGN-IN SHEETS AND COALITION ROSTER. THIS CAPACITY-BUILDING WILL BE DONE THROUGH RECRUITING, TRAINING, ENGAGING, AND RETAINING MEMBERS AND THROUGH COMMUNICATING WITH ALL STAKEHOLDERS. BY 2026, EXCELSIOR SPRINGS 6TH-12TH GRADE STUDENTS’ PAST 30 DAY USE OF ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE WILL DECREASE BY AT LEAST 3 PERCENTAGE POINTS, AS MEASURED BY THE MISSOURI STUDENT SURVEY. THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE THESE GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING COMPLEMENTARY ENVIRONMENTAL AND INDIVIDUAL STRATEGIES FOLLOWING CADCA’S (COMMUNITY ANTI-DRUG COALITIONS OF AMERICA) 7 STRATEGIES OF COMMUNITY CHANGE. STRATEGIES WILL FOCUS ON DECREASING YOUTH ACCESS TO ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE,  INCREASING THE PERCEPTION OF HARM OF YOUTH ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE USE, AND DECREASING ADULT AND YOUTH ACCEPTANCE OF YOUTH ALCOHOL AND NICOTINE USE. IN ADDITION, THE COALITION WILL WORK TO INCREASE YOUTH PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND DECREASE YOUTH RISK FACTORS TO IMPACT COMMUNITY CULTURE AND ATTITUDES REGARDING YOUTH NICOTINE AND ALCOHOL USE. SAFE IMPLEMENTS THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK AND USES EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES WHEN CHOOSING STRATEGIES.  THE COALITION AND ITS EFFORTS ARE THOROUGHLY EVALUATED AND HAVE A HISTORY OF CONTRIBUTING TO MEASURABLE CHANGE AND HEALTHY OUTCOMES FOR YOUTH IN OUR COMMUNITY.

SPENCER COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS (FISCAL AGENT) AND SPENCER COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK (COALITION) WILL COLLABORATE TO LEAD COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE THAT WILL RESULT IN A DRUG-FREE COMMUNITY. - SPENCER COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS (APPLICANT/FISCAL AGENT) IN COLLABORATION WITH SPENCER COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK (COMMUNITY COALITION) WILL IMPLEMENT A SUBSTANCE ABUSE EDUCATION, PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION PROGRAM WITHIN THE SPENCER COUNTY DISTRICT.  THE GRANT FUNDS WILL FACILITATE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF SPECIFIC PROGRAMS TARGETED TO YOUTH AND FAMILIES IN ORDER TO REDUCE THE USE OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO (SPECIFICALLY E-CIGARETTES) AND MARIJUANA IN YOUTH THROUGH COMMUNITY LEVEL-CHANGE. OVER TIME, THIS WILL IMPACT SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE IN THE ADULT POPULATION OF THE COUNTY, AS WELL.  THIS WILL BE YEARS 6-10 OF A DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES GRANT.  SPENCER COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK ORIGINALLY HAD YEARS 1-5 WITH A DIFFERENT LEGAL APPLICANT IN 2004-2009.

DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAMS - LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 4 MILES NORTH OF CHICAGO IN A SUBURBAN SETTING, SITS THE TOWNSHIP OF NEW TRIER, WHICH INCLUDES THE VILLAGES OF WILMETTE, WINNETKA, KENILWORTH, NORTHFIELD, GLENCOE AND PARTS OF GLENVIEW AND NORTHBROOK.  ACCORDING TO THE MOST RECENT CENSUS, THE POPULATION OF NEW TRIER TOWNSHIP IS OVER 56,000.  OF THAT, 29% OF THE POPULATION IS 18 YEARS AND UNDER.  THE AVERAGE MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME IS $167, 801 AND 3.2% OF THE POPULATION FALLS BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL.  OVER 83% OF THE ADULT POPULATION HAS A BACHELOR?S DEGREE OR HIGHER.  THE BREAKDOWN OF THE DIFFERENT VILLAGES WITHIN THE TOWNSHIP IS AS FOLLOWS: THE VILLAGE OF WILMETTE IS APPROXIMATELY 50% OF THE TOWNSHIP WITH JUST OVER 27,000 RESIDENTS; THE VILLAGE OF WINNETKA HAS A POPULATIONS OF OVER 12,000 RESIDENTS;  THE VILLAGE OF GLENCOE HAS A POPULATION OF ALMOST 9,000 RESIDENTS; THE VILLAGE OF NORTHFIELD HAS OVER 5,500 RESIDENTS AND KENILWORTH HAS A POPULATION OF JUST OVER 2,500 RESIDENTS.   LASTLY, VERY SMALL PORTIONS OF GLENVIEW AND NORTHBROOK FALL WITHIN NEW TRIER TOWNSHIP BOUNDARIES.  NEW TRIER HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT 203, OFFERS A HIGH-LEVEL PUBLIC EDUCATION TO APPROXIMATELY 4,000 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS.  THE SCHOOL DISTRICT IS COMPRISED OF 2 HIGH SCHOOLS; NEW TRIER NORTHFIELD CAMPUS WHICH CONSISTS OF THE FRESHMEN CLASS.  THE OTHER CAMPUS, NEW TRIER WINNETKA, CONSISTS OF THE SOPHOMORE THROUGH SENIOR CLASSES.  ACCORDING TO THE ILLINOIS SCHOOL REPORT CARD FROM 2019, THE RACIAL AND ETHNIC BACKGROUND DATA FOR DISTRICT 203 AS A WHOLE WAS AS FOLLOWS: 79.7% WHITE, 0.6% BLACK, 4.9% HISPANIC, 9.4% ASIAN, 0.2% AMERICAN INDIAN, AND 5.1% MULTIRACIAL. 16% OF THE STUDENTS RECEIVED SERVICES THROUGH AN INDIVIDUALIZED EDUCATION PLAN AND 98% OF STUDENTS GRADUATE IN FOUR YEARS WITH OVER 90% OF STUDENTS MOVING ON TO POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION.  THERE ARE SIX MIDDLE SCHOOLS LOCATED WITHIN THE COMMUNITIES PROVIDING PUBLIC EDUCATION AND FEED INTO NEW TRIER HIGH SCHOOL.  THE LARGEST MIDDLE SCHOOL DISTRICT IS L OCATED IN WILMETTE WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR ABOUT 45% OF THE INCOMING CLASS TO NEW TRIER HIGH SCHOOL.  THERE ARE ALSO A NUMBER OF ELEMENTARY AND HIGH SCHOOL PRIVATE SCHOOLS LOCATED WITHIN THE TOWNSHIP.  THE MOST PROMINENT PRIVATE SCHOOLS ARE LOYOLA ACADEMY (9TH-12TH GRADE), NORTH SHORE COUNTRY DAY SCHOOL (PREK-12TH GRADE) AND REGINA DOMINICAN HIGH SCHOOL (9TH-12TH GRADE).  NEW TRIER HIGH SCHOOL HAS A VERY STRONG REPUTATION FOR OFFERING STUDENTS AN EXCELLENT, WELL-ROUNDED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE.  HOWEVER, THE HIGH ACADEMIC DEMANDS AND EXPECTATIONS FOR HIGH SCHOOL AND BEYOND HAS LED TO AN INCREASE IN THE OVERALL STRESS, ANXIETY AND DECREASED MENTAL HEALTH AMONG STUDENTS.  ONE-THIRD OF ALL NEW TRIER HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS REPORT RECEIVING PROFESSIONAL MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES IN THE PAST YEAR.  BASED ON STUDENT REPORTS, THE MENTAL HEALTH COMPONENT IS ONE OF THE MAIN CONTRIBUTING FACTORS IN SUBSTANCE USE AMONG TEENS IN THE TOWNSHIP.  STUDENTS ARE TURNING TO ALCOHOL AND OTHER SUBSTANCE TO COPE WITH THEIR MENTAL HEALTH NEEDS.  OTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTORS FOR USE ARE PERMISSIVE PARENTAL ATTITUDES TOWARDS YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND PERCEIVED SOCIAL NORMS WHICH DIRECTLY CORRELATE TO THE INCREASE IN USE OF DRUGS AND ALCOHOL IN THE COMMUNITY.THE NORTH SHORE COALITION FOR DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES AIMS TO BRING COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TOGETHER TO CREATE A COMMUNITY IN WHICH THE TEENS FEEL SUPPORTED IN THEIR MENTAL HEALTH NEEDS BY INCREASING THEIR POSITIVE COPING SKILLS TO DECREASE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  ALSO, CHANGING SOCIAL NORMS AND DECREASING THE ACCEPTANCE OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE TO HELP OUR TEENS MAKE THE CHOICE TO REMAIN SUBSTANCE FREE.  CHANGING THE CULTURE OF THE COMMUNITY IS KEY SO THAT BEING SUBSTANCE FREE IS THE NORM.

STENGTHEN THE CASS COUNTY (IN) SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION COALITION VIA DFC FUNDING - THE CASS COUNTY SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION COALITION, UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF YOUTH SERVICES ALLIANCE (YSA) AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS, WILL LAUNCH ITS CASS COUNTY DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) PROJECT BEGINNING DECEMBER 31, 2020, TO PROMOTE POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND FAMILY RESILIENCE IN THE TEN ZIP CODES THAT COMPRISE CASS COUNTY, INDIANA. THE PROJECT SERVES TO ADDRESS THE NEED FOR COLLABORATIVE, BILINGUAL PREVENTION INITIATIVES AND COMMUNITY-BASED ADVOCACY. THESE INITIATIVES WILL CREATE A SAFE SPACE FOR DIALOGUE ABOUT GENERATIONAL CYCLES OF SUBSTANCE USE AND ADDICTION ASSOCIATED WITH ADVERSE DEVELOPMENTAL FACTORS AND ENVIRONMENTAL INFLUENCES IN THE COUNTY. THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE EXISTING COALITION BY LINKING COMMUNITIES AS LARGE AS LOGANSPORT (POPULATION EST. 18,300) AND AS SMALL AS WALTON AND ONWARD (POPULATION EST. 1,100 AND 100, RESPECTIVELY) WITH RESOURCES SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO HELP YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES ADAPT TO STRESSORS AND CHANGE NORMS.  WITH A POPULATION OF NEARLY 40,000, AND A MEDIAN AGE OF 40, CASS COUNTY IS EXPERIENCING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL DECLINE INCREASINGLY TYPICAL OF AGING RURAL COMMUNITIES. THIRTEEN PERCENT OF RESIDENTS LIVE AT OR BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL  (STATSINDIANA, INDIANA INDEPTH PROFILE FROM 2010 U.S. CENSUS, 2018 U.S. BUREAU OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS). PER CAPITA INCOME IS AN ESTIMATED $38,788, AND NEARLY ONE OUT OF EVERY 5 CHILDREN UNDER AGE 18 LIVE IN POVERTY (THE ANNIE E. CASEY KIDS COUNT DATA CENTER, 2008-2017). THESE DATA ARE NOT ATYPICAL OF CENTRAL INDIANA, CASS COUNTY BEING ADJACENT TO SIX OTHER COUNTIES WHOSE BOUNDARIES ARE SIMILARLY SHAPED BY AGRIBUSINESS MONOCULTURE FARMING AND TRANSPORTATION ROUTES, BUT IN FACT CASS COUNTY?S DATA ARE ALARMINGLY PREDICTIVE OF RURAL COMMUNITIES STRUGGLING WITH SUBSTANCE MISUSE AS A HARBINGER OF CULTURAL SHIFTS. WHAT DOES MAKE CASS COUNTY DIFFERENT FROM OTHER RURAL COMMUNITIES IN INDIANA IS IMMIGRATION, PRIMARILY HISPANIC AND BURMESE, INFLUENCED BY TYSON FOODS AND OTHER MEAT PROCESSORS. THE COUNTY IS APPROXIMATELY 79% WHITE, 16% HISPANIC/LATINO, AND 5% AFRICAN AMERICAN AND ASIAN. AN ESTIMATED 23% IS UNDER 18 YEARS OLD AND 18% WHO ARE 65 AND OLDER. THE COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS FRAMEWORK PUTS CASS COUNTY IN THE BOTTOM 15TH PERCENTILE FOR HEALTH OUTCOMES IN INDIANA (COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS, 2020). AMONG ADULTS, EXCESSIVE ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION (16%) AND TOBACCO/NICOTINE USE (21%) EXCEED STATE AND NATIONAL RATES (WITH INDICATIONS OF UPWARD TRENDS SINCE 2013 FOR THE COUNTY). AN ESTIMATED 11.5 PERCENT OF WOMEN WHO ARE PREGNANT SMOKE (INDIANA STATE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH, 2019). NEARLY 30% OF SURVEYED ADULTS REPORTED THEIR LIVES HAVE BEEN NEGATIVELY INFLUENCED BY SUBSTANCE USE (PROFESSIONAL RESEARCH CONSULTANTS, CASS COUNTY COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSESSMENT, 2016). CASS COUNTY SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION COALITION HAS MADE IT A PRIORITY TO STAY INVOLVED IN EFFORTS THAT WORK ON BUILDING A BETTER, HEALTHIER, AND SAFER COMMUNITY. THE COALITION WAS FORMED IN 2016, BUT PREVENTION EFFORTS BEGAN LONG BEFORE THAT. YSA HAS BEEN RECEIVING DMHA FUNDING FOR NEARLY 22 YEARS, AND IN 2016 YOUTH SERVICES ALLIANCE (YSA) RECEIVED FEDERAL FUNDING FROM A PARTNERSHIP FOR SUCCESS (PFS) GRANT. YSA AND PARTNERS HAVE FOCUSED ON STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THE RISK, PROTECTIVE AND CONTRIBUTING FACTORS, NAMELY: TO IMPROVE THE PERCEPTION OF HARM FROM ALCOHOL USE, TO REDUCE SOCIAL AVAILABILITY OF ALCOHOL, TO REDUCE FAMILY CONFLICT, TO IMPROVE SCHOOL COMMITMENT, AND TO PROMOTE YOUTH RECOGNITION OF PROSOCIAL INVOLVEMENT.DFC FUNDS WILL ALLOW THE COALITION TO CONCENTRATE EFFORTS ON ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO/NICOTINE USE. AN ESTIMATED 6,500 YOUTH AND 7,000 HOUSEHOLDS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE CASS COUNTY DFC PROJECT AS A RESULT OF ANNUAL POPULATION-BASED SURVEYS; EDUCATION INITIATIVES ON RETAILER COMPLIANCE AND MEDIA LITERACY; TAILORED OUTREACH RECOGNIZING PREVENTION SUCCESSES TO CELEBRATE; AND YOUTH TRAINING OPPORTUNITIE

STURGIS POLICE ATHLETIC LEAGUES' (STURGIS PAL) COALITION'S PRIORITY IS UNDERAGE DRINKING BY YOUTH AGES 12-18 AND ILLEGAL USE OF MARIJUANA IN MEADE COUNTY SD. - ON JUNE 5TH, 2019 THE CITY OF STURGIS SURPRISED THE COMMUNITY WHEN IT MADE AN ANNOUNCEMENT THAT IT WOULD ALLOW ALCOHOL AT A COMMUNITY YOUTH WRESTLING EVENT IN THE CITY?S MAIN STREET SQUARE. THIS ANNOUNCEMENT CAME FROM THE LOCAL NEWSPAPER AND QUICKLY TOOK TO SOCIAL MEDIA WITH PARENT AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS OUTRAGED. THE STURGIS POLICE CHIEF WAS PUBLIC IN HIS VOICE AGAINST THE EVENT HOWEVER CITY COUNCIL MEMBERS PASSED THE OPEN CONTAINER EVENT WITH A VOTE OF 6-2.      MEADE COUNTY, SOUTH DAKOTA (3,483 SQ. MILES) IS THE THIRD LARGEST COUNTY IN LAND SIZE IN THE UNITED STATES AND HAS A COMBINATION OF LOW POPULATION DENSITY, HIGH AGRIBUSINESS EMPLOYMENT, AND LOW PAYING EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. THERE ARE SIGNIFICANT, PERSISTENT CHALLENGES IN THE IDENTIFIED COMMUNITY. STURGIS IS HOME TO THE FAMOUS STURGIS MOTORCYCLE RALLY. THIS ANNUAL GATHERING OF ROUGHLY 500,000 BIKERS, BRINGS A UNIQUE SET OF CHALLENGES. HIGH ON THIS LIST IS UNDERAGE DRINKING. WHILE THE STURGIS MOTORCYCLE RALLY OFFICIALLY RUNS ONLY TEN DAYS EACH YEAR, IT BRINGS MANY NEGATIVE EFFECTS TO THE COMMUNITY, SUCH AS AN INCREASE IN SUBSTANCE AVAILABILITY AND DRUG USE; EXPOSURE TO PUBLIC INTOXICATION; EXPOSURE TO NUDITY AND OTHER BEHAVIORS THAT NEGATIVELY AFFECT YOUTH. MANY OF THESE EFFECTS STAY LONG AFTER THE RALLY HAS ENDED.     THERE WERE 329 ARRESTS FOR JUVENILES IN 2019 WHICH IS UP FROM THE PREVIOUS YEAR OF 255. ALCOHOL IS INVOLVED IN NEARLY HALF OF ALL REPORTED CRIMES IN SD. ACCORDING TO THE MOST RECENT DATA PUBLISHED BY THE FBI, OVER 1 IN 10 JUVENILE ARRESTS ARE RELATED TO DRUGS. SOUTH DAKOTA LEADS THE NATION IN JUVENILE DRUG ARRESTS AT 45.75 PER 10,000 PEOPLE. THE NEIGHBORING STATES WERE IN THE LOW TO MID-20?S. MUCH OF THE CRIME IN THE IDENTIFIED AREA OF NEED IS RELATED TO ALCOHOL OR ILLEGAL SUBSTANCE USE. IN 2018 MEADE COUNTY SHERIFF?S OFFICE RECEIVED 6,049 CALLS FOR SERVICE AND THE STURGIS POLICE DEPARTMENT RECEIVED 9,810 CALLS, WHICH RESULTED IN 2,486 ARRESTS.       IN THE SUMMER OF 200 9, A WOMAN WAS ARRESTED FOR A .708 BAC IN STURGIS LIMITS. THE INFORMATION MADE NATIONAL NEWS AND NOW STURGIS HOLDS THE RECORD FOR THE HIGHEST BAC ARREST. WITH THE HELP OF THE DFC FUNDING STURGIS PAL HOPES TO EMPOWER THE COMMUNITY TO CHANGE SOCIAL NORMS BY REMOVING THE STIGMA OF THE STURGIS MOTORCYCLE RALLY AND ITS RESIDUAL EFFECTS AND THE IMPACT IT HAS ON THE YOUTH?S PERCEPTION OF HARM IN REGARDS TO THE USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA.     THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE: (1) TO STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF THE STURGIS PAL COALITION AND ITS MEMBERS; AND (2) TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE AMONG YOUTH BY ADDRESSING COMMUNITY RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS THROUGH THE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES.THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE ITS GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING THESE STRATEGIES:STRENGTHEN INTERNAL CAPACITY BY ENHANCING SKILLS, LEADERSHIP AND KNOWLEDGE IN BEST PRACTICES OF COALITION BUILDING.MODIFY/CHANGE POLICIES TO STRENGTHEN COALITION?S INTERNAL CAPACITY TO ACCOMPLISH GOALS, OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES.INCREASE FUNDING SOURCES AND STAFF EXPERTISE IN GRANT WRITING AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION.EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ON THE RETAIL ACCESS TO ALCOHOL BY MINORS.INCREASE YOUTH'S KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO MAKE HEALTHIER DECISIONS RELATED TO SUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE.INCREASE THE YOUTH?S MOTIVATION AND SKILLS TO SET AND MONITOR MULTIPLE HEALTH BEHAVIOR GOALS BY PROVIDING BRIEF INTEGRATED INTERVENTIONS TO YOUNG PEOPLE AND FAMILIES IN THE COMMUNITY.REDUCE ACCESS AND ENHANCE BARRIERS TO THE SOCIAL ACCESS OF ALCOHOL TO MINORS.ENFORCE LAWS CONTRIBUTING TO THE ILLEGAL USE OF MARIJUANA AND DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF MARIJUANA.

NORTHEAST PREVENTION COALITION SERVING CALEDONIA AND SOUTHERN ESSEX COUNTIES - THE NORTHEAST PREVENTION COALITION (NPC) SERVES CALEDONIA AND SOUTHERN ESSEX COUNTIES, VERMONT, A COMMUNITY OF APPROXIMATELY 33,867. THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCALEFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. NPC WILL ACHIEVE ITS GOALS BY DEVELOPING A MORE FORMAL COALITION STRUCTURE AND SUBCOMMITTEES. NPC WILL CONTINUE TO ADDRESS SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH BY IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCED BASED STRATEGIES. DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM - KEY FEATURES OF THE COMMUNITY: THE GREENSBURG PREVENTION GROUP COVERS THE CITY OF GREENSBURG, A GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION THAT RESIDES IN DECATUR COUNTY IN THE SOUTHEASTERN PORTION OF INDIANA. IT IS CONSIDERED THE COUNTY SEAT, MEASURING JUST OVER NINE SQUARE MILES. THE TOWN SITS ALONG THE INTERSTATE 74 CORRIDOR, WHICH CONNECTS INDIANAPOLIS TO CINCINNATI, AND IS ABOUT HALFWAY BETWEEN THESE TWO METROPOLISES, OR ABOUT A 60-MINUTE DRIVE FROM EACH.  GREENSBURG HAS A POPULATION OF 11,916, WITH A POPULATION DENSITY THAT IS 628% HIGHER THAN THE REST OF INDIANA. THE MEDIAN AGE IS 37 WITH NEARLY 30% OF THE POPULATION BELOW THE AGE OF 18. THERE IS AN ALMOST EVEN SPLIT BETWEEN MALES (48.9%) AND FEMALES (51.1%). CULTURALLY AND RACIALLY, THE POPULATION IN GREENSBURG IS MOSTLY WHITE/NON-HISPANIC (93.2%), WITH OTHER POPULATIONS INCLUDING ASIAN (3%), HISPANIC OR LATINO (2.2%), AND AFRICAN AMERICAN (1%).  THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 4,900 HOUSEHOLDS IN GREENSBURG WITH JUST OVER 2,900 OF THEM LIVING IN THE CITY. SOCIOECONOMICALLY, THEIR RESIDENTS HAVE A MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME OF $53,436, WITH ALMOST 13% OF RESIDENTS LIVING IN POVERTY. IN FACT, MORE THAN 50% OF GREENSBURG CHILDREN RECEIVE FREE OR REDUCED SCHOOL LUNCHES.  FURTHER, 91.4% OF ADULTS HAVE A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA, BUT ONLY 19.5% OF THEM GO ON TO OBTAIN A SECONDARY DEGREE. THIS RATE IS ALMOST 6.5% LESS THAN FOR THE STATE OF INDIANA. HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES THAT HAVE HAD AN IMPACT ON YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE: GENERATIONS OF FAMILIES TEND TO STAY IN THE GREENSBURG AREA. WHILE THERE ISN?T MUCH NIGHT LIFE OR ENTERTAINMENT IN THE LOCAL AREA, EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY. FREE OUTDOOR SUMMER MOVIES TAKE PLACE MONTHLY ON THE COURTHOUSE LAWN, A WEEKLY FARMER?S MARKET SPARKS REGULAR TRAFFIC TO THE DOWNTOWN AREA, AND A 3.1 MILE NEWLY PAVED BIKING/WALKING TRAIL HAS BEEN DEVELOPED. DESPITE THESE EFFORTS, A LACK OF YOUTH RECREATION AND ENTERTAINMENT CAN LEAD TO A SENSE OF LOW COMMUNITY ATTACHMENT AND YOUTH BECOMING BORED, WHICH CAN THEN LEAD  TO IMPULSIVENESS AND SENSATION SEEKING, ALL KNOWN AS RISK FACTORS THAT CAN LEAD TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.THE COMPANIES THAT OFFER THE MOST JOBS IN GREENSBURG ARE IN MANUFACTURING. THESE JOBS ARE MOSTLY FILLED BY TEMP AGENCIES AND DO NOT PROVIDE BENEFITS, WHICH CAN PERPETUATE THE CYCLE OF POVERTY. POVERTY OFTEN CORRELATES WITH SUBSTANCE USE, PARTICULARLY WHEN THE RISK FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH POVERTY BEGIN AT AN EARLY AGE. THIS IS PARTICULARLY TRUE FOR ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA.  FURTHER, BOTH INCOME AND EDUCATION HAVE BEEN INVERSELY CORRELATED TO SMOKING IN INDIANA. ANOTHER ENVIRONMENTAL FACTOR INCLUDES THE FACT THAT GREENSBURG IS HOME TO ONE OF THE STATE?S MOST SUCCESSFUL E-CIGARETTE BRICK-AND-MORTAR AND ONLINE RETAILERS, HOOSIER E-CIG. THIS COMPANY OPENED IN 2012 AND HAS AN ANNUAL REVENUE ESTIMATED AT NEARLY $1 MILLION.

BEAVER COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION DFC INITIATIVE 2020 - THE BEAVER COUNTY PREVENTION COALITION (BCPC) IS REQUESTING FUNDING FROM THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM FOR THE COMMUNITY OF BEAVER CITY IN SOUTHWEST UTAH. BEAVER CITY IS THE COUNTY SEAT OF BEAVER COUNTY, AND WAS SETTLED IN 1856 BY MEMBERS OF THE CHURCH OF JESUS CHRIST OF LATTER DAY SAINTS (LDS/MORMON) FAITH.BEAVER IS APPROXIMATELY 200 MILES FROM SALT LAKE CITY, UTAH AND 225 MILES FROM LAS VEGAS, NEVADA. BEAVER IS A GATEWAY TO LOCAL CANYONS AND MOUNTAIN RANGES. BEAVER IS AN ACCESS POINT TO FISHLAKE NATIONAL FOREST WHICH OFFERS A VARIETY OF OUTDOOR EXPERIENCES SUCH AS CAMPING, FISHING, HUNTING, AND WINTER SPORTS. RESIDENTS OF BEAVER HAVE A STRONG SENSE OF COMMUNITY AND ARE VERY PROUD OF THE BEAUTIFUL GEOLOGY THEIR HOME HAS TO OFFER.THE COMMUNITY OF BEAVER IS INTERCONNECTED WITH MULTIPLE NEARBY COMMUNITIES. THE MAJOR NEIGHBORING CITY IN THE COUNTY, MILFORD, IS ABOUT 30 MILES WEST, BUT IS DIFFERENT FROM BEAVER IN OVERALL COMMUNITY DEMOGRAPHICS AND CULTURE. THE YOUTH OF BEAVER AND MILFORD SERVE AS THE MAJOR SOURCE OF CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN THE TWO OTHERWISE SEPARATED COMMUNITIES. ALTHOUGH BEAVER HAS ITS OWN HOSPITAL, LOCAL GROCERY STORE, AND VARIOUS OTHER BASIC SERVICES, RESOURCES FOR THE COMMUNITY ARE STILL LIMITED. MANY BEAVER CITY RESIDENTS TRAVEL TO NEIGHBORING COUNTIES FOR OTHER BASIC NEEDS SUCH AS LARGER-SCALE GROCERY SHOPPING, SHOPPING FOR CLOTHES, AND FAMILY MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES.BEAVER CITY IS HOME TO MOST OF THE POPULATION OF BEAVER COUNTY. THE 2010 CENSUS REPORTS THAT OF THE APPROXIMATE 6,600 PEOPLE LIVING IN BEAVER COUNTY, AN ESTIMATED 3,100 OF THOSE PEOPLE LIVE IN BEAVER CITY. 93% OF RESIDENTS ARE WHITE (NON-HISPANIC), WITH 5% HISPANIC, 1% NATIVE AMERICAN, AND 1% OTHER. THE MEDIAN AGE IS 35, WITH APPROXIMATELY 2,050 ADULTS. 25% OF THOSE ADULTS ARE CONSIDERED SENIORS. HOME OWNERSHIP IS HIGH IN BEAVER, WITH APPROXIMATELY 74% OF ALL RESIDENTS OWNING AS OPPOSED TO RENTING THEIR HOMES. 89% OF RESIDENTS HAVE ATTAINED AT LEAST A HIGH  SCHOOL DIPLOMA, WITH 16% ALSO ATTAINING A BACHELORS DEGREE. BEAVER HAS SOME INCOME AND POVERTY DISPARITIES. AVERAGE INCOME FOR MALES IS $46,563 WHILE FEMALES AVERAGE $24,792, AND POVERTY AMONG WHITES AT 5% WHILE HISPANIC RESIDENTS EXPERIENCE POVERTY AT ABOUT 17%.THE DOMINANT FAITH OF BEAVER IS THE LATTER DAY SAINTS (MORMON), WITH OVER 50% OF RESIDENTS IDENTIFYING AS LDS. THE LDS RELIGION HAS SIGNIFICANT INFLUENCE ON THE CULTURE AND NORMS RELATED TO SUBSTANCE USE, AS LDS FAITHFUL ARE REQUIRED TO ABSTAIN FROM ATODS. FOR THIS REASON, BEAVER'S ILLICIT DRUG AND ALCOHOL USE RATES ARE SOME OF THE LOWEST IN THE NATION; HOWEVER, THEY ARE LESS LIKELY TO DISCUSS OR ADDRESS SUBSTANCE USE AMONG ADOLESCENTS. THE RELIGIOUS INFLUENCE OF THE LDS FAITH HAS PROVIDED BOTH RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY.BEAVER CAN BE ACCESSED THROUGH TWO EXITS ON I-15. I-15 IS A MAJOR DRUG TRAFFICKING CORRIDOR, WHICH INFLUENCES THE AVAILABILITY OF PROBLEM SUBSTANCES AND PLACES AN ADDED STRAIN ON OUR LOCAL SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT AND HIGHWAY PATROL. THE SIZE OF THE COUNTY AND THE HIGH PERCENTAGE OF WILDERNESS AREA ALSO CREATE STRAIN, AS LOCAL SHERIFF'S DEPUTIES CAN BE AS MUCH AS TWO HOURS AWAY FROM THEIR NEAREST BACKUP, AND ENFORCEMENT OF SOME DRUG PROBLEMS LIKE UNDERAGE DRINKING CAN BE PROBLEMATIC.YOUTH IN BEAVER ARE USING TOBACCO PRODUCTS, PRIMARILY E-CIGARETTES, AND DRINKING ALCOHOL UNDERAGE AT ALARMING RATES. ALCOHOL USE IS CONSIDERED A SOCIAL NORM, AS YOUTH OFTEN OBTAIN ALCOHOL WITH PARENTAL PERMISSION. BEAVER WAS FORTUNATE TO HAVE SUPPORTIVE LOCAL LEGISLATORS PASS A CITY ORDINANCE THAT BANNED SPECIALTY VAPE SHOPS FROM COMING TO THE CITY, BUT YOUTH ARE STILL BOMBARDED BY E-CIGARETTE ADVERTISEMENTS AND A RISING ADULT USE RATE. AS A RESULT, E-CIGARETTE YOUTH USE RATES HAVE STEADILY INCREASED SINCE 2013.

DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM - THE COASTAL COALITION FOR SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION (CCSAP), LOCATED IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA, DRAW ITS MEMBERS FROM FIVE ADJOINING COASTAL COUNTIES, WHICH ARE SUBJECT TO FLOODS AND HURRICANES AND MOSTLY LACK SIGNIFICANT INDUSTRY.MILITARY AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES ARE THE PREDOMINANT FORCES AND MAJOR SOURCES OF EMPLOYMENT IN OUR COALITION AREA.  FOUR OF THE FIVE COUNTIES ARE HOME TO THE WORLD?S LARGEST UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS AMPHIBIOUS BASE, TWO LARGE MARINE CORPS AIR STATIONS, A NAVAL AVIATION DEPOT, TWO UNITED STATES COAST GUARD STATIONS, AND A UNITED STATES NAVAL HOSPITAL. A CLOSER LOOK AT OUR COALITION REGION REVEALS THE FOLLOWING:?CARTERET COUNTY, POPULATION 66,473, IS MADE UP OF 11 TOWNS BORDERING THE ATLANTIC OCEAN AND OTHER WATERWAYS, IS A BEDROOM COMMUNITY FOR MILITARY, BUT IS ALSO A RECREATIONAL VACATION DESTINATION WHOSE POPULATION DOUBLE IN SIZE EACH SUMMER.  THE PARTY CULTURE THAT ACCOMPANIES THIS AREA IS AN ADDED INFLUENCE ON THE YOUTH IN OUR CATCHMENT AREA.  CARTERET COUNTY RECENTLY DROPPED FROM A TIER 3 TO A TIER 2 COMMUNITY.?CRAVEN COUNTY, POPULATION 102,139, IS MADE OF EIGHT MUNICIPALITIES INCLUDING HISTORICAL NEW BERN, WHICH IS NORTH CAROLINA?S SECOND OLDEST TOWN, AND WAS THE FIRST PERMANENT COLONIAL CAPITAL.  CRAVEN COUNTY IS HOME TO CHERRY POINT AND IS LARGELY A RETIREMENT COMMUNITY.?JONES COUNTY, POPULATION 9,149, IS THE SMALLEST COALITION COUNTY AND IS A RURAL FARMING COMMUNITY. ITS LACK OF INDUSTRY HAS CONTRIBUTED TO ITS STATUS AS A TIER 1 (MOST ECONOMICALLY DISTRESSED), WITH A 16.2% POVERTY LEVEL.?ONSLOW COUNTY, POPULATION 197,938, IS HOME TO CAMP LEJEUNE AND NEW RIVER AIR STATION GIVING ONSLOW THE YOUNGEST AVERAGE AGED POPULATION (22) IN THE NATION. ONSLOW HAS SIX MUNICIPALITIES AND HAS HAD ONE OF THE STATE?S HIGHEST STATISTICS FOR ALCOHOL-RELATED CRASHES AND FATALITIES. IN SPITE OF THE ECONOMIC ENGINE OF CAMP LEJEUNE, ONSLOW HAS A 15.1% POVERTY LEVEL. MANY OF THE YOUTH WHO SERVE IN THIS COUNTY ARE MILITARY DEPENDEN TS AND OFTEN FACE TIME AWAY FROM THEIR PARENT(S) DUE TO DEPLOYMENTS, BOTH STATESIDE AS WELL AS OVERSEAS. THIS CAN CONTRIBUTE TO THE FAVORABLE ATTITUDES TOWARDS SUBSTANCE USE.?PAMLICO COUNTY, POPULATION 12,726, IS ONE OF THE LESSER POPULATED COUNTIES, HAS ITS ROOTS IN FISHING AND FARMING. PAMLICO IS A TIER 2 COMMUNITY, AND ALSO LACKS MAJOR INDUSTRY.AN OVERALL DEMOGRAPHIC PICTURE SHOWS THE ETHNICITY OF OUR COUNTIES RANGING FROM 62-89% CAUCASIAN, 6-32% AFRICAN AMERICAN, 3-8% HISPANIC, AND 1% NATIVE AMERICAN OR ASIAN BACKGROUND. FAVORABLE ATTITUDES TOWARDS ALCOHOL HAVE FUELED UNDERAGE DRINKING IN OUR AREA, WITH JACKSONVILLE, NC DESIGNATED THE DRUNKEST CITY IN NORTH CAROLINA FIVE YEARS IN A ROW, AND THE DESIGNATION OF ONSLOW COUNTY AS NUMBER TWELVE IN THE NATION OF PRESCRIPTION DRUG MISUSE, HIGHLIGHTS THE LOW PERCEPTION OF HARM FROM SUCH USE. PARENTAL PERMISSIVENESS TOWARDS UNDERAGE DRINKING FURTHER COMPOUNDS THE PROBLEMS FACED RELATED TO UNDERAGE DRINKING.HURRICANE FLORENCE DEVASTATED OUR COUNTIES IN 2018. MANY AREAS OF THE COUNTIES ARE STILL REBUILDING, SCHOOLS ARE STILL UNDER CONSTRUCTION, AND THERE ARE FAMILIES STILL DISPLACED, WITH MANY LIVING WITH RELATIVES, OR IN LOCAL HOTELS. YOUTH WHO ARE LACKING ADEQUATE COPING SKILLS MAY TURN TO SUBSTANCE USE TO COPE.  CCSAP WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH LOCAL YOUTH TO DEVELOP NECESSARY COPING SKILLS, AND WITH LOCAL SCHOOLS AND AGENCIES TO DEVELOP TRAUMA INFORMED POLICIES.

HEALTHY LINCOLN COUNTY SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION PARTNERSHIP - PROJECT NAME: HEALTHY LINCOLN COUNTY SUBSTANCE USE PREVENTION PARTNERSHIPLINCOLN COUNTY, MAINE IS MADE UP 19 TOWNS, INCLUDING ONE OFF-SHORE ISLAND COMMUNITY, SPREAD ACROSS OVER 450 SQUARE MILES OF LAND, WITH 450 MILES OF ROCKY COASTLINE IN THE MID-COAST REGION. OUR POPULATION IS ABOUT 34,000. WE HAVE NO CITIES IN OUR COUNTY, AND THE NEAREST ?BOX STORE? IS AT LEAST A 30-40-MINUTE DRIVE EITHER EAST, WEST, OR NORTH. THE COASTAL GEOGRAPHY, WITH ITS MANY PENINSULAS JUTTING MILES INTO HARBORS, CONTRIBUTES TO STRONG LOCAL VILLAGE CULTURE, AS WELL AS ISOLATION. WE HAVE AN ECONOMIC DIVIDE WHICH OUR YOUTH COALITION MEMBER DESCRIBED AS ?LOBSTER BOATS AND SAIL BOATS?. FOR EXAMPLE, THE MEDIAN FAMILY INCOMES OF SOMERVILLE (AN INLAND VILLAGE) AND BOOTHBAY HARBOR ARE $39,063 AND $81,250, RESPECTIVELY. THE BEAUTY OF THE AREA BRINGS TOURISTS, AND WEALTHY RETIREES, MAKING OUR COUNTY THE OLDEST IN MAINE (ALMOST 28% OF OUR POPULATION IS 65 OR OLDER). YET 18.5% OF OUR CHILDREN ARE LIVING IN POVERTY (PRE-COVID), AND THERE EXISTS A ?BRAIN DRAIN? OF YOUNG PEOPLE LEAVING FOR COLLEGE AND RARELY COMING BACK DUE TO A SCARCITY OF JOBS. ALMOST 97% OF RESIDENTS DESCRIBE THEMSELVES AS WHITE/NON-HISPANIC. LINCOLN COUNTY HAS ONE OF THE HIGHEST RATES OF YOUTH WHO IDENTIFY AS LGBTQ IN MAINE, AND MANY LGBTQ ADULTS AND FAMILIES ARE INTEGRATED INTO COMMUNITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS WITH VARYING LEVELS OF ACCEPTANCE. WHILE SMALL TOWN LIFE CREATES SUPPORT AND A SENSE OF DUTY TO CARE FOR ONE ANOTHER, OUR COMMUNITIES ARE CHALLENGED BY LONG-STANDING RELIANCE ON SUBSTANCES TO MANAGE STRESS IN THE FACE OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL PRESSURES. ACCORDING TO THE 2018 LINCOLN COUNTY HEALTH PROFILE, OUR CHRONIC HEAVY DRINKING RATE FOR ADULTS IS ABOUT 9%, COMPARED TO 7.6% (MAINE) AND 5.9% (US), AND IS COMMON AMONG MULTI-GENERATIONAL FAMILIES, PARTICULARLY IN THE SEAFARING COMMUNITIES. WITH THE DECRIMINALIZATION OF MARIJUANA IN MAINE, WE EXPECT OUR FIRST RETAIL MARIJUANA SHOPS TO OPEN IN SUMMER OF 2020. YOUNG  CHILDREN GROWING UP IN FAMILIES WHO WORK IN THE MARIJUANA INDUSTRY ARE CONFUSED WHEN PROVIDED PREVENTION EDUCATION, WITH ONE SIXTH GRADER NOTING, ?MY PARENTS FINALLY HAVE A STEADY PAYCHECK? FROM THEIR MARIJUANA BUSINESS. THESE FACTORS ARE JUST SOME OF THE CONTEXT WHICH IS CONTRIBUTING TO OUR YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CONTINUE ENGAGING OUR COMMUNITY IN PREVENTING AND REDUCING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, BUILDING ON OUR SUCCESSES OF THE PAST AND TAKING A DEEPER LOOK INTO SPECIFIC DISPARITIES, SOLIDIFYING OUR SYSTEMS FOR LONG-TERM SUCCESS, AND EQUIPPING THE ADULTS IN OUR COMMUNITY WITH THE SKILLS THEY NEED TO MORE EFFECTIVELY HELP OUR YOUTH MAKE HEALTHY, LOW RISK CHOICES. WE SEEK TO REDUCE THE PERCENT OF OUR YOUTH WHO REPORT DRINKING ALCOHOL AND USING MARIJUANA IN THE PAST 30 DAYS, AND TO INCREASE THEIR ACCESS TO HEALTHY ALTERNATIVES. WE WILL CREATE A ROBUST SYSTEM TO SUPPORT OUR RETAILERS SO THEY CAN CONTINUE TO DO THE RIGHT THING, AND WE WILL MORE FULLY INCORPORATE RESTORATIVE PRACTICES INTO OUR SCHOOLS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND COMMUNITY. WE ARE MOTIVATED TO SHAPE OUR COMMUNITY?S ENVIRONMENT WITH POLICIES AND PRACTICES WHICH FOSTER A HEALTHY, SUBSTANCE-FREE LIFE FOR EVERYONE WHO LIVES, WORKS, AND PLAYS IN LINCOLN COUNTY, AND IN PARTICULAR, OUR YOUNGEST RESIDENTS.

EMPOWER WATSONVILLE - IN 2017, THE EMPOWER WATSONVILLE (EW) YOUTH LEADERSHIP PROGRAM WAS CREATED AS PART OF THE TOBACCO USE PREVENTION AND EDUCATION (TUPE) PROGRAM AT PAJARO VALLEY PREVENTION AND STUDENT ASSISTANCE, INC. (PVPSA).  SINCE THEN, THE GROUP HAS EXPANDED TO INCLUDE STAKEHOLDERS FROM MORE SECTORS IN THE COMMUNITY, SUCH AS THE WATSONVILLE POLICE DEPARTMENT, FRIDAY NIGHT LIVE (AN ORGANIZATION DEVOTED TO YOUTH-LED LOCAL PROJECTS PROMOTING SAFER COMMUNITIES), THE PAJARO VALLEY UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT STUDENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT, PVPSA?S PROMOTORAS DE SALUD, THE SANTA CRUZ COUNTY TOBACCO EDUCATION COALITION, AND WATSONVILLE HIGH SCHOOL?S CONFLICT RESOLUTION TEAM.  AS OF 2018, WATSONVILLE, CALIFORNIA?S POPULATION WAS 53,937.  81.9% ARE LATINX; 14.3% ARE WHITE; 2.4% ARE ASIAN AMERICAN; 0.8% ARE TWO OR MORE RACES; 0.4% ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN; 0.1% ARE ALASKAN NATIVE/NATIVE AMERICAN; AND 0.1% ARE OTHER.  73.2% ARE US CITIZENS, AND 37.6% WERE BORN OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES.  THE MEDIAN AGE OF ALL RESIDENTS IS 29.7 YEARS; NATIVE-BORN RESIDENTS HAVE A MEDIAN AGE OF 19, WHILE FOREIGN-BORN RESIDENTS HAVE A MEDIAN AGE OF 43.  28.7% OF RESIDENTS LIVE BELOW THE POVERTY LINE; OF THOSE RESIDENTS, 47.6% ARE LATINX.  MALES REPRESENT 49.6% OF THE POPULATION, AND FEMALES 50.4%.  OF THE PARAJO VALLEY UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT (PVUSD) YOUTH FROM THE AREA WHO RESPONDED TO THE CALIFORNIA HEALTHY KIDS SURVEY, FEWER THAN 1% IDENTIFIED AS TRANSGENDER; BETWEEN 13% AND 18% (DEPENDING ON GRADE LEVEL) IDENTIFIED THEMSELVES AS GAY/LESBIAN/BISEXUAL.  FOR THOSE RESIDENTS WHO DECLARED THEMSELVES TO BE RELIGIOUS (31.7% OF THE POPULATION), 63.4% ARE CATHOLIC, 28% BELONG TO A PROTESTANT DENOMINATION, 4.4% ADHERE TO AN EASTERN FAITH, 2.7% ARE MUSLIM, AND 1.5% ARE JEWISH.EVENTS CONTRIBUTING TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE IN WATSONVILLE INCLUDE THE FACT THAT THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA LEGALIZED RECREATIONAL CANNABIS USE FOR ADULTS IN 2016; THE WATSONVILLE CITY COUNCIL APPROVED RECREATIONAL CANNABIS CULTIVATION  AND MANUFACTURE. ARE NOW WORKING IN THE CANNABIS CULTIVATION BUSINESSES AND THUS NORMALIZING YOUTH EXPOSURE TO THE SUBSTANCE.
