DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES- MOROVIS - THE COALICION DE PREVENCION MOROVE?A (CPM) IS A COALITION WORKING TO FOSTER COMMUNITYPARTNERSHIPS AND IMPLEMENT INNOVATIVE STRATEGIES TO PROMOTE SUBSTANCE PREVENTION AND A HEALTHYENVIRONMENT FOR YOUTH DEVELOPMENT IN THE MUNICIPALITY OF MOROVIS, PUERTO RICO. WITH A POPULATION OF31,320, MOROVIS IS LOCATED IN A RURAL GEOGRAPHIC AREA IN THE NORTH CENTRAL SIDE OF PUERTO RICO. THEVAST MAJORITY OF THE POPULATION IDENTIFIES AS LATINO (99%, AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY, OR ACS,2018), AND 97% REPORTING SPANISH AS THEIR PRIMARY LANGUAGE. THE POPULATION OF MOROVIS CONSISTS OF18.2% UNDER THE AGE OF 18, AND 15% OVER THE AGE OF 65. THE MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME IS $20,589,ABOUT ONE-THIRD OF THE AMOUNT IN UNITED STATES: $60,293; WITH 45% OF PERSONS LIVING BELOW THEPOVERTY LEVEL, AND 58% OF CHILDREN BELOW THE POVERTY LINE.IN SEPTEMBER OF 2017, THE ENTIRE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO WAS IMPACTED BY TWO CATEGORY FOUR HURRICANESWITHIN A TWO-WEEK PERIOD, CAUSING MASSIVE DEVASTATION. THEN, ON JANUARY 7, 2020, A 6.4 MAGNITUDEEARTHQUAKE HIT THE SOUTHERN REGION OF PR, WITH TREMORS OF A MAGNITUDE OF 4 OR MORE STILL OCCURRING.THESE EVENTS HAVE AFFECTED ECONOMICALLY THE ISLAND, BUT MOSTLY THE EMOTIONAL HEALTH OF THE PEOPLE OFPR, CREATING MANY CHALLENGES, AND INCREASING THE NEED FOR THE DRUGS FREE COMMUNITIES PROJECT.OUR APPROACH TO THE DFC CONTINUING PROJECT LIES IN THE BELIEF THAT YOUTH SHOULD BE ACTIVE PARTICIPANTSIN UNDERSTANDING THEIR COMMUNITY?S ISSUES, FACILITATED THROUGH THE SHARING OF MUTUAL EXPERIENCES, ANDBECOMING AGENTS OF COMMUNITY CHANGE. THE PURPOSE OF THE DFC PROJECT FOR THE CONTINUING YEARS ISTO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND ENGAGEMENT OF YOUTH USING INNOVATIVE STRATEGIES TOACHIEVE COMMUNITY TRANSFORMATION AROUND PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH UNDERAGE ALCOHOL USEAND PERCEPTION OF RISKS OF ABUSING PRESCRIPTION DRUGS. THE DFC PROJECT WILL SERVE YOUTH BETWEEN THEAGES OF 14-18 FROM THE MUNICIPALITY OF MOROVIS. THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE:DF C GOAL ONE: INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATIONOBJECTIVE 1: BY SEPTEMBER 2021, INCREASE CAPACITY OF COALITION AND INCREASE YOUTH ACTIVEMEMBERSHIP BY 5%, MEASURED BY SIGN-IN-SHEETS DURING ACTIVITIES.DFC GOAL TWO: REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USEOBJECTIVE 1: BY SEPTEMBER 2021, DECREASE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT ALCOHOL USE AS MEASURED BY THEPERCENTAGE OF YOUTH REPORTING PAST 30-DAY ALCOHOL USE ON THE MOROVIS YOUTH SURVEY BY 3%.OBJECTIVE 2: BY SEPTEMBER 2021, INCREASE BY 3% THE PERCEPTION OF RISK FOR THE USE OF PRESCRIPTIONTHE CPM WILL UTILIZE THE STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK TO ENSURE INTERDISCIPLINARY, MULTI-SECTORALUNDERSTANDING OF THE UNDERAGE DRINKING AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG PROBLEM IN THE TARGET POPULATION ANDLEVERAGE NEW AND EXISTING PREVENTION RESOURCES TO ENSURE A COMPREHENSIVE RESPONSE. THE 9-MONTHACTION PLAN DESIGNED IS GROUNDED IN SPF AND INCLUDES A MIX OF CADCA?S SEVEN STRATEGIES FORCOMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE IN ORDER TO BUILD COALITION CAPACITY, YOUTH ENGAGEMENT AND CREATETRANSFORMATION ON AN ENVIRONMENTAL LEVEL.

COUNCIL ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND YOUTH DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES.  THE COALITION'S GOAL IS TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT SUBSTANCE ABUSE. - THE COUNCIL ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND YOUTH (CSAY) HAS APPLIED FOR A FISCAL YEAR 2020 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $125,000, FOR THE MOUNT PLEASANT AREA.  THE COALITION SERVES MOUNT PLEASANT, PENNSYLVANIA, A COMMUNITY OF 17,374.  THE MOUNT PLEASANT AREA SCHOOL DISTRICT ENCOMPASSES APPROXIMATELY 106 SQUARE MILES AND INCLUDES MOUNT PLEASANT BOROUGH, MOUNT PLEASANT TOWNSHIP, DONEGAL BOROUGH AND DONEGAL TOWNSHIP.  AS A WHOLE, THE SCHOOL DISTRICT IS CONSIDERED LARGELY SUBURBAN, WITH A RESIDENTIAL POPULATION OF 17,374.  FURTHERMORE, THE DISTRICT HAS AN ENROLLMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 2,066 STUDENTS.  THE MEDIAN AGE IN THIS COMMUNITY IS 46.1 YEARS AND 9.9% OF THE RESIDENTS LIVE IN POVERTY, A RATE COMPARABLE TO THE COUNTY RATE OF 10.3%. HOWEVER, WITHIN MOUNT PLEASANT BOROUGH, THE POVERTY RATE RISES TO 12.9%, WHICH IS SLIGHTLY ABOVE THE NATIONAL POVERTY RATE OF 12.3%.  THE RACIAL MAKEUP OF THE COMMUNITY IS 97.9% WHITE OR CAUCASIAN, 1.0% FROM TWO OR MORE RACES, 0.6% ASIAN, AND 0.4% BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN.  UNDERAGE DRINKING HAS BEEN A CONSISTENT, ONGOING PROBLEM FOR THE MOUNT PLEASANT AREA, DUE TO THE RURAL LOCATIONS THAT ARE EASILY ACCESSIBLE.  THE DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES YEARS 1-5 GRANT FOCUSED ON UNDERAGE DRINKING AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG ABUSE. CSAY WORKED DILIGENTLY TO ADDRESS THESE TWO SUBSTANCES AND IS NOW SEEING A SHIFT TO A SUBSTANTIAL PROBLEM OF MARIJUANA USE BY THE YOUTH OF THE MT. PLEASANT COMMUNITY. A COUNTY-WIDE NEEDS ASSESSMENT WAS CONDUCTED AND THROUGH FOCUS GROUPS AND SURVEY DATA, IT HAS BEEN DISCOVERED THAT THE LEGALIZATION OF MEDICAL MARIJUANA, AS WELL AS TALK OF LEGALIZING RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA, HAVE INCREASED USE AMONG YOUTH.  PARENTAL APPROVAL OF MARIJUANA USE AMONG YOUTH HAS ALSO INCREASED.  CSAY HAS ACTIVELY BEEN WORKING ON BUILDING CAPACITY BY SHARING ITS NEEDS ASSESSMENT INFORMATION WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS AND WORKING ON A NINE-MONTH ACTION PLAN.THE FIRST FIVE YEARS ENABLED CSAY TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE TECH NICAL ASSISTANCE AND RAMP UP COALITION ACTIVITIES, WITH STRONG YOUTH PARTICIPATION.  CSAY HAS MADE GREAT STRIDES AND ESTABLISHED PARTNERSHIPS IN THE COMMUNITY. IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TO ADDRESS FACTORS THAT INCREASE THE RISK OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE AND CHANGE THE CULTURE AND CONTEXT WITHIN WHICH DECISIONS ABOUT SUBSTANCE USE ARE MADE, THE CONTINUATION OF DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES YEARS 6-10 IS ESSENTIAL. IT WOULD ALLOW CSAY TO ENHANCE COALITION MEMBERSHIP, AS WELL AS INCREASE ACTIVITIES THAT WOULD ADDRESS UNDERAGE DRINKING AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG YOUTH AGE 18 AND YOUNGER.  CSAY WANTS TO KEEP GROWING YOUTH INVOLVEMENT THROUGH THE SCHOOL AND TO SUPPORT THEM IN THEIR PEER TO PEER PREVENTION EFFORTS, AS WELL AS HAVING THE YOUTH WORK WITH THE COALITION?S COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE AMONG YOUTH.

"THE REDUCTION OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE OF TOBACCO/NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA, INCLUDING THE USE OF ELECTRONIC NICOTINE DELIVERY SYSTEMS" - DRUG-FREE IRONDEQUOIT WILL USE EVIDENCE BASED PREVENTION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE MARIJUANA AND NICOTINE USE, PARTICULARLY WITH ELECTRONIC NICOTINE DELIVERY SYSTEMS (ENDS) AMONG TEENS BETWEEN 7TH AND 12TH GRADE. STRATEGIES INCLUDE MEDIA CAMPAIGNS PROVIDING INFORMATION TO PARENTS AND TEENS, ENHANCING SKILLS OF PARENTS TO START EARLY CONVERSATIONS WITH YOUTH, PROVIDING SUPPORT TO YOUTH BY INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND ENSURING ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES TO REDUCE ACCESS TO THESE SUBSTANCES.THE DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO SUPPORT INITIATIVES TO DECREASE NICOTINE AND MARIJUANA USE AMONG APPROXIMATELY 3400 MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOLERS IN THE TOWN OF IRONDEQUOIT, NY. IT WILL ALSO HELP US TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL INFORMATION AND ENHANCE PARENT SKILLS TO INCREASE THE PERCEPTION OF HARM AND RISK.A COMMUNITY PARADIGM SHIFT OVER A PERIOD OF THE 5 YEAR GRANT WOULD IMPACT ABOUT 50000 RESIDENTS.OBJECTIVES OF THE GRANT INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND NURTURING PARTNERSHIPS WITH ADULT AND YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS IN THE TOWN AS WELL AS SPECIFIC AGENCIES WHO PROVIDE AREAS OF EXPERTISE TO THE COALITION. A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE IRONDEQUOIT POLICE IS ALSO PART OF OUR STRATEGIES IN RE: TO COMPLIANCE CHECKS AND ENSURING MORE POLICE ARE TRAINED AS DRE (DRUG RECOGNITION EXPERTS).STRATEGIES ALSO INCLUDE BUILDING A MEDIA LIBRARY OF EXPERTS TO SHARE INFORMATION, SOCIAL MEDIA AND VARIOUS OTHER MEDIA FORMATS, PROVISION OF CESSATION MATERIALS FOR YOUTH AND ADULTS.INCREASED COLLABORATION WITHIN THE TOWN IS ESSENTIAL AND WE WILL BE WORKING TO EXPAND MEMBERSHIP FROM UNDERSERVED SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY. THE COALITION WILL ALSO BE REFINING THE EVALUATION AND SUSTAINABILITY PLANS OVER THE NEXT 5 YEARS.

PYRAMID COALITION: YEAR 6 YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION FOR HIDALGO COUNTY, NM. - HIDALGO COUNTY, IN THE SOUTHWESTERN CORNER OF NEW MEXICO, BORDERS ARIZONA TO THE EAST AND MEXICO TO THE SOUTH. IT IS 3,440 SQUARE MILES (LARGER THAN DELAWARE AND RHODE ISLAND COMBINED). POPULATION DENSITY PER SQUARE MILE IS 1.4, WITH 1,753 HOUSEHOLDS IN THE COUNTY. THE MAJOR COMMUNITIES ARE LORDSBURG, VIRDEN, ANIMAS, RODEO, PLAYAS AND COTTON CITY. TWO THIRDS OF THE COUNTY?S 4,198 RESIDENTS LIVE IN LORDSBURG (POPULATION 2,797), THE COUNTY SEAT AND MARKET CENTER. PER CAPITA INCOME IN HIDALGO COUNTY IS $20,275, NEARLY $6,000 LOWER THAN NEW MEXICO?S PER CAPITA AVERAGE. 36.3% OF THE CHILDREN UNDER AGE 18 LIVE IN POVERTY IN THE COUNTY, COMPARED TO 25.9% FOR NM AND 18.4% FOR THE U.S. (NM DEPT. OF HEALTH IBIS 2017). THE COUNTY IS A ?MAJORITY MINORITY? COUNTY WITH ALMOST 60% OF RESIDENTS IDENTIFYING AS NOT WHITE AND PRINCIPALLY HISPANIC/LATINO; 39.5% OF THE POPULATION ARE SPANISH SPEAKING (US CENSUS 2014-18).  AS A COUNTY BORDERING MEXICO, HIDALGO IS A FEDERALLY DESIGNATED HIGH INTENSITY DRUG TRAFFICKING AREA- HIDTA.LACK OF EDUCATION, POVERTY, AND UNEMPLOYMENT ARE WIDELY RECOGNIZED RISK FACTORS FOR SUBSTANCE ABUSE. NEW MEXICO IS NEAR THE TOP IN THE NATION FOR ALCOHOL AND DRUG RELATED DEATHS AS WELL AS SUICIDE, RANKING 1ST IN THE STATE FOR THE LATTER. (NM DOH 2020 EPIDEMIOLOGY PROFILE)ON THE NEW MEXICO COMMUNITY SURVEY OF ADULTS IN HIDALGO COUNTY 27.5% (N=180) INDICATED THAT THEY HAD DRANK IN THE LAST 30 DAYS AND OF THAT NUMBER 35% (N=60) INDICATED THAT THEY HAD ENGAGED IN BINGE DRINKING IN THE LAST 30 DAYS. HIDALGO COUNTY RANKS 1ST  IN THE STATE FOR ADULT HEAVY DRINKING, 2ND IN BINGE DRINKING, AND 3RD IN DEATHS DUE TO DRUG OVERDOSE (NM DOH 2017 EPIDEMIOLOGY PROFILE). HIDALGO COUNTY?S HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATION RATE IS ONLY 79.2%. THE COUNTY SCHOOL DISTRICTS ARE, LORDSBURG MUNICIPAL SCHOOLS (509 STUDENTS) AND ANIMAS PUBLIC SCHOOLS (177 STUDENTS) (US CENSUS 2014-18, NATIONAL CENTER FOR EDUCATION STATISTICS 2019).ONCE HOME TO VIBRANT MINING AND RAILROAD INDUSTR IES, HUNDREDS OF JOBS WERE LOST OVER THE PAST TWO DECADES AS COMPANIES DOWNSIZED OR CLOSED COMPLETELY. CENSUS POPULATION ESTIMATES FROM 2019 SHOW A 14.3% POPULATION DECREASE IN THE LAST 9 YEARS. TODAY, SEVERAL HUNDRED FARMS AND RANCHES ARE SCATTERED THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. INTERSTATE 10 (I-10) IS THE MAJOR EAST-WEST HIGHWAY IN THE COUNTY AND LORDSBURG IS A FLAG-STOP FOR THE UNION PACIFIC/AMTRAK RAILROAD LINE.HIDALGO COUNTY'S REMOTENESS FROM METROPOLITAN CENTERS HAS SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE ECONOMY AND ON THE ABILITY OF SOCIAL SERVICE PROVIDERS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE POPULATION. THE COUNTY IS DESIGNATED AS "FRONTIER" WHERE RESIDENTS TYPICALLY DRIVE OVER ONE HOUR ONE-WAY TO A GROCERY STORE, PHARMACY OR CINEMA. THE NEAREST HOSPITAL IS OVER ONE HOUR FROM LORDSBURG AND RESIDENTS OFTEN TRAVEL TWO TO FOUR HOURS ONE-WAY TO RECEIVE SPECIALIZED HEALTH CARE. REMOTENESS, LOW POPULATION AND DISTANCE FROM THE STATE CAPITAL OF SANTA FE AND MAJOR URBAN MARKETS MAKE HIDALGO?S RESIDENTS INVISIBLE POLITICALLY WITH LITTLE INFLUENCE TO RECEIVE THE SERVICES, RESOURCES AND BENEFITS OTHER COUNTIES IN THE STATE ENJOY.CHRONIC SUBSTANCE ABUSE ALONG WITH A DISPROPORTIONATE LACK OF RESOURCES CONTRIBUTED TO THE SELECTION OF HIDALGO COUNTY AS THE RECIPIENT OF A COMPETITIVE STATE-FUNDED SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION PROGRAM IN 2008. A SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION COALITION WAS FORMED THE SAME YEAR AND MODEST BUT MEASURABLE REDUCTIONS IN YOUTH DWIS, BINGE DRINKING AND ALCOHOL USE HAVE BEEN ACHIEVED.

DRUG FREE (DFC) COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE COLLABORATION AND BUILD COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS' CAPACITY TO MOVE THROUGH A CHANGE PROCESS AIMED TO REDUCE YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE. AS THE COALITION MOVES THROUGH THE STEPS OF THE SPF, WE ANTICIPATE DECREASING PAST 30-DAY USE OF ALCOHOL, NICOTINE, AND MARIJUANA AMONG MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH THROUGH COMMUNITY-LEVEL CHANGE BY 1) INCLUDING KEY PARTNERS, INCLUDING SCHOOLS, YOUTH, PARENTS, BUSINESSES, AND LAW ENFORCEMENT TO FULFILL THE ACTION PLAN ACTIVITIES, 2) CHANGING COMMUNITY CONDITIONS TO REDUCE RISK FACTORS AND INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS RELATED TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE; 3) REDUCING YOUTH ACCESS TO SUBSTANCES OF CONCERN; 4)IMPROVING SYSTEMS AND PROCESSES, AND 5) CHANGING COMMUNITY NORMS THAT MAY CONTRIBUTE TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.

SAFE & HEALTHY HOMEWOOD COALITION-YOUTH DRUG PREVENTION PROJECT - SAFE & HEALTHY HOMEWOOD COALITION  HOMEWOOD IS A SMALL, URBAN CITY IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, ALABAMA LOCATED WITHIN THE BIRMINGHAM METROPOLITAN AREA (POP. 1,151,801). THE CURRENT POPULATION OF HOMEWOOD IS 25,678 WHICH CONSISTS OF 10,092 HOUSEHOLDS; 3,039 WITH CHILDREN UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE.   HOMEWOOD IS A SOUGHT AFTER PLACE TO LIVE FOR SEVERAL REASONS. IT IS PROXIMATE TO THE CITY OF BIRMINGHAM WHICH IS THE OPERATION CENTER FOR SEVERAL LARGE EMPLOYERS. INTERSTATE 65 TRANSECTS THE CITY, MAKING COMMUTE TIME MINIMAL. THE SCHOOL SYSTEM IS ONE OF THE BEST IN THE NATION OFTEN RECEIVING RECOGNITION IN NATIONAL SCHOOL RANKINGS. HOMEWOOD CITY SCHOOLS HAS THREE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, ONE MIDDLE SCHOOL AND ONE HIGH SCHOOL; THE DISTRICT SERVES APPROXIMATELY 4,200 STUDENTS. THE CITY ALSO BOASTS AN EXCELLENT PARKS & RECREATION PROGRAM AND PUBLIC LIBRARY.  DIVERSITY IS ANOTHER CHARACTERISTIC OF HOMEWOOD THAT IS CELEBRATED. MUCH OF THE CULTURAL DIVERSITY IS DRIVEN BY THE CITY?S PROXIMITY TO THE WORLD RENOWNED UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA AT BIRMINGHAM MEDICAL FACILITY AND TEACHING HOSPITAL. INDIVIDUALS COME FROM ALL OVER THE WORLD TO WORK AND STUDY HERE. IN 2010, THE RACIAL MAKEUP OF HOMEWOOD WAS 78% CAUCASIAN, 14% AFRICAN-AMERICAN, 2% ASIAN, 4% FROM OTHER RACES, AND 2% FROM TWO OR MORE RACES. 4% OF THE POPULATION IDENTIFY THEMSELVES AS HISPANIC OR LATINO. ACCORDING TO A SURVEY BY THE UNITED WAY 2.6% OF THE POPULATION IDENTIFY AS LGBTQ.  THE POPULATION OF HOMEWOOD IS DIVERSE IN WAYS BEYOND RACIAL COMPOSITION. ONE SIGNIFICANT AREA OF DIVERSITY IS THE SOCIOECONOMIC RANGE AMONG FAMILIES IN HOMEWOOD. ACCORDING TO THE 2018 DATA, THE MEDIAN FAMILY INCOME IS $71,494; HOWEVER, 28% OF STUDENTS QUALIFY FOR FEDERAL LUNCH ASSISTANCE.  ANOTHER SIGNIFICANT AREA OF DIVERSITY IS IN THE HOUSING COMPOSITION OF HOMEWOOD. HOUSING TYPES RANGE FROM GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIZED APARTMENTS TO AFFLUENT SUBURBAN NEIGHBORHOODS. ACCORDING TO CURRENT POPULATION DATA, HOMEWOOD HAS ONE OF THE HIGHEST POPU LATION DENSITIES IN ALABAMA. IT IS A LAND-LOCKED, URBAN CITY THAT IS ONLY 8.3 SQUARE MILES, BORDERED ON ALL SIDES BY OTHER MUNICIPALITIES.   HOMEWOOD ALSO BOASTS A DIVERSE FAITH COMMUNITY. THE FAITH COMMUNITY INCLUDES SEVERAL CATHOLIC CHURCHES, NUMEROUS PROTESTANT CHURCHES, AND THE BIRMINGHAM ISLAMIC SOCIETY. NO JEWISH SYNAGOGUES ARE LOCATED IN HOMEWOOD PROPER, BUT SEVERAL IN THE NEIGHBORING CITY OF BIRMINGHAM.  HOMEWOOD IS ALSO DIVERSE IN THE RESIDENTS? POLITICAL AFFILIATIONS. BECAUSE ALABAMA IS A ?RED? STATE, MANY HOMEWOOD RESIDENTS PUT BLUE DOT STICKERS ON THEIR CARS. THE BLUE DOT SYMBOLIZES THEIR ?BLUE? PARTY AFFILIATION IN A SEA OF RED.  THE HOMEWOOD COMMUNITY FACES A SERIOUS THREAT DUE TO THE AVAILABILITY OF ILLEGAL DRUGS. THE BIRMINGHAM METRO AREA (INCLUDING HOMEWOOD) IS ONE OF ONDCPS FIVE HIGH INTENSITY DRUG TRAFFICKING AREAS (GULF COAST). THIS COMMUNITY LEVEL THREAT TRANSLATES TO ELEVATED SUBSTANCE USE BY HOMEWOOD YOUTH WHICH IN 2015 WAS HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE ACCORDING TO THE PRIDE NATIONAL SUMMARY. SINCE RECEIVING DFC FUNDING IN 2015 WE HAVE EXPERIENCED A DECREASE IN YOUTH USE OF CIGARETTES, ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND PRESCRIPTION DRUGS. DURING THAT TIME PERIOD WE HAVE WITNESSED A SHARP INCREASE IN YOUTH USE OF ELECTRONIC NICOTINE DELIVERY SYSTEMS (ENDS).  THE SAFE & HEALTHY HOMEWOOD COALITION WILL CONTINUE TO ENGAGE MULTIPLE SECTORS OF THE COMMUNITY IN A CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT PROCESS USING THE SPF AND ENSURING WE ARE FOCUSING ON PREVENTION STRATEGIES IN ALL SEVEN AREAS NECESSARY FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE. BASED ON PRIDE SURVEY DATA, THE COALITION WILL STRIVE TO REDUCE YOUTH: MARIJUANA, TOBACCO (NICOTINE), AND UNDERAGE ALCOHOL USE IN THE CITY OF HOMEWOOD AND WITHIN THE STUDENT POPULATION OF HOMEWOOD CITY SCHOOLS. THE COALITION?S GOAL IS TO REDUCE YOUTH USE OF THESE SUBSTANCES BY 10% OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS WHILE ALSO STRENGTHENING THE COALITION'S CAPACITY TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABILITY AS A COMMUNITY-ENGAGED PREV

DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM - THE BOROUGH OF POMPTON LAKES (PL) IS LOCATED IN PASSAIC COUNTY, NEW JERSEY. AS OF THE 2010 US CENSUS, 11,097 HARDWORKING, FAMILY FOCUSED, CARING RESIDENTS LIVE WITHIN OUR 3.2 SQUARE MILE BORDERS. IT WAS ONCE HEADQUARTERS TO GENERAL GEORGE WASHINGTON AND OUR MOST NOTABLE RESIDENT WAS THE FAMOUS DIRECTOR CECIL B. DEMILLE. AS WIKIPEDIA DESCRIBES, PL IS AN OUTER-RING SUBURB OF NEW YORK CITY, LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 20 MILES NORTHWEST OF MIDTOWN MANHATTAN. WITH SUCH A CLOSE PROXIMITY TO ONE OF THE WORLD?S LARGEST CITIES, SOME MAY ASSUME PL IS A BUSTLING URBAN SUBURB, BUT IT IS NOT. PL IS A SMALL SUBURBAN COMMUNITY, WITH A QUAINT DOWN TOWN AND EASY ACCESS TO THREE RUSHING RIVERS, THE RAMAPO, PEQUANNOCK AND WANAQUE, AS WELL AS A LARGE LAKE AND NUMEROUS HIKING TRAILS THROUGH THE MOUNTAINS LOCATED IN OUR BACKYARD. FORMED ON FEBRUARY 26, 1895, PL WAS THE FIRST BOROUGH TO BE FORMED IN PASSAIC COUNTY.  LIKE MOST SMALL COMMUNITIES, PL IS LARGELY BASED AROUND ORGANIZED LONGSTANDING EVENTS, INCLUDING HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS, SENIOR CITIZEN GATHERINGS, AND VARIOUS GROUP ACTIVITIES ORGANIZED BY THE PL RECREATION COMMITTEE. THERE IS A PUBLIC LIBRARY, WITH REGULARLY SCHEDULED READING GROUPS AND ONE OF THE AREA?S LARGEST CATHOLIC CHURCHES, ST. MARY'S, IS LOCATED DIRECTLY ACROSS THE STREET FROM BOROUGH HALL. THERE IS A LARGE WELL-USED YOUTH/TEEN CENTER, WHICH HAS MANY DANCES AND EVENTS FOR OUR YOUTH. POMPTON DAY, THE TOWN'S MAJOR END-OF-SUMMER EVENT, TAKES PLACE EVERY LABOR DAY WEEKEND, WITH THOUSANDS OF RESIDENTS ATTENDING. OTHER POPULAR TOWN EVENTS ARE THE HOLIDAY STROLL, MEMORIAL DAY PARADE, AND TRICK-OR-TREATING DOWNTOWN. PL HAS LONG ESTABLISHED TRADITIONS THAT ARE ORGANIZED AND ATTENDED BY MULTIPLE GENERATIONS OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS. UNFORTUNATELY, ALONG WITH MANY OF OUR GREAT COMMUNITY BASED GROUPS AND ORGANIZATIONS, PL IS HOME TO A HISTORY OF FEW ORGANIZATIONS THAT HAVE LONG SINCE DISBANDED IN OTHER COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT NJ. THESE GROUPS CONSIDER THEMSELVES  AS LOCAL FRATERNITY BASED SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS. ESTABLISHED ALMOST 50 YEARS AGO, THESE STARTED AS CLUBS THAT WERE CONNECTED TO OUR HIGH SCHOOL AND WERE COMPRISED OF STUDENT MEMBERS FROM PL AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES. UNLIKE MOST HIGH SCHOOL CLUBS, MEMBERS STAYED ACTIVE WITH MANY ADULT MEMBERS WELL INTO THEIR 60S. SIMILAR TO OTHER ADULT ORGANIZATIONS, THESE FRATERNITIES HAVE NUMEROUS ALCOHOL RELATED CELEBRATIONS. YOUTH FRATERNITY MEMBERS HAVE BEEN KNOWN TO PARTICIPATE IN THESE CELEBRATIONS, PERMITTED, AND EVEN ENCOURAGED TO DRINK. THE LONG HISTORY AND PAST POPULARITY OF THESE FRATERNITIES IS DEEPLY ENGRAINED IN THE CULTURE OF OUR COMMUNITY, AND DUE TO THE FRATERNITIES MAKING THE UNHEALTHY CHOICE EASIER IT FURTHER BECOMES THE COMMUNITY NORM.ANOTHER EQUALLY AS DANGEROUS NORM IS BEGINNING TO TAKE HOLD, THE USE OF MARIJUANA AND ITS DERIVATIVES AMONG OUR YOUTH. MOST OF OUR COMMUNITY IS AWARE OF THE LINGERING POSSIBILITY OF THE LEGALIZATION OF MARIJUANA, RESIDENTS ARE CONCERNED ABOUT THE OPENING OF A LOCAL CBD STORE AND VAPE STORE IN OUR SMALL DOWNTOWN. MOST OF THE RESIDENTS DO NOT REALIZE THE LARGE SHIFT IN OUR COMMUNITY RELATED TO MARIJUANA. DRIVEN BY CONFUSING MESSAGES REGARDING MARIJUANA AND A NATIONAL PUSH TO LEGALIZE, THE PERCEPTION OF RISK AMONG OUR YOUTH IS DECREASING AT ALARMING RATES. SIMILAR TO THE FREQUENT UNDERAGE DRINKING CONDONED BY OUR ENTRENCHED COMMUNITY-BASED FRATERNITY TRADITIONS, A CULTURE SUPPORTIVE TO MARIJUANA USE HAS OPENED SHOP RIGHT IN OUR DOWNTOWN. THE POMPTON LAKES PREVENTION COALITION (PLPC) HAS DEDICATED ITS WORK TO FOSTER A DRUG-FREE COMMUNITY AND ESTABLISH A NEW CULTURE AND TRADITION THAT MAKES THE HEALTHY CHOICE FOR OUR YOUTH THE MORE POPULAR CHOICE. THE PLPC EDUCATES COMMUNITY MEMBERS, INCREASING HEALTH AND WELLNESS, REDUCING STIGMA, AND PROVIDING YOUTH AN OPPORTUNITY TO EXPRESS THEMSELVES IN HEALTHY, POSITIVE WAYS.

STRAIGHT TALK ABOUT TOUGH STUFF (STATS) COALITION - REETHS-PUFFER SCHOOLS IS LOCATED IN NORTHERN MUSKEGON COUNTY, MICHIGAN ON THE SHORES OF LAKE MICHIGAN.  ORIGINALLY FOUNDED AS THE REETHS-PUFFER RURAL AGRICULTURAL SCHOOL DISTRICT AND LATER NAMED REETHS-PUFFER SCHOOLS IN 1948, TOTAL ENROLLMENT IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 8TH GRADE WAS 298, WITH A TEACHING STAFF OF EIGHT.  TODAY THE DISTRICT COVERS AN AREA OF 70 SQUARE MILES REACHING FIVE TOWNSHIPS.   THE COMMUNITY FINDS ITS IDENTITY IN THE SCHOOLS.  THERE IS NO DOWNTOWN SHOPPING AREA OR CENTRALIZED GOVERNMENT.  YOU CANNOT FIND ?REETHS-PUFFER? ON A MAP.  SINCE OUR MASCOT IS THE ROCKETS, OUR COMMUNITY HAS TAKEN ON THE INFORMAL IDENTITY OF ?ROCKET CITY.?  THIS MONIKER BECOMES OUR RALLYING CRY AS WE SUPPORT OUR STATE CHAMPION MARCHING BAND, LITTLE LEAGUE SOCCER TEAMS, ROBOTICS COMPETITORS, AND SO MANY VARSITY ATHLETIC TEAMS.  REETHS-PUFFER SCHOOLS BOASTS A 91% GRADUATION RATE AND A 4% DROP OUT RATE.  HOWEVER REFERRALS FOR DISCIPLINARY ACTION AND EXPULSION RATES ARE HIGHER THAN THE STATE AVERAGE WITH SUBSTANCE USE, VAPING AND OTHER DRUG USE OFTEN A FACTOR.  REETHS-PUFFER ADMINISTRATORS AND STAFF HAVE INDICATED AN ALARMING RATE OF VAPING ON SCHOOL PROPERTY AND REGULARLY CONFISCATE VAPING DEVICES.  THE POPULATION OF THE REETHS-PUFFER DISTRICT IS 21,660 WITH 3,683 STUDENTS ENROLLED.  STUDENTS ENROLLED ARE 87% WHITE, 4.8% AFRICAN AMERICAN, 4% HISPANIC, AND 3.5% IDENTIFY AS TWO OR MORE RACES.  HALF (50%) OF FAMILIES IN THE DISTRICT QUALIFY AS ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED, AND OVER 11% OF SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN LIVE IN POVERTY.  INCOME DATA SPECIFIC TO THE SCHOOL DISTRICT IS NOT AVAILABLE, THOUGH WE ARE CLOSELY ALIGNED WITH COUNTY AVERAGES.  MUSKEGON COUNTY?S MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME IS $48,885, WHICH IS SIGNIFICANTLY LOWER THAN STATE-WIDE AT $54,840.  PERVASIVE DRINKING, SMOKING AND OUTDOOR PARTIES AND FESTIVALS HAVE BEEN A COMMUNITY NORM.  IN THE EARLY 2000S, MUSKEGON COUNTY WAS KNOWN AS THE "BEER TENT CAPITAL OF THE WORLD"  WITH HEAVY RATES OF BOTH ADULT  AND YOUTH RATES OF ALCOHOL USE.   IN THE PAST 15 YEARS, THE ADULT RATES OF SMOKING AND DRINKING HAVE DECLINED, HOWEVER HEROIN, PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE AND MARIJUANA USE REMAIN STEADY.   MUSKEGON COUNTY HAS SEEN SIGNIFICANT DROPS IN YOUTH SMOKING AND ALCOHOL USE; HOWEVER YOUTH HAVE SHIFTED TO SMOKING MARIJUANA AND VAPING TOBACCO PRODUCTS. MUSKEGON COUNTY IS RECOGNIZED AS A HIGH INTENSITY DRUG TRAFFICKING AREA (HIDTA), WITH EXCELLENT COORDINATION AMONG ITS LAW ENFORCEMENT, COURT, AND JUVENILE JUSTICE PROGRAMS, WITH MULTIPLE SPECIALTY COURTS.   IN THE 2019/20 SCHOOL YEAR, THE MOST-USED DRUGS AMONG TEENS IN REETHS-PUFFER WERE ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND VAPING NICOTINE. AMONG HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, 17.3% REPORTED ALCOHOL USE IN THE PAST 30 DAYS, 15.7% MARIJUANA, AND 20.4% USE OF AN ELECTRONIC VAPING DEVICE.  AMONG MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS, 11.7% REPORTED ALCOHOL USE IN THE PAST 30 DAYS, 13.0% MARIJUANA, AND 6.7% USE OF AN ELECTRONIC VAPING DEVICE.  THE PURPOSE OF STRAIGHT TALK ABOUT TOUGH STUFF (STATS) IS EDUCATION AND PREVENTION IN THE USE OF MARIJUANA AND TOBACCO THROUGH VAPING, AMONG MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS.  AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WE WILL SEE ANNUAL REDUCTIONS IN MARIJUANA USE, A REDUCTION IN VAPING, AND AN INCREASE IN PERCEIVED RISK OF VAPING AND MARIJUANA USE.

IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES TO PREVENT ALCOHOL AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE IN TAYLOR COUNTY YOUTH USING COLLABORATION BETWEEN STUDENTS, COMMUNITY, AND TAYLOR COUNTY DRUG OPPOSITION COALITION. - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY ? COMMUNITY OVERVIEWFUNDING FOR THE TAYLOR COUNTY DRUG OPPOSITION PARTNERS (TCDOP) PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE STRONG COMMUNITY COLLABORATION FOCUSED ON EMPOWERING TAYLOR COUNTY YOUTH TO CHOOSE TO DELAY ONSET AND REDUCE SUBSTANCE USE. TCDOP AND PURE PERFORMANCE, THE YOUTH COALITION, WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES THAT WILL EXPAND ON THE SUCCESSFUL APPROACHES CURRENTLY IN PLACE AND IMPLEMENT NEW STRATEGIES TO IMMERSE THE COMMUNITY WITH PURE PERFORMANCE PRINCIPLES. OUTCOMES TARGET DEVELOPING NEW, WHILE MAINTAINING CURRENT COMMUNITY COLLABORATIONS. YOUTH ALCOHOL USE OUTCOMES WILL TARGET DECREASING CURRENT USE AND BINGE DRINKING, INCREASING PERCEPTION OF RISK/HARM AND DELAYING ONSET OF ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION. TOBACCO OUTCOMES WILL FOCUS ON DECREASING CURRENT USE OF TOBACCO WHILE INCREASING YOUTH PERCEPTION OF RISK/HARM. THE PROJECT WILL CONCENTRATE ACTIVITIES ON EDUCATION, REDUCING ACCESS, CHANGING CONSEQUENCES AND IMPLEMENTATION OF POLICIES. TCDOP WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR FOR RESURGENCE OF METHAMPHETAMINE AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG USE AND ABUSE AS WELL AS MONITORING FOR DELIVERY OF MARIJUANA VIA EDIBLES AND ELECTRONIC DELIVERY. RURAL TAYLOR COUNTY, IN NORTH-CENTRAL WISCONSIN, IS A 1,000 SQUARE MILE RECTANGLE WITH A POPULATION OF 20, 653 (2018 U.S. CENSUS). SEVENTY THREE PERCENT OF THE AREA IS FOREST AND WET LAND; 21 PERCENT IS DAIRY AND CROP FARMLAND, AND SIX PERCENT IS DEVELOPED LAND. ONE-THIRD OF THE COUNTY IS IN THE CHEQUAMEGON NATIONAL FOREST WITH REMOTE PAVED AND GRAVEL ROAD ACCESS TO LAKES, RIVERS AND WILDLIFE. THE RURAL NATURE OF THE COUNTY, WITH RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE FORESTED AREA IS A DRAW FOR OUTDOOR SPORT ENTHUSIASTS AND SUPPORTS A CULTURE OF ALCOHOL ACCEPTANCE. HUNTING SEASON IS A HIGH-RISK PERIOD FOR YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  GRAVEL PITS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY ARE PRIME AREAS FOR SECLUDED YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE PARTIES. MEDFORD IS THE LARGEST CITY, AND THE COUNTY SEAT, WITH A POPULATION OF 4,364 LOCATED  IN THE SOUTH EAST CORNER. TWO OTHER CENTRAL COMMUNITIES ARE GILMAN, ON THE WESTERN BOARDER OF THE COUNTY WITH A POPULATION OF 434 AND RIB LAKE, POPULATION 910, LOCATED IN THE NORTH EAST CORNER OF THE COUNTY. THE HIGHWAY SYSTEM CONSISTS OF TWO-LANE PAVED AND RUSTIC ROADS. WISCONSIN HIGHWAY 29, FIFTEEN MILES SOUTH OF THE SOUTHERN COUNTY BORDER, CONNECTS DIRECTLY WITH MINNEAPOLIS, MINNESOTA, APPROXIMATELY THREE HOURS WEST. CHICAGO ILLINOIS IS FIVE HOURS SOUTH ON INTERSTATE 39.NINETY SIX PERCENT OF TAYLOR COUNTY?S POPULATION IS CAUCASIAN. THREE PERCENT ARE BLACK, ASIAN AND NATIVE AMERICAN. TWO PERCENT OF THE COUNTY?S POPULATION IS OF HISPANIC DESCENT.  OF THE TOTAL POPULATION, 51% ARE MALE, 49% FEMALE. APPROXIMATELY 24% OF THE POPULATION IS UNDER THE AGE OF 18 YEARS. BECAUSE OF THE STRONG EUROPEAN DESCENT, CHRISTIANITY IS THE PROMINENT RELIGION IN TAYLOR COUNTY. THERE ARE NO CLEAR STATISTICS ON GENDER IDENTITY AND SEXUAL ORIENTATION ESPECIALLY AMONG THE YOUTH. POVERTY IS AT 10% FOR THE COUNTY, BUT FOR CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 18, THE POVERTY RATE IS 16%. TWENTY-EIGHT PERCENT OF SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN IN TAYLOR COUNTY SCHOOL DISTRICTS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THE FREE OR REDUCED LUNCH PROGRAM. SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN ATTEND ONE OF THE THREE SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN THE COUNTY. MEDFORD IS THE LARGEST WITH A STUDENT POPULATION OF 2,142, RIB LAKE AND GILMAN SCHOOL DISTRICTS ARE MUCH SMALLER WITH STUDENT POPULATIONS OF 468 AND 306 (2019-2020). ALL THREE DISTRICTS USE EXTENSIVE BUSSING SERVICES TO TRANSPORT STUDENTS FROM THE REMOTE RURAL AREAS. THE COUNTY UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IS 3.4%. THE COMMUNITY DEPENDS HEAVILY ON AGRICULTURE, LOGGING MANUFACTURING/TRADE, UTILITIES, EDUCATION AND HEALTH OCCUPATIONS.  MEDFORD IS THE INDUSTRIAL HUB OF THE COUNTY PROVIDING JOBS IN WINDOW MANUFACTURING, PIZZA AND CHEESE PRODUCTION.

COMMUNITIES THAT CARE OF MARINETTE AND MENOMINEE COUNTIES - THE COMMUNITIES THAT CARE OF MARINETTE & MENOMINEE COUNTIES COALITION SERVES RESIDENTS OF TWO COUNTIES WITHIN TWO DIFFERENT STATES INCLUDING 12 SCHOOL DISTRICTS. MARINETTE COUNTY, WISCONSIN AND MENOMINEE COUNTY, MICHIGAN ARE BORDERING CITIES SEPARATED BY THE MENOMINEE RIVER.  THE GEOGRAPHIC AREA INCLUDES 2,445 SQUARE MILES WITH A COMBINED POPULATION OF 63,356.  OUR COMMUNITIES SPAN 75 MILES FROM THE SOUTHERNMOST COMMUNITY TO THE NORTHERNMOST WHICH MAKES US A RELATIVELY CONSERVATIVE, RURAL AREA WITH AN INDUSTRY-BASED ECONOMY. NINETY-SIX PERCENT OF OUR POPULATION IS CAUCASIAN AND PREDOMINANTLY ENGLISH SPEAKING. OTHER RACES INCLUDE A SMALL POPULATION OF AMERICAN INDIANS (6%), AFRICAN AMERICANS (2.4%) AND HISPANICS (4%) IN MENOMINEE COUNTY, AND A SMALL POPULATION OF HISPANICS (1.5%) IN MARINETTE COUNTY. RELIGIOUS AFFILIATIONS ARE PRIMARILY CHRISTIAN, INCLUDING MANY CATHOLICS, LUTHERANS, BAPTISTS AND ASSEMBLY OF GOD FOLLOWERS. THE TOTAL YOUTH POPULATION (AGES 0-17) IN MENOMINEE COUNTY IS 4,181 AND IN MARINETTE COUNTY IS 7,762. THE TWO LARGEST CITIES WITHIN OUR SERVICE AREA ARE MARINETTE, WI AND MENOMINEE, MI.  ALTHOUGH THEY ARE SEPARATED BY THE MENOMINEE RIVER, THE TWO COMMUNITIES ARE CONSIDERED ONE.  WE HAVE NUMEROUS ORGANIZATIONS SUCH AS THE TRI-COUNTY UNITED WAY, THE MARINETTE MENOMINEE AREA CHAMBER OF COMMERCE AND THE M&M AREA COMMUNITY FOUNDATION THAT SERVICE BOTH COUNTIES. THE UNIQUENESS OF OUR COMMUNITY EVEN ALLOWS FOR ALL LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS TO WORK TOGETHER TO BETTER SERVE THE CITIZENS OF OUR COMMUNITY. ACCORDING TO THE U.S. CENSUS BUREAU IN 2018, MENOMINEE COUNTY REPORTS THAT 11.8% OF ITS RESIDENTS ARE CURRENTLY LIVING IN POVERTY WHICH IS ONLY SLIGHTLY BELOW THE STATE AVERAGE.  MARINETTE COUNTY IS OVER THE STATE AVERAGE OF CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY AT 20% ACCORDING TO THE COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS AND ROADMAPS WEBSITE WHICH CORRELATES WITH THE RECENTLY RISING UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IN MARINETTE COUNTY, ACCORDING TO F IGURES RELEASED BY WISCONSIN?S DEPARTMENT OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN 2017. THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION AND MICHIGAN CENTER OF EDUCATIONAL PERFORMANCE AND INFORMATION REPORTS THAT DURING THE 2018-2019 SCHOOL YEAR, 41-64% OF THE STUDENT POPULATION AT THE PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN MARINETTE AND MENOMINEE COUNTIES PARTICIPATED IN THE FREE OR REDUCED LUNCH PROGRAM.TO GROW UP IN MARINETTE OR MENOMINEE COUNTY IS TO BE RAISED IN AN ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH ALCOHOL AND OVERINDULGENCE ARE ACCEPTED AS NORMAL.  ALCOHOL IS SERVED NOT JUST AT BARS AND RESTAURANTS, BUT ALSO COMMONLY AT GRADUATIONS, FAMILY GATHERINGS, HUNTING CAMPS, CHILDREN?S BIRTHDAY PARTIES, AND MORE. COMMONLY, YOUNG CHILDREN IN THIS AREA GROW UP OBSERVING ALCOHOL ABUSE QUITE FREQUENTLY, AND NATURALLY, MANY TEND TO ACCEPT IT AS NORMAL OR EVEN PARTAKE WITH PARENTS? CONSENT. THERE ARE MANY CONTRADICTING LAWS AND POLICIES SURROUNDING ALCOHOL AND OTHER SUBSTANCE USE WITHIN MINUTES OF EACH OTHER, IN TWO DIFFERENT STATES, AND HAS OUR CHILDREN GROWING UP IN A COMMUNITY WITH MANY QUESTIONS ABOUT WHETHER OR NOT SUBSTANCE USE IS ACTUALLY HARMFUL.THIS AREA HAS ALSO SEEN A SURGE IN HEROIN, COCAINE, AND OTHER NARCOTICS, MAKING THEIR WAY FROM AREAS SUCH AS CHICAGO AND MILWAUKEE; POSSIBLY FOR THE SAME GEOGRAPHIC REASONS THAT CAUSED THE AREA TO BE USED BY BOOTLEGGERS DURING PROHIBITION. DURING THE PROHIBITION ERA, MARINETTE COUNTY WAS USED BY BOOTLEGGERS AS A HIDEOUT OR GATEWAY TO OTHER NORTHERN COMMUNITIES.  ALCOHOL AND OTHER SUBSTANCES, AND ITS ABUSE, ARE UNFORTUNATELY EMBEDDED IN THE CULTURAL FABRIC OF THE AREA.

KEY CONNECTION COALITION DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES - COMMUNITY OVERVIEWTHE CITY OF KENNEWICK IS LOCATED ALONG THE BANKS OF THE COLUMBIA RIVER IN SOUTHEASTERN WASHINGTON STATE. KENNEWICK, THE LARGEST OF THE "TRI-CITIES", SPANS APPROXIMATELY 29 SQUARE MILES AND HAS A POPULATION OF NEARLY 83,000, A 10% INCREASE SINCE 2010. THE CITY'S DIVERSE POPULATION IS 75% WHITE AND 28% HISPANIC OR LATINO ETHNICITY OF ANY RACE. THE CITY'S HISPANIC POPULATION INCREASED 125% FROM 2010 TO 2017. IN 2017, THE HOUSEHOLDS IN KENNEWICK HAD A MEDIAN ANNUAL INCOME OF $54,420, WELL BELOW THE MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME OF $70979 ACROSS WASHINGTON STATE AND $61937 ACROSS THE ENTIRE UNITED STATES. KENNEWICK HAS SEVERAL UNIQUE CHARACTERISTICS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE NORMALIZATION OF SUBSTANCE USE IN THE COMMUNITY BOTH BY YOUTH AND ADULTS. FIRST, RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA WAS LEGALIZED IN WASHINGTON STATE IN 2012. SECOND, THE PRIVATIZATION OF LIQUOR SALES WAS ENACTED IN 2011, LEGALIZING THE SALE OF LIQUOR IN GROCERY STORES AND "BIG-BOX" STORES. FINALLY, THE AREA IS PART OF WASHINGTON'S "WINE COUNTRY", IS HOME TO NUMEROUS WINERIES AND BREWERIES, AND IS LOCATED ON SEVERAL WINE TOUR ROUTES. ALL OF THESE THINGS CONTRIBUTE TO A CULTURE THAT IS NOT ONLY TOLERANT TOWARDS BUT PROMOTES THE USE OF MARIJUANA AND ALCOHOL. THIS IS EVIDENT IN THE DATA WHICH SHOWS THAT A QUARTER OF KENNEWICK'S 12TH GRADERS AND NEARLY 20% OF THE 10TH GRADERS USED ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA IN 2018. EQUALLY CONCERNING IS THE 40% INCREASE IN THE USE OF E-CIGARETTES AND VAPING PRODUCTS BY KENNEWICK'S YOUTH FROM 2016 TO 2018, MIRRORING A NATIONAL INCREASE IN THE POPULARITY OF VAPING PRODUCTS OVER THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS. KENNEWICK YOU HAVE FOUR TIMES AS MANY DRUG-RELATED ARRESTS THAN ALL OF WASHINGTON STATE AND THREE TIMES AS MANY ALCOHOL-RELATED ARRESTS. THEY ALSO HAVE LOWER GRADUATION RATES (77%) THAN ALL OF WASHINGTON STATE (79%), BOTH OF WHICH ARE WELL BELOW THE NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 85%.THE KEY CONNECTION COALITION WAS FO RMED IN LATE 2018 WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF PREVENTING AND REDUCING THE USE OF ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, TOBACCO/E-CIGARETTES, AND NON-PRESCRIPTION OPIOIDS BY KENNEWICK'S YOUTH. IN ITS FIRST YEAR, KEY CONNECTION DEVELOPED A COMPREHENSIVE LONG-RANGE PLAN TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL. THIS STRATEGIC PLAN IS ROOTED IN SAMHSA'S STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK PLANNING MODEL AND THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE. THE COALITION RECEIVED FUNDING FROM WASHINGTON STATE'S COMMUNITY PREVENTION AND WELLNESS INITIATIVE AND IS USING THOSE FUNDS TO ADDRESS YOUTH ALCOHOL USE AND NON-PRESCRIPTION OPIOID MISUSE. IF FUNDED BY DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM, KEY CONNECTION INTENDS TO UTILIZE THE FUNDS TO REDUCE THE USE OF MARIJUANA, E-CIGARETTES/VAPE PRODUCTS, AND ALCOHOL, BY THE COMMUNITY'S YOUTH. THE SPECIFIC OUTCOMES THE COALITION HOPES TO ACHIEVE ARE TO REDUCE THE KENNEWICK'S 10TH GRADERS' USE OF MARIJUANA, E-CIGARETTES/VAPE PRODUCTS, AND ALCOHOL BY 10%, 5%, AND 12%, RESPECTIVELY. KEY CONNECTION PLANS TO IMPLEMENT MULTIPLE STRATEGIES TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS, INCLUDING REDUCING YOUTH ACCESS TO THESE SUBSTANCES AND UTILIZING MEDIA, AWARENESS ACTIVITIES, AND PUBLIC EVENTS TO REDUCE THE FAVORABLE ATTITUDES TOWARDS SUBSTANCE USE AND INCREASE THE PERCEPTION OF HARM FROM SUBSTANCE USE AMONG KENNEWICK'S YOUTH. KEY CONNECTION ALSO AIMS TO IMPROVE ITS OWN CAPACITY AND INCREASE THE COMMUNITY'S AWARENESS OF THE COALITION AND ITS STRATEGIES, BOTH OF WHICH WILL ENHANCE THE COALITION'S ABILITY TO CREATE THE COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE IT SEEKS.

MOBILIZING A COMMUNITY TOWARDS A FRESH START - THE FRESH COALITON WAS AWARDED A FY 2020 DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT IN THE AMOUNT OF $ 125,000 BY THE WHITE HOUSE OFFICE OF NATIONAL DRUG CONTROL POLICY, IN COOPERATION WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. THE COALITION SERVES FRANKLIN COUNTY, VIRGINIA, A COMMUNITY OF 56,419 PEOPLE. FAMILY CONNECTION OF COLUMBIA COUNTY, INC. DRUG FREE COMMUNITY COALITION - COLUMBIA COUNTY IS A GROWING, PROSPEROUS AREA THAT IS PART OF METRO-AUGUSTA, THE SECOND LARGEST METROPOLITAN AREA IN GEORGIA. IT IS LOCATED IN THE EAST CENTRAL PORTION OF GEORGIA ALONG THE SOUTH CAROLINA BORDER. IT IS CONSIDERED THE GATEWAY TO THE FORT GORDON ARMY POST, HOME OF THE U.S. ARMY CYBER CENTER OF EXCELLENCE. THE COUNTY IS MADE UP OF FIVE COMMUNITIES:  APPLING, EVANS, GROVETOWN, HARLEM AND MARTINEZ. IT HAS 290 SQUARE MILES SPLIT BY INTERSTATE 20.  OVER THE LAST 20 YEARS, THE COUNTY HAS BEEN GROWING RAPIDLY, CONCENTRATED IN THE MARTINEZ-EVANS AREA AND IN HARLEM AND GROVETOWN. AS THE COUNTY?S POPULATION HAS GROWN TO 154,291 - A 25% INCREASE IN THE PAST 10 YEARS - IT HAS EVOLVED FROM PRIMARILY RURAL TO AN INCREASINGLY URBAN BEDROOM COMMUNITY.  ABOUT 73.5% OF THE POPULATION IS WHITE, 18.4% AFRICAN AMERICAN, 6.9% HISPANIC, 4.2% ASIAN AND 3% MULTI-RACIAL AND OTHER.  APPROXIMATELY 10% OF THE POPULATION SPEAK A LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH WITH SPANISH BY FAR THE MOST COMMON OTHER LANGUAGE. CHILDREN 18 AND YOUNGER COMPRISE 25% OF THE POPULATION WHILE 11% ARE ACTIVE AND RETIRED MILITARY FAMILIES.  COLUMBIA COUNTY IS MORE URBANIZED THAN ITS RURAL NEIGHBORS, WITH MANY SHOPPING, CULTURAL AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, MOSTLY NEAR EVANS, VOTED ONE OF THE BEST PLACES TO LIVE BY MONEY MAGAZINE IN 2013. SOUTH OF I-20, THE COUNTY IS MORE RURAL AND ITS RESIDENTS ARE MUCH POORER. COLUMBIA COUNTY HAS A LOWER PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE LIVING IN POVERTY THAN ITS NEIGHBORS (16% VS 23.5% FOR THE METRO-AUGUSTA REGION); HOWEVER, IT HAS SEEN A RECENT RISE IN THE PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY. THE FREE AND REDUCED LUNCH RATE HAS GROWN FROM 11% TO 33% IN THE PAST DECADE. POCKETS OF POVERTY ARE LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY, WITH SOME SCHOOLS HAVING 60% TO 70% FRL RATES. EVEN SO, THE MEDIAN INCOME IS $20,000 HIGHER THAN GEORGIA?S. WHILE THERE ARE NO STATISTICS CURRENTLY AVAILABLE, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE AUGUSTA REGION (INCLUDING COLUMBIA COUNTY) HAS THE SEC OND LARGEST LGBTQ POPULATION IN GEORGIA WITH ABOUT 27% HAVING CHILDREN SCHOOL-AGED OR YOUNGER. APPROXIMATELY 41% OF THE RESIDENTS CONSIDER THEMSELVES RELIGIOUS. A MAJORITY IDENTIFY WITH VARIOUS CHRISTIAN DENOMINATIONS AND 3% IDENTIFY WITH JUDAISM, ISLAM AND OTHER EASTERN RELIGIONS. THE SCHOOL SYSTEM HAS 23,340 STUDENTS ATTENDING 18 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, EIGHT MIDDLE SCHOOLS, FIVE HIGH SCHOOLS AND ONE ALTERNATIVE SCHOOL. STUDENT DEMOGRAPHICS MIRROR THOSE OF THE COUNTY. THE HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATION RATE IS 92%, HIGHER THAN THE STATE AVERAGE. MANY ADULTS WORK LONG HOURS OUTSIDE THE HOME AND HAVE AN AVERAGE COMMUTE TIME OF 30 MINUTES LEAVING YOUTH WITH UNSUPERVISED OUT-OF-SCHOOL TIME. THERE ARE ONLY A HANDFUL OF SUPERVISED AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS. MOST HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS HAVE THEIR OWN CARS, MONEY AND FREE TIME TO INDULGE IN A VARIETY OF RISKY BEHAVIORS. LAKE THURMOND PROVIDES THE SITE FOR MANY TEEN PARTIES WHERE ALCOHOL IS COMMONLY USED. THERE IS EASY ACCESS TO ALCOHOL AND OTHER DRUGS, MOSTLY FROM HOMES. JUVENILE COURT IS PACKED WITH MINOR IN POSSESSION CHARGES. FIVE YEARS AGO, RESIDENTS WERE STEEPED IN DENIAL THAT ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA AND OTHER DRUGS PRESENTED PROBLEMS IN COLUMBIA COUNTY.  THANKS TO THE FAMILY CONNECTION?S DRUG FREE COMMUNITY COALITION AND THE DFC SUPPORT PROGRAM GRANT THEY RECEIVED FROM 2015 THROUGH 2020, IMPRESSIVE INROADS IN CHANGING THOSE PERCEPTIONS HAVE BEEN MADE.  THE FAMILY CONNECTION HAS LONG HISTORY OF BRINGING THE RIGHT FOLKS TO THE TABLE TO IDENTIFY AND TACKLE ALL SORTS OF PROBLEMS, AND THEIR DFCC HAS CONTINUED THIS TRADITION IN TACKLING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  NOT ONLY IS THE COMMUNITY MORE AWARE OF THE PROBLEMS RELATED TO YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE, BUT THERE IS STRONG PUBLIC WILL TO SUPPORT THE DFCC?S EFFORTS TO ADDRESS THEM.  MULTIPLE STRATEGIES TO REDUCE ACCESS AND CHANGE THE NORMS OF ACCEPTANCE TO THOSE THAT RECOGNIZE NO-USE IS THE BETTER OPTION ARE CURRENTLY IN PLACE AND WILL BE EXPANDED DURING

CAYA DRUG-FREE COALITION - THE COALITION SERVES ST. CROIX, VI, A COMMUNITY OF 50,061.  THE GOALS OF THE COALITION ARE TO ESTABLISH AND STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN SUPPORT OF LOCAL EFFORTS TO PREVENT YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.  THE COALITION WILL ACHIEVE ITS GOALS BY IMPLEMENTING THESE STRATEGIES: SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGNS, PREVENTION MESSAGING, PEER LEADERSHIP, AND CAPACITY BUILDING TO REDUCE YOUTH ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION AND MARIJUANA USE.

DRUG FREE COMMUNITIES (DFC) SUPPORT PROGRAM - DFC PROJECT SUMMARYPROJECT NAME- YUMA COUNTY ANTI-DRUG COALITION YUMA IS A GROWING COMMUNITY WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 209,756. YUMA COUNTY, ARIZONA IS THE 5TH LARGEST COUNTY IN ARIZONA. YUMA IS THE LARGEST CITY IN ARIZONA OUTSIDE THE METROPOLITAN AREAS OF PHOENIX. DURING THE WINTER MONTHS, YUMA COUNTY IS ALSO HOME TO 80,000 TO 100,000 WINTER VISITORS AND TUCSON. THE CITY?S GROWTH IS REFLECTED IN MORE THAN 21,500 NEW RESIDENTS SINCE THE LAST CENSUS.YUMA IS A YOUNG COMMUNITY WITH AN AVERAGE AGE OF 31.3 YEARS. THE CITY?S ETHNICITY IS DOMINATED BY ITS HISPANIC (55.7%) AND WHITE (35.7%) POPULATIONS. YUMA?S LARGEST AGE COHORT IS 20 TO 29 YEARS. THERE ARE 48,328 MALE RESIDENTS LIVING IN YUMA AND 47,245 FEMALE RESIDENTS.WITH ONE IN EVERY FIVE OF YUMA?S RESIDENTS IMPOVERISHED, OR 20.7% BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL, THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH & HUMAN SERVICES CONFIRMS YUMA AS A HIGH NEEDS AREA. POVERTY RATES WERE HIGHER AMONG MINORITIES. AMONG HISPANIC RESIDENTS, FOR EXAMPLE, THE POVERTY RATE WAS ESTIMATED AT 26.0%. THE ROBERT WOOD JOHNSON FOUNDATION?S 2015 SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC FACTORS RANKING PLACED YUMA IN THE WORST THIRD OF THE COUNTIES IN THE STATE. YUMA COUNTY?S RATE OF POPULATION BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL RANKS IN THE MIDDLE OF ARIZONA COUNTIES, BUT IN THE WORST THIRD FOR THE PORTION BELOW THE LOW- INCOME LEVEL, COMMONLY CALCULATED AS TWO TIMES THE POVERTY LEVEL.THE SHIFTS IN ATTITUDES TOWARDS AND NORMALIZATION OF USE OF DRUGS LIKE MARIJUANA AND VAPING HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO INCREASED SUBSTANCE ABUSE IN OUR COMMUNITIES. ADDITIONALLY, THERE HAS BEEN A LACK OF COORDINATED PREVENTION PROGRAMS AND CONSISTENT EFFORTS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO THE COMMUNITY. OUR PROXIMITY TO THE BORDER AND THE INCREASE IN SYNTHETIC DRUGS BEING AVAILABLE HAS INCREASED USE AS WELL AS A LACK OF PERCEPTION OF THE SIGNIFICANT DANGERS. THE YUMA COUNTY ANTI-DRUG COALITION (YCADC) IS A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY COALITION WITH MEMBERS FROM MANY DIFFERENT COMMUNITY SECTORS AND WE STRIVE TO BRING SUBSTANCE ABUSE PREVENTION, EDUCATION, AWARENESS AND TREATMENT RESOURCES TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE AGENCIES, KEY STAKEHOLDERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS COLLABORATING FOR THE YCADC ALSO STRIVE TO LINK THOSE
OPEN DOORS COMMUNITY  SCHOOL'S PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MARANA PREVENTION ALLIANCE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PREVENTING YOUTH SUBSTANCE USE.

WEST HAVEN PREVENTION COUNCIL - THE CITY OF WEST HAVEN (CT) IS ON THE LONG ISLAND SOUND, BETWEEN MILFORD AND NEW HAVEN, EIGHTY MILES FROM NEW YORK CITY, CONNECTED BY RAIL AND MAJOR HIGHWAYS.  WEST HAVEN SITS IMMEDIATELY ON THE I-95 INTERSTATE DRUG CORRIDOR.  WEST HAVEN IS A MID-SIZED CITY WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 55,044 (CT ECONOMIC RESOURCE CENTER [CERC], 2017).  THE CITY IS RELATIVELY LOW MEDIAN HOUSEHOLD INCOME ($55,299) SIGNIFICANTLY LOWER THAN THE STATE ($73,781) AND COUNTY ($64,872). (CERC 2009)  CORRESPONDINGLY, ITS POVERTY RATE IS HIGHER: 13.2% COMPARED TO 10.1% FOR THE STATE AND 12.1% FOR THE COUNTY.  THE CITY IS RACIALLY AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE WITH A BREAKDOWN OF 51.8% WHITE; 22.4% BLACK; 21.0% HISPANIC; AND 3.9% ASIAN (LOCAL DATA IS DRAWN FROM UDSMAPPER.ORG).  WEST HAVEN HAS A LARGE FOREIGN BORN POPULATION OF 15.9%, COMPARED TO 13.7% FOR THE COUNTRY.  WITH REGARD TO LANGUAGE 72% OF THE POPULATION SPEAK ONLY ENGLISH, AND 28% SPEAK SOME OTHER LANGUAGE.  THE MOST PROMINENT NON ENGLISH SPEAKING LANGUAGE IS SPANISH AT 18%.  THE WEST HAVEN PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM HAS APPROXIMATELY 6,091 STUDENTS ENROLLED IN ONE HIGH SCHOOL (WITH AN ALTERNATIVE EDUCATION SCHOOL), ONE SCHOOL HOUSING 5TH AND 6TH GRADERS, ONE SCHOOL HOUSING 7TH AND 8TH GRADERS, AND SIX ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS.  THE CITY ALSO HAS TWO PRIVATE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS AND ONE PRIVATE HIGH SCHOOL.  THE LARGEST EMPLOYERS ARE THE VA MEDICAL CENTER, UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAVEN AND YALE UNIVERSITY.  WHILE THERE IS NO BREAKDOWN OF RELIGIOUS DATA THAT COULD BE FOUND FOR THE CITY, THE COUNTY DATA REFLECTS THAT 51.2% REPORT NO RELIGIOUS AFFILIATION, 35.3% CATHOLIC, 11% PROTESTANT, AND 2.3% OTHER.  THE WEST HAVEN DRUG & ALCOHOL TASK FORCE WAS INCORPORATED IN 1985 THROUGH THE STATE OF CONNECTICUT'S OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY OF THE STATE.  THE COMMITTEE WAS FORMED AS A RESULT OF CONCERNS VOICED AT FROM THE PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM'S PTA AROUND ISSUES OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE.  OVER THE YEARS, THERE WAS NEVER SUFFICIENT FUNDING  TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE DATA DRIVEN APPROACH TO THE REDUCTION OF YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE, NOR DID THE COALITION MAINTAIN BROAD REPRESENTATION OR RECOGNITION.  THE RECENT APPROACH HAS BEEN TO PROVIDE STRATEGIES AND EVENTS TO INDIVIDUAL SCHOOLS, AND AGAIN THE LACK OF ANY PAID, DEDICATED STAFF AND FUNDING PREVENTED THE COALITION FROM CREATING A STRONG SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE ON THE VARIETY OF PLATFORMS THAT YOUTH ACCESS.  DESPITE THE LONGSTANDING PRESENCE OF THE COALITION, THE LACK OF RESOURCES DID NOT AFFORD THE OPPORTUNITY FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE.THE WEST HAVEN PREVENTION COUNCIL (WHPC) WILL EMPLOY ITS COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP, AND THE KEY GRANT PERSONNEL TO EFFECT COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE. THE MECHANISM TO ACHIEVE THIS IS THE UTILIZATION OF SAMHSA'S STRATEGIC PREVENTION FRAMEWORK (SPF) AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SEVEN STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY LEVEL CHANGE TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION STRATEGIES IN WEST HAVEN.  THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND TO REDUCE YOUTH USE OF ALCOHOL AND MARIJUANA.  THE COALITION WILL INCREASE ITS MEMBERSHIP BY 25% AND ITS LEADERSHIP BY 100%.  THE USE OF ALCOHOL WILL BE REDUCED BY ADDRESSING LOCAL ROOT CAUSES OF AVAILABILITY AND FAVORABLE ATTITUDES; THE USE OF MARIJUANA WILL BE REDUCED BY ADDRESSING THE ROOT CAUSES OF LOW PERCEPTION OF HARM AND AVAILABILITY.

PUTNAM WELLNESS COALITION PLANS TO POSITIVELY IMPACT THE KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIORS OF PUTNAM COUNTY YOUTH AND ADULTS REGARDING SUBSTANCE ABUSE. - THE PUTNAM WELLNESS COALITION HAS RECOGNIZED A NEED TO ADDRESS YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE ISSUES IN THE COUNTY ANDHAS BEEN INSTRUMENTAL IN DETERMINING APPROACHES THAT WILL DECREASE RISK FACTORS AND INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS. THECOALITION PRIMARILY TARGETS YOUTH WITH REGARD TO MARIJUANA USE PRESCRIPTION DRUG ABUSE AND UNDERAGE DRINKING. THECOALITION WORKS ON A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE FOLLOWING RECENT ACCOMPLISHMENTS: 1) ALCOHOL COMPLIANCECHECKS: THE COALITION WORKS WITH LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AND ABCA IN PUTNAM COUNTY TO COMPLETE COMPLIANCE CHECKSAT A HIGHER RATE THAN OTHER SURROUNDING COUNTIES AND THE STATE AS A WHOLE. 2) YOUTH INVOLVEMENT AND MEDIA: OVER THEPAST FEW YEARS, THE COALITION HELD CONTESTS WHICH RESULTED IN MULTIPLE YOUTH-LED AND YOUTH-CREATED BILLBOARDS AND RADIOPSA'S FOCUSING ON MULTIPLE SUBSTANCES. 3) YOUTH LEADERSHIP AND COALITION INVOLVEMENT: PUTNAM WELLNESS HAS BEENINSTRUMENTAL IN PLACING AND STRENGTHENING STUDENTS AGAINST DESTRUCTIVE DECISIONS (SADD) CHAPTERS, OR YOUTHCOALITIONS, IN ALL 8 OF THE MIDDLE/HIGH SCHOOLS IN THE COUNTY. 4) POLICY CHANGES: ONE OF THE MOST NOTABLE COALITIONACCOMPLISHMENTS IS THE PASSING OF A SOCIAL HOST ORDINANCE IN JULY 2015. THIS WAS THE FIRST SOCIAL HOST ORDINANCE INTHE STATE OF WV AND IS FOR THE PURPOSE OF HOLDING ADULTS LEGALLY LIABLE FOR PROVIDING SPACE TO THOSE UNDER THE AGE OF 21YEARS TO DRINK ALCOHOL OR USE ANY OTHER DRUG WITHIN PUTNAM COUNTY. THE COALITION HAS ALSO BEEN INSTRUMENTAL IN MAKINGPOLICY CHANGES WITHIN LOCAL BUSINESSES REGARDING EMPLOYEE SUBSTANCE USE AND CLIENT MEDICATION DISPOSAL. THECOALITION HAS REDEFINED ITSELF OVER THE YEARS TO PRIMARILY FOCUS ON THE AREA WHERE THERE IS THE GREATEST NEED - YOUTHSUBSTANCE USE AND ABUSE. THE COALITION PLANS TO CONTINUE TO DEDICATE EFFORTS TO REDUCING YOUTH SUBSTANCE ABUSE,INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS, DECREASING RISK FACTORS, AND MAKE POSITIVE SOCIAL NORM CHANGES IN THE COUNTY FOR MANYYEARS TO COME.
